PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Education
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government schools costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to Local Government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in General Revenue Grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend certain Acts in consequence of the establishment of the Australian Government Solicitor.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of amendments to legislation consequential upon the provisions of the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 for the establishment of the Australian Government Solicitor. A number of Commonwealth Acts contain references to the Crown Solicitor or to a Deputy Crown Solicitor. A number of these references are such that they may not be conveniently dealt with by the interpretation provision contained in that Bill, by which references to the Crown Solicitor or a Deputy Crown Solicitor were to be converted into references to the Australian Government Solicitor. It has therefore been found necessary to make specific amendments to the Acts in question.

Generally speaking, the provisions which are amended by the present Bill are such as to require a person to be identified for the purposes of the relevant provision. The approach taken in this Bill is to amend those provisions so that references to the Crown Solicitor or a Deputy Crown Solicitor are translated into references to the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department or to an officer of that Department authorised by him to act in the name of the Australian Government Solicitor. It will be recalled that, in setting up the Australian Government Solicitor as a body corporate, it is intended that all acts done in the name of the body corporate shall be done by the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department or by legally qualified officers of that Department authorised by the Secretary for the purpose. The Bill is purely of a technical and consequential kind. It is proposed to be debated cognately later today with the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill, but as I said briefly yesterday evening, I shall not be criticising the Wool Industry Amendment Bill in my statements today but rather referring to the reasons given by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) which, in total, seem to blame the depressed market conditions rather than address the issue of lack of government action in this area and the effects of other government action on the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night I referred to the fact that in the six months prior to the flotation of the Australian dollar in December last year, the dollar revalued by up to 15 per cent on a wool trade weighted index. Local merino type wools were then quoted up to 50c a kilogram higher than their South African counterparts. The Australian Wool Corporation consistently purchased as a result of that in the four months following the opening of the wool selling season in July last year 30 per cent of the catalogue boosting its stockpile from 400,000 bales to 1.3 million bales.

Following the flotation of the dollar in December, the Corporation came under a great deal of criticism for its decision not to adjust the floor price mechanism . The Australian Council of Wool Buyers, for example, went so far as to say that if a revaluation of between 3 per cent to 5 per cent occurred, overseas buying of Australian wool would cease completely. The revaluation has been of the order of 4.6 per cent and the Australian Council of Wool Buyers predictions have not at this stage proved true. Indeed, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in its Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy in the February 1984 edition predicted under the optimistic heading 'Prices to improve in 1984':

For the 1984 calendar year, the average price is forecast to be 510c/kg and 540c/kg clean, with the most likely price being around 520c/kg clean, 9 per cent above the average price in November. Australian auction prices should improve significantly in the second half of the 1983-84 season (July-June) as offerings decline, stocks in South Africa are further reduced and demand strengthens in line with improving economic activity.

In fact, what has happened is almost the exact opposite of that optimistic prediction. Prospects for a predicted recovery in the wool market took a heavy blow at the auctions in Brisbane and Adelaide last week. The Australian Wool Corporation was forced to intervene buying to about 30 per cent of the 60,000 bales offered to reach the highest point to date for the second half of the season. The market indicator at the close of the week was 3c down at 487c per kilogram clean, although the quote is still being distorted by the effect of the 19 micron demand squeeze generated from February tradings.

The market indicator is still being supported to a large extent by the nominal 19 micron-type quotations. The removal of these quotations would take at least another 5c to 7c from the present stated level of the indicator, leaving it at about 10c to 12c above the floor price. Last week's slump appears to have been triggered by a combination of the catalogue affixed in Adelaide which usually sells to the Eastern European competition, and a large offering of pre-sale dumped wool in Brisbane. Nevertheless, the extreme volatility of the Australian dollar on the market-again this was exemplified last week-my Party believes is a complicating factor and has led to a depression of the market.

Another factor which obviously is important is the comparatively low reserve prices in South Africa and New Zealand. Also important is the virtual non- appearance of China in the wool sales. In spite of constant predictions that China will appear, very little has occurred. In fact, China has been buying only a very small quantity of crossbred fleece. If we take all these factors into consideration, we believe that the effects of the world currency in the wool trade weighted index is probably the most critical factor currently affecting the Australian wool industry. Therefore, it is extremely easy to sympathise with the Corporation in the situation in which it finds itself, a situation which has necessitated this Bill.

I will mention some other factors before suggesting what we believe ought to be the action that should be taken by the Government at this time. I refer first to wool promotion funding. At the half yearly conference of the Wool Council of Australia in November last year increased promotional funding was seen as the major priority in the coming months. Indeed, there was a projected shortfall of $18m in 1983-84 and $21.5m in 1984-85, and Senator Scott in his speech last night alluded to this aspect. The shortfall is currently being funded by the Wool Corporation's reserves, but obviously this is a short term measure. The industry needs to develop a long term policy. The decision to establish a wool promotion trust account and redirect one per cent of current woolgrowers' levies to the fund specifically for additional promotion will certaintly go part way to meeting the problem. The fact that this decision was reached as a result of the Chairman's casting vote suggests that there is still a fair amount of confusion within the industry as to the usefulness of this activity and as to how it will contribute in the longer term. We will have to wait and see about that.

The Government has contributed to the problems in wool promotion. I remind the Senate that during the election campaign last year the Australian Labor Party promised $28m a year in funding for promotion. Last year's Budget allowed for only $20m, $8m short of the election promise. This shortfall on the Australian Labor Party's election promise becomes very important in terms of the commitment of the Corporation and other wool-growing bodies to funding new markets, particularly given the International Wool Secretariat's $US42.5m wool promotion in the United States during the next five years. The Australian Wool Corporation is fully behind this promotion. Given that the Corporation's reserves are being used to fund the shortfalls in wool promotion funding, it is quite clear that the breaking of the Australian Labor Party election promise on this matter has put further pressure on the Corporation's finances. This, in turn, has necessitated this Bill we are now discussing.

It was therefore with considerable enthusiasm that I greeted the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 8 March that the Federal Government would reassess the 1983-84 Budget decision not to increase wool promotion funding. According to Mr Hawke, the Government had been unable to lift its contribution to the promised amount because of budgetary constraints, but things had now improved and he was now directing that the matter be brought forward for discussion before the normal 1984-85 Budget discussion. Mr Hawke, when he made that statement on 8 March, was speaking at an open day at the merino stud property of Mr Rupert Murdoch at Deniliquin. He obviously expected that his speech would be widely reported, as indeed it was. Consequently, there arose the expectation that the Government would soon honour its election promise. If we consider last Saturday's New South Wales election results in the country seats, we might say that the activity of the Prime Minister in that regard had borne some fruit.

When I was preparing notes for this speeech during the last couple of days I thought that the $28m per annum promise by the Prime Minister was a step in the right direction. According to the most recent estimates, the promotion costs will be of this order: $60m to the International Wool Secretariat, $8.5m for the special United States promotion campaign and a very heavy domestic commitment. Given all those factors, I thought the Prime Minister's promise was a step in the right direction. However, Mr Kerin informed us, when launching the New South Wales ALP rural policy, that the Government would definitely be breaking its election promise yet again because he said the Government would be granting $25m in 1984-85. To be fair, this is a step in the right direction, especially as it appears that the Government has accepted in principle the formula proposal of the Wool Council of Australia that the Government pay a dollar for every two dollars raised by wool growners, but it is still a total of $12m short of the Government's election promise at this stage, $12m which the industry drastically needs. The industry has paid out $12m over and above what we believe it should in order that the Corporation sustain itself within its financial structures; hence this Bill.

I would like to refer briefly to a couple of other items, not tangential to this Bill but which I think are important in overall financing. At the Queensland Wool Centre at Rocklea an experiment in tri-packing prior to sale is currently being carried out. It is rather interesting to note that while tri- packing has gone on after sales, this is the first experiment in doing it prior to sales. It would seem from the results at the moment that there have been savings of almost a million dollars a year. If that is the case, the Wool Corporation, in giving its full support to this system, is certainly heading in the right direction.

The centralisation of wool sales which is taking place has been far less popular within the industry. Wool sales are being centralised at six major centres rather than being spread across 15 sales rooms as at present. The Wool Corporation has bought into this dispute by virtue of its report 'The Preparation for Shipping Arrangements for Wool in New South Wales', which was released in May of last year. The Corporation has had further difficulties in this area, due, I believe, to its constituency, its peronnel. I do not wish to go too far into this but there could be conflicts of interest between certain people because of the various hats that they wear, some of which will be resolved by 30 June of this year. I believe it is an area that we should pay attention to. This involves a delicate public policy area, one which I think can cause disquiet within the industry, and is of some concern to the growers.

I think the other activity of the Corporation, selling wool sight unseen, demands fairly close scrutiny, particularly in relation to the proposed introduction of sale by description. I understand that equipment problems have arisen and that this has delayed the introduction of the first steps of this procedure, we believe, by up to about three months. It is now expected to be in operation by the end of this year. The various steps in this procedure do lead one to have some concerns but provided it continues along its present track the computerised selling operation, which is due to be completely operational within a 5-year period, should be a boon to the industry. If the buyers end up accepting the proposal-and approximately 90 per cent of them accept it-there will be a 14c per kilogram saving in transport and handling charges.

I raise this matter in debate on this Bill because the enormous costs involved in the implementation of the system have put a further strain on the Corporation 's finances at a time when it is under pressure elsewhere. The negative reaction of buyers to having the procedure forced upon them has encouraged them to look elsewhere. In my opinion, it is clear that we must eventually get to this method of selling but at this time I would caution about moving too quickly, particularly bearing in mind the current high volatility of the wool market.

Last night, Senator Watson referred to the floor price mechanism, which is extremely important in terms of wool and is something about which anybody involved with the industry is always concerned. Senator Watson's comments were quite pertinent. I add to the points he raised the fact that the Corporation itself, through its Chairman, has bought into this operation in a sharp and defined way and has opted to leave the floor price mechanism unaltered. The reason given is that the industry needs to put more weight on the element of risk concerning the Australian dollar but it has rejected the suggestion put forward at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference last year that a set percentage, between 10 per cent and 15 per cent, be maintained between the floor and the market to cover the risks of dollar fluctuation. The Chairman has said that while there needs to be a greater awareness of the risk involved, the industry should retain the setting of the floor on the basis of the world outlook for wool. It is fine to say that but in reality that comment fails to address the critical situation in which the market currently finds itself. Indeed, it is a situation in which it has basically found itself for the last nine months and a situation which, if one listens to the economic predictions, is not likely to go away very rapidly.

We believe we need to address this matter now. This Bill does help slightly by allowing the Corporation to borrow from a wider range of sources; and certainly it allows it to borrow at much more competitive rates than it has been able to do in the past. But we must ask how much further into debt the Corporation can afford to go. Since the start of the 1983-84 wool selling season on 1 July, the Corporation has gone from having liquid assets in the market support fund of more than $250m to having a potential debt of $115m. It has also drawn heavily on other reserves and has spent income from wool sales and wool tax. The total amount spent by the Corporation in market support activities since 1 July is estimated to be more than $400m to the beginning of this year, with the stockpile increasing by more than half a million bales. The situation is delicate in the extreme; I see that Senator Watson indicates that possibly it is something even worse than delicate. What needs to be done we believe needs to be done rapidly.

We support the notion that, in the light of the various items that I have raised and in the light of the fact that one cannot see, even with this Bill, terribly much hope on the horizon, all relevant bodies need to come together-the producers, sellers and buyers, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics-to look at the current situation and to look at our market procedures. The only body which could assist in achieving that result would be the Government. So the Australian Democrats call on the Government to organise a summit on this matter as soon as possible.

The summit would need to consider the effects of the fluctuations in the Australian dollar and other relevant currencies on the Australian wool industry, the comparative reserve prices in South Africa and New Zealand, the changing buying patterns of our major traders, including China-we have been told that there are some hopeful signs on the horizon in that regard but we are still looking for them-the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Yugoslavia, appropriate levels of government assistance to wool promotion, tri-pack selling, the centralisation of wool sales, selling wool sight unseen, the floor price mechanism and the current indebtedness of the Australian Wool Corporation and other matters some of which have been raised by Senator Watson and Senator Scott in this debate and which I will not be able to go into due to the shortness of time. These items include rising freight costs and expenditure on wool research.

I feel that if we do not sit down now and solve these urgent problems, if we merely stand by and watch the indebtedness of the Corporation increase, the Government will be called upon to bail out the industry and it will have to bail it out to the tune of a fairly massive amount because undoubtedly at that point there will be nothing else that the Government could do. Why wait? Why allow the industry to move through to that extremely critical situation? Why not work with the industry now and have in place an agreed formula and an agreed understanding of where we are going? Undoubtedly the Government will be called upon to assist. I believe that if it makes its move at this time we could very well avert what might be a catastrophic situation for the wool industry of Australia. Without immediate Government action it is difficult to predict the future. I believe that the trends which are currently appearing do not give us very much hope. We may be looking at a disastrous future for one of the most important rural industries in Australia.

I commend the Bill to the Senate but urge the Government not to allow its activity in this area to stand solely on this Bill. Rather it should take the further initiative of working with everybody concerned in the industry to get in place a coherent, cohesive and effective plan that will take us through to 2000 in such a way as to allow our growers to be confident that there is a bright future for this important rural industry, one upon which so much of rural Australia depends for its livelihood.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 December 1983 I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), who represents the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in this place, several questions about the pre-sale dumping of wool at the Queensland Wool Centre. I was less than satisfied with some aspects of the response, but as I believed there were only six months remaining of the 12 month trials, I decided to wait for the results of the commercial evaluation. I hoped that the study being undertaken by the Australian Wool Corporation would prove whether the continuation of the Queensland Wool Centre trial was warranted on commercial grounds. I have now changed my position as a result of a report in last Friday's Australian Financial Review which indicated that more information will be sought in relation to pre-sale dumping and that sales will be supported through the floor price for a further 12 month period. The Minister's replied to my question as to whether the Government should intervene should wool brokers proceed with the installation of further pre-sale dumping, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation has indicated it will not continue a reserve price support indefinitely for pre-sale dumped wool unless the system proves its commercial viability and potential net benefit to the wool industry.

The Australian Financial Review article reported that the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr David Asimus, had said that: 'it would be very reasonable to extend the support for another 12 months as the market must get above the floor price level'. What is so surprising is that at the last meeting with the brokers, the Australian Wool Processors Council was told that pre-sale dumping at the Queensland Wool Centre was an outstanding success and had fulfilled all the objectives set. Only two months later the Australian Wool Corporation has seen fit to continue to propose the operation through the floor price. Not since 1980 has the Australian Wool Corporation conducted a detailed comparative study of the more restricted attempt at pre-sale dumping, known as the jumbo bale exercise. One would have thought that in matters of this nature continuous monitoring would have to be undertaken in order to assess the acceptance level under varying demand conditions. There must be some correlation between the two forms of pre-sale dumping, for the Corporation has indicated that the difference in the jumbo price and farm bales would be greater than that anticipated from tripacks.

If the Australian Wool Corporation can forecast this with such preciseness I for one cannot see why it cannot evalute the acceptance level of tri-packs by the lack of response they have received from China and Russia. Together the Japanese mills and the Australian industry purchase about two thirds of our clip . Certainly, during February when wool prices rose above the floor level it was reported that tri-packs were quoted 2 per cent lower than farm bales.

It has been stated that tri-packs would be considerably cheaper at the Queensland Wool Centre if the normal proportion of skirtings had been offered. If the Wool Corporation has extended the trial period to assess the influence of tri-packs on the selling price, I suggest that skirting should represent only 17 per cent of the total sold in tri-packs, not 80 per cent as was offered during the most recent sale. This is certainly not representative of the final proportions and must distort any investigation into demand and price.

I indicate that this is not an isolated instance of a distorted clip representation. Skirting represented about 75 per cent in the previous offering. At the beginning I explained that I was less than satisfied with the replies received through the Department of Primary Industry from the Australian Wool Corporation. The first two replies were evasive, although it was indicated that detailed comparisons were currently being undertaken. I ask now why these comparisons, as well as the assessments made in the desk studies by the investors in the Queensland Wool Centre, cannot be made available to all parties concerned for the purpose of appraisal and comment. I asked the Minister in my question--

TALK.START.PARA: —What question was this?

—I referred earlier, before the Minister for Resources and Energy came into the chamber, to a series of questions I put on notice on 1 December 1983. I am referring now to the answers and demonstrating some of the doubts I have about them. In a question directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy representing the Minister for Primary Industry I asked that an international authority on commodity handling undertake the comparisons and commercial appraisal. I requested that this approach be considered not because I did not believe that the Australian Wool Corporation was competent, but because I felt that impartiality must be achieved and demonstrated. Certainly bias was demonstrated in the reply from the Minister, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a study into the comparative effects of pre-sale dumping on the wool industry is being undertaken by the Australian Wool Corporation on behalf of woolgrowers.

He did not say this was on behalf of the buyer and users; he stated specifically that it was on behalf of the woolgrowers. How can the evaluation of the net benefits to the wool industry be unbiased when the buyers and users have been excluded from studies and earlier assessments?

The Australian Wool Processors Council has indicated to me that it is appreciative of the understanding displayed by the Minister for Primary Industry . In fact it undertook to support sales at the Queensland Wool Centre as a result of this understanding, even though overseas buyers walked out of the sales to demonstrate their opposition. I understand that the Australian Wool Processors Council, whose members process more than 20 per cent of the Australian clip, are giving serious consideration to boycotting the Queensland Wool Centre as a result of what they consider to be a breach of an understanding . The competitive position of the local industry is aggravated, as it cannot take advantage of the lower freight rates for superdensity dumped wools. This does reduce their competitiveness on overseas markets. While they see this as a commercial hazard, they are seriously disadvantaged by the charges made for a pack which they do not want and which adds a considerable amount to their costs, as these bales must then be de-dumped. In fact it doubles the original dumping charge, so they are paying twice for something they do not want. So far, discussions with brokers have yielded nothing and have been described to me as circular negotiations, getting nowhere.

I put it to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry that this matter can hardly be considered purely a commercial one, for discussions among the parties concerned are really yielding nothing. The extension of the trial period could quite easily develop into a situation where attendance at the Queensland Wool Centre will be limited to the European buyers who accept the bales because of freight savings. What I also find surprising is that within the last week the brokers involved in the Queensland Wool Centre have invited wool buyers to join with them to determine the features that need to be exercised to evaluate properly pre-sale dumping trials. Surely after the original investigation and six months of trial it is a somewhat belated attempt by the brokers to see what features need to be exercised.

It seems to me that this latest nonsense will result in another circular discussion designed as an iron lung to extend the life of the faltering trial into pre-sale dumping, something that has been mishandled from the time it was forced on to the industry. I am not saying that there are not advantages in pre- sale dumping. What I am saying is that when a form of packaging that is not wanted is introduced without consultation, and additional charges are made for this unwanted package as well as placing additional burdens on sectors of the industry, the exercise will need propping up. That is what is happening, as is evidenced by the Australian Wool Corporation having to buy up to 90 per cent of the fleece wools offered in tri-packs.

I suggest that this matter has become critical and that this Government should not stand aside from an issue that could seriously jeopardise the sales of Queensland wool and the operations of the Australian processors as well as redirect our major customers to purchase from South America, South Africa, New Zealand and their own domestic wools. I say that in the spirit of constructive comment. As I said at the outset, it is important that top level discussions be carried out, including wool processors, because I believe it is of critical importance to the industry that we sustain the valuable help that has been provided by the wool processors of Australia.

AUSTRALIAN WOOL PROCESSORS COUNCILS' POSITION SUBSEQUENT TO DISCUSSION WITH THE NATIONAL COUNCIL OF WOOL SELLING BROKERS OF AUSTRALIA-2ND FEBRUARY, 1984

1. This council is not convinced that sufficient thought has been given to improving the handling and movement of farm bales, prior to sale to warrant the installation of a system only capable of reaching maximum efficiency under total presale dumping conditions.
2. There seems to be a tendancy on the part of the brokers to describe presale dumping as ''progress'' before the benefits are known.

3. Until an evaluation of both presale and postsale dumping can be objectively approached with due regard to all aspects of distribution and use, further dislocation of sections of the wool industry including labour and management should be avoided.
4. As commercial acceptance should eventually depend on the net cost or worth to each party, the conflict cannot be overcome at this point by compensatory means.

5. The AWPC recognise that sales in Brisbane did present unique problems and that improvements were overdue. It also acknowledges that its members do not generally bid as widely or purchase at the same level in Queensland, as in other States.

Local processors are, however, concerned that presale dumping could flow onto other centres without due regard to alternative methods or indeed consideration to important issues and the disruptive influence this will have on trading.

6. Should assessments of technical and commercial acceptance, as well as viability of presale packaging include the first three sales at the Queensland Wool Centre i.e. quarter ending December '83, significant adjustments will need to be made to compensate for the unrepresentative nature of the wool offered.

Over the past few years skirtings have represented about 17 per cent or 18 per cent of the total sales in Brisbane. The average level of skirtings sold in tripacks at the Q.W.C. during the first 3 sales represented 63 per cent of the total. This is 3.6 times greater than normal.

The acceptance of skirtings sold in tripacks was significantly higher than fleece wools, but still below the level of acceptance in farm bales. The trade demonstrated that presale dumping was unacceptable as it bought less than 15 per cent of fleece wool offered, while it purchased larger quantities of skirtings in farm bales than in 3BUs and 2BUs.

7. There have been several forecasts produced suggesting a significant increase in the level of activity in the scouring and topmaking in Australia during the ' 80s and '90s. While Australia's lack of positive export incentives has retarded growth, extensions to presale dumping would result in reductions rather than increases in activity.
8. This council repeats its opposition to presale dumping on four grounds.
The imposition of total presale dumping in any one area denies the buyer's freedom of choice.
Significant charges are made without any benefits to buyer/user.
Capital expenditure will be incurred.
Dedumping and disruption to work flows will result in substantial increases in operating costs.

9. The ability of the Australian wool processing industry to compete on International markets will be impaired as freight advantages will operate in favour of superdensity dumped bales of greasy wool.

10. While the local processors are concerned about their own position, they recognise that the majority of Japanese buyers, the USSR and the Peoples Republic of China oppose presale dumping at the Queensland Wool Centre and as a concept.

Should the reduction in costs achieved by brokers be less than the costs incurred by prospective buyers, the adoption of presale, dumping will be counter productive for total industry. Commercial judgement that will be exercised by disadvantaged buyers will dictate that the discounts must be greater than costs. The resultant price depression will be supported by those not disadvantaged.

The Australian Wool Processors Council proposes that serious consideration be given to the withdrawal of the support price for presale dumped wool. It should be obligatory upon any enterprise engaged in presale dumping to underwrite price assurances equal to the current prices for farm bales. Unless offsets greater than the costs incurred by the buyer of presale dumped wool can be achieved, then presale dumping must be regarded as futile.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that the Senate have a cognate debate covering this Bill and the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering the three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) seems to have little interest in the debate on these important measures because he walked out of the chamber when they were called on for debate.
—I am right here.

—I am pleased to note that he is still here. The Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 and the Bills associated with it-the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984-are, I think, of considerable importance and should be of considerable interest to this chamber. I might say that the Bills have come to us in a rather messy fashion. This is particularly the case with the third Bill of the group, the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984, which was introduced only this morning and which seeks to amend one of the Bills that is to be the subject of this debate. The legislation contains numerous amendments to various Acts of Parliament. One would have thought that the Government would have its act together in a sufficiently clear manner to have had all of these questions dealt with in the legislation that it introduced in the first place. Nevertheless, that seems to be simply a matter of technical amendments which are consequential upon the passage of some of the amendments to the Judiciary Act. Consequently I do not propose to deal at all in this debate with those minor matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the amendments to the Judiciary Act and the consequential amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act raise matters of very great significance. They deal primarily with the right of appeal to the High Court of Australia. A second and quite unrelated purpose of the legislation before us is to set up the office of Australian Government Solicitor and I will deal with that matter quite separately. The amendments to the Judiciary Act seek to limit the appeals to the High Court to cases where the High Court grants special leave to appeal. What the amendments will do essentially is take away one of the major features of the operation of the High Court. They seek to take away one of the major rights which have been enjoyed by citizens of Australia since the institution of the High Court in 1903, namely, the right to appeal to it as of right. So that will be a very significant change-indeed, a very important change -in the future role of the High Court in the legal system of this country. Indeed, there will be a great change in the rights of the citizens of this country.

Undoubtedly the High Court of Australia is our most highly respected national institution and it deserves the very high regard it enjoys. It has earnt this regard by its record in the 80-odd years of its existence. Alfred Deakin, in introducing the Bill to establish the High Court of Australia as the first Commonwealth Attorney-General, said that in his view the High Court would be the keystone of the Federal arch. Although the High Court was opposed at the time by some people, nevertheless from its establishment it has satisfied that description by Alfred Deakin.

It is important to consider why the High Court has established that reputation. The policy followed by the first High Court of sitting in various parts of Australia, so that the Court could be available to litigants throughout the country and so that its presence should be obvious to the people, was an important factor in its growing reputation. The other important reason for the standing of the High Court has been the quality of its judges, their standing as lawyers, their experience in many walks of life and their high character and integrity.

The Court has enjoyed a reputation not only in this country; it has also established an enviable high reputation in the common law world. The Court's standing outside Australia is of great significance and is an important element in the development of the law in Australia and the quality of that development. At one stage of the Court's existence, in the era of what one may call the Dixon court-the period when Sir Owen Dixon was at the height of his judicial powers and reputation, particularly when he was Chief Justice of the Court-many people in this country, in the United Kingdom and the United States of America regarded the High Court as probably the greatest court in the common law world. When Justice Harlan of the United States Supreme Court visited Australia during that period he told me of his high regard for the High Court of Australia and particularly for some of its judges. Justice Harlan, one of the greatest lawyers to serve in the United States Supreme Court in recent times, also told me that he personally used to read the judgments of the High Court of Australia, particularly in constitutional cases, as a matter of course when preparing his own judgments as a member of the United States Supreme Court.

The High Court of Australia has enjoyed that reputation, and the legal profession has paid it the respect which has been its due. It is seen as the final bastion of the law in Australia in relation to the rights of the people. It is interesting to note the quality of the membership of the Court over the years. It is essential that in future those standards should be maintained and that appointments to the Court should be based on the legal standing and quality of those considered for appointment. That includes their experience and practice of the law, experience in other areas, particularly of government, and the character and integrity of the person considered for appointment.

A great deal of debate takes place these days as to who should appoint judges. The question is asked whether that process should be undertaken by a judicial commission or should remain with the Executive, as in the past. In my view, the Executive government is the body which should retain the responsibility for the appointment of judges in general but certainly those appointed to the High Court . It is one of the greatest responsibilities upon the Executive and should be exercised carefully and cautiously.

There is also the question of political appointments to the High Court. From time to time active, practising politicans have been appointed. Indeed, the first Court comprised Sir Edmund Barton, who stood down from being Prime Minister to become a justice of the High Court, and Mr Justice O'Connor, who stood down as Leader of the Government in the Senate, to do so. There are some precedents for active political figures being appointed to the High Court. I will not go into others. Although that practice is not necessarily to be criticised-I do not accept the view that there should be no such appointments to the Court-nevertheless, it should be only an occasional occurrence. It would be a sad day if the High Court of Australia ever became a political court dominated by political considerations. If appointments were commonly based on such considerations, the high standing of the Court would be at an end. It is a matter of concern that the few occasions on which there has been great public disquiet and criticism about High Court appointments have invariable been related to political appointments. It is an area in which government should exercise great caution. By and large, appointment to the Court should be made from outside the political arena. That is not to say that it may not be appropriate to appoint to the Court people who at some stage have had experience of government or political life, but the appointment of active, practising politicians should be rare indeed.

The Bill removes a right which Australians have enjoyed for a very long time. The Opposition's view is that this matter requires further consideration and investigation. Therefore I propose to move an amendment to the motion for second reading of the Bill in the following terms:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report and, without limiting the generality of such inquiry and report, particularly to examine:
(a) whether, in recent years, there has been an increase in the workload of the High Court sufficient to justify the abolition of the existing rights of appeal to that Court as of right;

(b) whether further restrictions upon the rights of appeal to the High Court are justified in view of the workload of the Court and, if so, what would be the fairest and most equitable system of restrictions which could be imposed;
(c) what matters should be considered by the High Court in determining whether to grant special leave to appeal;

(d) whether the conduct of the Government's litigation would be improved or rendered more efficient following the establishment of the Australian Government Solicitor to replace the office of Crown Solicitor, as proposed by the Bill.

With respect to those first three matters, the Attorney-General's speech in introducing this Bill was completely devoid of any statistics about the work load of the High Court, which is said to justify this very major change. In recent years the work load of the High Court in matters not thought to be appropriate for its attention because of its very great concentration on matters of law, particularly constitutional law, has been relieved quite considerably. I have been provided with some statistics; I do not know whether the Attorney- General intends to make them public. Suffice it to say that the statistics, such as they are, do not make out a case for this move at this time. I think it probably needs further consideration because I can appreciate that the increasing number of five and seven-judge benches and the increasing number of major matters of law, particularly constitutional law, coming before the Court would undoubtedly increase the work load of the Court. Just how urgent this matter is at this time is a matter for speculation and debate.

I believe that the appropriate course would be for this matter not to proceed at this stage. It should be investigated. I also believe that it is premature to take the step in view of the discussions that are taking place within the Australian Constitutional Convention for the establishment of an integrated court system in Australia. There is widespread support for the view that there ought to be a new national intermediate court of appeal which would be the appropriate body to hear a great number of cases dealing with complicated questions of fact which at present may go to the High Court. Undoubtedly, those cases create an undue burden for the High Court. I know it can be said that it is still very uncertain whether agreement will be reached about an integrated system of courts, or indeed about an intermediate court of appeal, but I think that very good progress is being made in those discussions. I do not think that the High Court's work load is so urgent at this stage. As I said, the Attorney- General has not even put on the public record--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney has not claimed any urgency.

—No, quite. I think it would be better if this matter were stood aside for the time being until the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs can look into it and report back to us. During that time I hope further progress will be made in the matter of an intermediate court of appeal.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I need to address is the proposed amendment to the Judiciary Act to establish what is called the Australian Government Solicitor in place of the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor. The Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, of course, is the solicitor appointed to perform that function on behalf of the Commonwealth Government and who, with his officers around the country, acts as the legal firm, so to speak, of the Government. His office is structured in the traditional way; he has the clear personal responsibility of a legal practitioner and responsibilities ultimately to the court. It is proposed to replace his office with a body corporate to be called the Australian Government Solicitor. Personal responsibility for that body corporate rests with the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department and other authorised officers of the Department. The many solicitors who will act on behalf of the Australian Government Solicitor will be subject to directions from the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. The Bill specifies the Secretary's responsibility to the court.

I think it is a major and rather curious step that an organisation which provides legal advice and does legal work should be in an incorporated form rather than in the traditional personal form in which solicitors practise. The Attorney in his speech talks about this new body being a firm, but of course, firms of solicitors are not incorporated bodies. Thus, this is a very major change in the structure of the legal profession, albeit confined to the office of the Australian Government Solicitor. Apart from those comments about matters which may be the subject of further debate or discussion at the Committee stage, I am intrigued about this whole exercise. It seems to be a totally cosmetic and bureaucratic exercise. What good it will do completely escapes me. To abolish the office of the Crown Solicitor is a very major change in the history of the Australian legal system as far as government law is concerned. The office has been with the government, I suppose, since its beginning. In the context of High Court judges, I point out that one former Commonwealth Crown Solicitor was a judge of the High Court for many years. I refer to Mr Justice Powers.

There is no apparant reason for this major change and no real argument has been presented by the Attorney-General for it. I think that proposal also should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for consideration as to the point of the change. It seems to be a cosmetic exercise and an example of legislation for the sake of legislation. For all those reasons, therefore, the Opposition believes that the amendments which are the subject of the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) are not in any way urgent. The right of appeal to the High Court, in particular, is an extremely serious matter when it is considered that we are taking away existing rights that have been enjoyed and exercised over a long period and that the role of the High Court, our most respected institution, is being changed in a major way. Those matters deserve very sober, serious and lengthy discussion. I do not think it is appropriate that it simply be dealt with in this chamber today. The proper course to take, as the matter is not urgent, is to refer it to the Senate Committee. I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report and, without limiting the generality of such inquiry and report, particularly to examine:
(a) whether, in recent years, there has been an increase in the workload of the High Court sufficient to justify the abolition of the existing rights of appeal to that Court as of right;

(b) whether further restrictions upon the rights of appeal to the High Court are justified in view of the workload of the Court and, if so, what would be the fairest and most equitable system of restrictions which could be imposed;
(c) what matters should be considered by the High Court in determining whether to grant special leave to appeal;

(d) whether the conduct of the Government's litigation would be improved or rendered more efficient following the establishment of the Australian Government Solicitor to replace the office of Crown Solicitor, as proposed by the Bill.'
