SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the referral of the very major changes proposed to the jurisdiction of the High Court of Australia in the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for consideration and report. The effect of the Bill is to abolish the right of a citizen to appeal to the High Court as of right. It is therefore a very fundamental change and obviously requires the closest scrutiny. That the proposed change has been condemned by the Law Council of Australia, comprising 12 constituent bodies and representing some 20,000 lawyers throughout Australia, is, I believe, further reason for the Senate to proceed with caution.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, I add that last Friday the shadow Attorney-General in South Australia, the Honourable K. T. Griffin, being a former Attorney-General in South Australia, also issued a statement expressing great concern at the change and the effect upon the people of South Australia. There is therefore considerable disquiet within the legal profession as to the consequences of the proposals of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). Whilst the legal profession obviously cannot dictate to government, its views should nevertheless be treated with respect. I would have thought that was a lesson that this Government would have learned from the current Medicare debacle; professional views are relevant and should be treated with respect. It is Australian lawyers, the practitioners at the coal face, who can most vividly foresee the consequences to their clients, the Australian public, of the Attorney-General's amendments. It is the public, the litigants, who will lose by this legislation what are regarded almost as basic rights in this country. It is not the legal practitioners who will lose by the Attorney-General's proposed amendments. The Bill does not affect the position of lawyers, only the position of their clients .

First, it is proposed that the High Court should be empowered to remit to the Federal Court or a State or Territory court a matter commenced in the High Court by virtue of its present exclusive jurisdiction. Thus the court may not, at its discretion, hear matters that it presently must hear. I briefly remind the Senate that they are as follows:
. . . matters arising directly under any treaty;
suits between States, or between persons suing or being sued on behalf of different States, or between a State and a person suing or being sued on behalf of another State;
suits by the Commonwealth, or any person suing on behalf of the Commonwealth, against a State, or any person being sued on behalf of a State;
suits by a State, or any person suing on behalf of a State, against the Commonwealth or any person being sued on behalf of the Commonwealth.

The High Court shall, if this amendment is passed, have power to remit such cases to another court. Thus the right of such litigants to have their cases determined by the High Court will be lost. I acknowledge that there are inappropriate cases, particularly lengthy determinations of questions of fact, that do reach the High Court and that there is need for reform in this area. But I am not convinced that the answer is simply to give the High Court the discretion to determine which matters of first instance it shall hear and determine.

Secondly, it is proposed to restrict the current rights of appeal. There is now a right of appeal to the High Court in respect of appeals involving matters concerning values of $20,000 or more or involving the interpretation of the Constitution. The effect of this amendment will be that no appeal from a State Supreme Court to the High Court will lie otherwise than by special leave of the High Court. I have considerable doubt as to whether this right should be removed , particularly in relation to constitutional matters. I must also admit a prejudice against refusals to grant leave when no reasons are given. I do not believe that that makes for a good legal system. I am concerned also that the proposal may mean a considerable increase in costs to litigants in having to travel, say, from South Australia to Canberra on applications for leave, and then in certain cases having to return to Canberra another day for the hearing of the case. This point was particularly made by the shadow Attorney-General in South Australia in his Press release last Friday.

What, therefore, are the Attorney-General's reasons for these dramatic changes? He says the justices have expressed concern about the increasing work load of the High Court and, as a result, its capacity to function effectively as a final appellate court and as the interpreter of the Constitution. Of course, interestingly enough, under these amendments it may in a sense cease to have such functions, but in any event the basic justification must be challenged. I was pleased to see that the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack, raised these matters. What is the extent of the increase in the work load of the High Court? I, as one senator, have not seen any figures and I do not think too many of my colleagues have either. What is the evidence that High Court justices work harder than, say, State Supreme Court judges? In particular, what is the evidence of the detrimental effect upon their performance? Surely, if the Attorney-General wants the Senate to endorse such dramatic changes, we should be given evidence of need. There has been no attempt to give us such evidence.

Even if we are convinced that the work load of the High Court should be reduced , we must nevertheless ask whether the Attorney-General is on the best track. The Law Council of Australia, which is not necessarily opposed to reducing the burden of work on the High Court, in a letter it wrote to me and I presume to other senators on 22 March 1984 expressed the view that the solution of the Attorney-General is drastic and undesirable.
The Law Council has provided a different formula, and stated in its letter:
The end purpose of the Council's policy is to protect the interests of citizens , ease the workload on the High Court and satisfy the Government's policy objectives.

The Law Council is of the firm view that the right of appeal as of right should not be abolished. It has put to the Attorney-General a whole series of proposals as alternatives which it believes will better achieve the objectives which it understands the Attorney is seeking to achieve. It did this in the form of a letter to the Attorney-General dated 17 August 1983, a copy of which is attached to the Law Council's letter to me and I presume to correspondence to other senators. Rather than go through its alternative proposals and take up time of the Senate in doing so, I seek leave to have incorported in Hansard a copy of that letter.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LAW COUNCIL OF AUSTRALIA
THE FEDERAL COUNCIL OF BAR ASSOCIATIONS AND LAW SOCIETIES
17th August, 1983
The Hon. Senator G. A. Evans,
Commonwealth Attorney-General,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Attorney,
APPEALS TO THE HIGH COURT

At the recent General Meeting of the Law Council, the Council approved a policy in relation to appeals to the High Court. I therefore set out below for your information the policy adopted and mention as background that it is the firm view of the Council that the right of appeal as of right to the High Court should not be abolished.
Policy of the Law Council of Australia

1. If a monetary criterion is adopted, then the present limit of $20,000 should be raised. Further, the law should be that the appellant must show that the result of the appeal may advantage him in the requisite sum; that is a stiffer test than the present one.
2. Consideration should be given to providing an appeal as of right where the appeal court below is divided in opinion, subject to a mechanism to exclude appeals raising purely factual points.

3. The Full Federal Court should be given jurisdiction to entertain any application for a prerogative writ which may at present be made to the High Court, with an appeal by special leave to the High Court.

4. Appeals to the High Court should be permissible in cases where special leave is presently necessary or will become necessary under these proposals, on the certificate of the appellate court from which the appeal is brought that, in its opinion, a point of law of general importance is involved or that the point is one which ought to be considered by the High Court.

5. A right of appeal should be granted in criminal cases with respect to any ground relating to a point on which the appellate court below was divided in opinion, but only where the applicant has been sentenced to life, or to a term of imprisonment of five years or more.
6. The present right of appeal with respect to constitutional matters given by Section 35 (6) of the Judiciary Act should be preserved.

7. There should be no appeals as of right in tax matters as at present-see Section 200A of the Income Tax Assessment Act-but otherwise all types of civil cases heard in the Full Federal Court or the State appellate courts are to be governed by the same rules as to the right of appeal to the High Court. This would involve a new grant of the right of appeal in certain cases, e.g. patent actions.
8. Appeals from the Full Family Court should be governed by the same provisions as at present-i.e. by special leave or certificate from the Full Family Court only.
9. Appeals on the quantum of damage should be governed by the same provisions as at present-i.e. special leave only.

While not directly related to the question of appeals to the High Court, at the same General Meeting it was resolved that, recognising the heavy workload now borne by the judges of the High Court and the effect upon that workload that the adoption of the Council's policy in relation to the right of appeals would involve, the number of judges in the High Court should be increased from seven to nine. Adopting this policy, the Council appreciates that in major constitutional cases it will still be necessary for all judges to sit.
Yours faithfully,
G. A. MURPHY President

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I agree with all of the Law Council's submission. Many of the points raised are arguable, although as I have indicated I am not satisfied with the merits of what the Government proposes. In considering this matter, I bear in mind that there has been no suggestion to the Senate that this is a Bill of any great urgency. Therefore, as I have indicated, when fundamental rights such as the right of appeal to the High Court as the ultimate court in major matters is to be lost, the Parliament should move cautiously. Of course we do have a mechanism for the careful review of such matters-I am pleased to see you nodding agreement, Mr Deputy President-and that mechanism is reference to one of the standing committees of this Senate. In this case, the obvious standing committee to consider these important matters is the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.
—It has some very fine members, too.
—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, it has some very fine members.
—Is he on it?

—He was in the past, and contributed greatly. When the proposed crimes authority legislation was referred to the Committee, I was confident that the Committee would proceed constructively and expeditiously and also meticulously keep to its terms of reference. The Government opposed reference of that matter to the Committee but I can report with some confidence that the Committee will be reporting to the Senate on time and that it has proceeded both constructively and expeditiously; and I believe the Senate will approve of its work. The same would apply to this reference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Tate, spoke immediately before me. Although as his deputy I do not particularly want to disagree with what he said in regard to the work load of the Committee, I remind the Senate that the crimes authority legislation report will be brought down by the end of next month. The Committee has completed its public hearings on the national service Bill. The question of privilege that Senator Tate mentioned is still around. I think it is fair to say it has not attracted quite the public interest that we thought it might and it is clearly a matter that can be considered over a more lengthy period. It does not require urgent consideration by the Committee. The same sentiment applies to our ongoing reference to oversee Australian Law Reform Commission reports. Certainly the reference of this task to the Committee will provide more work but I guess that is what we are here for. I do not see in the Committee's current work load anything that would unduly hinder the expeditious consideration of this matter. In saying that, I do bear in mind that the Attorney has not put to us that there is a tremendous urgency in the matter.

I certainly disagree with an interjection we heard a few minutes ago that, with this proposed course of action, we are seeking to delay implementation of these provisions. That is obviously not the intention of the Opposition in this matter . I am disappointed to hear that objection. We are saying that it is a matter of major concern. It has caused considerable worry to the legal practitioners of Australia. We have some 20,000 legal practitioners who, through their supreme body, have expressed concern to honourable senators. All we say is that the matter should receive proper and careful consideration. We can give it that consideration through the committee system. Therefore, I urge support for this proposal-I suppose in many ways I am speaking particularly to the Australian Democrats who decide these matters in this place-because I am sure that in the longer term it will be in the best interests of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last two weeks, I, and I understand a large number of other senators, have undertaken discussions with a number of groups which have an interest in the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984, including representatives of the Australian Bar Association and of the Law Council of Australia, both here and in South Australia. Senator Hill said a moment ago that at the end of the letter he received from the Law Council it indicated it had a number of concerns, including a desire to protect the rights of Australian citizens and a desire to ease the work load on the judges, as well as some concern for accommodating Government policies. It seems to me from the discussions I have had that almost everyone has agreed that the High Court of Australia work load is increasing, that that increase is not improving the quality of justice in Australia, that there is a very significant and real difficulty in coming up with a set of criteria for as-of-right appeals and that we are urgently in need of balancing, first, the need to cut back the number of inappropriate as-of-right appeal cases before the High Court and, secondly, offering some sort of certainty to lawyers and their clients with regard to leave-to-appeal cases. I understand that part of the problem comes from the fact that no reasons are given when leave to appeal is denied.

SPEECH.PARA: I also understand, I hope correctly, that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is undertaking some discussions with the judges about coming up with some reasonable way of getting around this problem. Quite clearly it is not the sort of thing that could be drafted into legislation without either producing the need for a full appeal hearing or coming up with a new layer of legal judgments. Everybody seems to agree that the money criterion is not an appropriate one, but suggestions that have been made to me by members of the Law Council of Australia and the Australian Bar Association about making it more appropriate by increasing it, have ranged from raising it to $50,000 or $60,000 and raising it to $200,000. So there does not seem to be great agreement there. Senator Hill was correct when he raised the question of costs to clients with an increased number of leave applications. This applies particularly to South Australia and Western Australia where it is simply not possible for counsel to make a quick one-day trip to Canberra to put the case. That is a significant question that has to be faced.

Objections have been raised, also, with regard to what some people see as the lottery element of the proposed scheme, notwithstanding the fact that they argue that there is considerable inappropriateness inherent in the current scheme. Whatever they say, the problem always comes back to the fact that there is no uniformity of opinion among the groups concerned, which includes the Government, the Opposition, the Law Council of Australia and the Australian Bar Association, about what sorts of cases should fall into which categories. Senator Durack believes that the solution for this is to refer this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. In the first part of his amendment he says that the Committee should inquire into, report on and examine whether, in recent years, there has been an increase in the workload of the High Court sufficient to justify the abolition of the existing rights of appeal to that Court as a right. One wonders, if it decides there has been no real work load increase, whether it will dissect the sorts of things that have been forming part of that work load to work out whether there would have been an increase if more of the leave to appeal cases which should have gone before the court, but could not because of the number of inappropriate right of appeal cases, had gone before it. Paragraph (b) of Senator Durack's amendment states:

Whether further restrictions upon the rights of appeal to the High Court are justified in view of the workload of the High Court and, if so, what would be the fairest and most equitable system of restrictions which could be imposed.

Yet, in discussions that I have had over the last two weeks with people who are most closely involved in this, no agreement has been able to be reached. I would have thought that what one representative of the ABA said to me should be taken into account. He said that lawyers-the people involved in this-have been turning their minds to this question for years and have not been able to come up with a reasonable set of criteria.

One wonders how much time Senator Durack and the Opposition believe that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee will have to put into this sort of inquiry if it has to come up with a set of criteria that presumably the finest legal minds in this country have not been able to come up with despite the fact that they have, according to one senior member of the ABA, been considering it for a number of years. This is particularly so given the fact that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee is currently rounding off its report into the National Crimes Authority and that senior and significant members of that Committee will have to take on the work load of an investigation into the Age tapes. Quite clearly any consideration of the work load confronting the High Court will have to take some considerably lower priority than it ought to take. I suggest that this sort of delaying tactic is at least partly due to the fact that Senator Durack is understandably interested in the formation of a national appellate court which he believes will emanate from the next constitutional convention. I suspect that he believes that with more optimism than justification given the fact that Queensland has indicated that it is not interested in this and that Queensland has a charming habit of stacking the conventions.

The Law Council of Australia telexed me yesterday with several amendments that it felt would improve the current Government proposal. The Council suggested that proposed section 35A should be amended so that in the first sentence, after the word 'but', the words 'without limiting the generality of the foregoing,' be inserted. It suggested that the final three words-'have regard to'-should be omitted and that the words 'grant such an application where' should be inserted. It suggested also that in paragraph (a) of the proposed section the first word, 'whether', should be omitted and that one or two other consequential amendments should be made. It suggested also that following the end of the proposed section the words 'and shall have regard to the punishment (if any) in criminal cases and to the significance of the outcome to the litigants in civil cases' should be added. The Government has indicated that it is not at all happy with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor am I.

—In the brief conversation that I had with Senator Durack this morning, he indicated that he was not at all interested in pursuing the path suggested by the Law Council. As I am not in the business of pursuing futile exercises in this place, I am afraid that I have to say to the Law Council of Australia that, notwithstanding the amount of work that Ian Temby and Brian Maguire put into this, there seems to be no point in pursuing it for them.

SPEECH.PARA: That leaves us in the position of coming to a decision with regard to the current problem facing us in this legislation and that is whether to take some sort of steps to improve what everybody agrees is a situation which cannot be allowed to continue or to say that the Senate is not in the position or not prepared to make a decision on this and to foist yet another piece of legislation or another controversial question upon an already overworked group of people. Given those two alternatives, we decided that the better, although obviously not the most satisfactory, of the two paths to take is to support the Government's proposed legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984, the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984 are aimed at decreasing the work load of the High Court of Australia. Of course, that is a matter of conjecture. I will read to the Senate a letter that I received from the President of the Law Society of the Northern Territory in regard to this matter. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed by the Law Council of Australia that the Commonwealth Government has recently introduced legislation to limit appeals to the High Court to only those matters in respect of which special leave has been given.

I believe that Territory lawyers would join with those in the rest of Australia in saying that this proposal is not the best way of divesting the High Court of unwanted work. In the Territory, we have no Full Court of our Supreme Court and therefore one of the appeal processes presently available to all of the other people in Australia, is not available to Territory residents.

Access to the High Court for Territorians has been regular in recent years, and of reasonable frequency having regard to the population living in the Northern Territory. I believe that such access for Territorians is of fundamental importance having regard to the emerging nature of our law and the relative uncertainty of much of the modern legislation effecting Territorians.
He continued:

I therefore urge that you consider the Bill which I understand to have been presented before the Senate. If you do not reach the conclusion that the Bill is not in the interests of Territorians, then I invite you to meet with myself and other members of the Council of the N.T. Law Society to discuss the matter and make suggestions which might provide for alternative ways of lessening the work load presently being experienced by the High Court.
If any matters occur to you on which you require specific advice from the N.T. Society, please do not hesitate to contact me.

That letter was signed by H. B. Bradley, the President of the Law Society of the Northern Territory. Briefly, it appears that the representations by that Law Society are reasonable. I suggest that the Government gives very full consideration to the points that the Society has put forward. It appears that if the legislation is passed it will not be in the best interests of the Northern Territory, which I and another senator represent in this place. Those people have given very good reason why a right of appeal to the High Court is necessary if justice is to be seen to be done. I note that the Opposition shadow Attorney- General, Senator Durack, has brought forward an amendment which in part states:
the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report and, without limiting the generality of such inquiry and report, particularly to examine:
(a) whether, in recent years, there has been an increase in the workload of the High Court sufficient to justify the abolition of the existing rights of appeal to that Court as of right;

(b) whether further restrictions upon the rights of appeal to the High Court are justified in view of the workload of the Court and, if so, what would be the fairest and most equitable system of restrictions which could be imposed;

The amendment continues. One would surely say that this amendment is most reasonable as it affects the rights of individuals in Australia, particularly those of the people in the Northern Territory, which faces special problems. As Senator Durack has said, there is a necessity to review this legislation. Would it not be better to refer it to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs so it may inquire into the matter and bring back to the Senate a report on the situation as it finds it? Surely it is much better to legislate after the matter has been properly reviewed rather than, as appears to be the case now, legislating in haste and then finding that some people in Australia will suffer because of it. I support the amendment. I hope that honourable senators will support it also. If the amendment is not passed by the Senate I suggest that, as the Government is obviously legislating in haste, the legislation should be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to make three major changes to the Judiciary Act 1903. First, it provides for the establishment of an Australian Government Solicitor to replace the personal office of the Crown Solicitor. This is largely an administrative change. It will not alter the powers held by the office or its functions. It is designed to make the office more efficient and more functional. I am not in a position to make judgment on whether it will. However, it is not without significance to me at least to note that the amendment to section 55E of the Act deletes any reference to the Crown, which is in line, of course, with Labor's practice to delete the Crown from legislation. Although it might be thought by some to be a trivial matter of no moment, it is but another step by the Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his pursuit of a republic of Australia. I might describe it as another insidious and pernicious move towards that goal. It is a course of action which Senator Evans has made quite public before and for which he makes no apology. In the same way as he would abolish the States and gut the Senate of its consequential powers, he would cut out Australia's historical and intrinsic links with the Crown.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Bill will give the High Court of Australia the power to remit cases, which were previously under the exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court, to State and Federal courts, where the State and Federal courts have concurrent jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties involved in the case. No doubt this matter will be raised at the Committee stage. On reading the amendment to section 38, my superficial observation is that the amendment becomes nonsensical in terms of its wording. I imagine that is only a drafting which will be corrected in due course. The cases concerned are those involving matters arising directly under any treaty, suits between States and suits between the States and the Commonwealth or people being sued on behalf of a State or the Commonwealth. Under the provisions of this Bill the High Court will be empowered to remit the whole or part of the case to a Federal, State or Territory court; for example, where lengthy hearings are required to establish matters of fact. The High Court will retain the power to issue directions concerning the case to the lower court, thus retaining some control over the proceedings. Of course, they will have absolutely no influence upon the final judgment.

It may be properly argued that this clause does represent a strengthening of the powers of the State and Territory courts and, as such, may be welcomed by some. However, in many instances the case will have been dealt with by the full Supreme Court on appeal and if the matter has been dealt with previously by the Federal court on appeal that is the end of the matter.

It is the first part of this Bill, dealing with the right of appeal to the High Court from courts of the States, to which I am strongly opposed. I believe that this clause seeks to remove one of the basic rights of Australian citizens, namely, that in certain circumstances a case has an automatic right to be heard by the High Court. The Bill would amend the Judiciary Act of 1903 so that an appeal against a judgment passed by a lower court in Australia would only be heard by the High Court where special leave is given to appeal by the High Court .

Currently, there are two grounds upon which a person may claim his or her right to a hearing by the High Court. The first is upon monetary grounds, where the subject matter of a case involves an amount of $20,000 or more. I agree that it is an arbitrary figure which was set some time ago-as I recall, 1976-and perhaps a monetary figure is not necessarily appropriate. There may be questions of law which are more important than the amount of money involved. However, it does seek to strike a guideline and a bottom line as to what is a case which may be referred by appeal automatically to the High Court.

At the moment, any case which involves the interpretation of the Australian Constitution may, as of right, be brought before the High Court. If the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is now before us, is made law, there would be no grounds upon which a case could, as of right, be heard by the High Court. At one stroke, one of the most basic rights in Australian law would be removed. An automatic right of appeal to the High Court in certain circumstances has been embodied in Australian law since 1903. Now it is proposed that it should be abolished.

What is the reason for the removal of this basic tenet of Australian law? We are told it is simply to ease the work load of the High Court judges. I do not deny for a moment that the work load of the High Court judges is excessive and, indeed, that measures must be taken to alleviate this problem. But I would point out that there is an enormous work load in the Federal Court and the State Supreme courts. By the provisions of this Bill cases will be referred back to those courts by the High Court and that will add to their work load. So while we may be relieving in some part the work load of the High Court all we are really doing is redistributing the work load back to the States and the Federal Court.

I must say that I have no memory of the Labor Government showing any concern for the work load of the High Court at the time it sought to impose upon that Court, the Australian Federal Parliament and the Australian people, the advisory opinions which would have placed, in my view, an intolerable burden on the work load of the High Court. On that occasion the Labor Government sought to take the power of the Parliament and of the Australian citizens and place it, in some obscure way, in the hands of the High Court. Now they propose to take from the Australian people access to the High Court. This Bill proposes that only where special leave is granted will there be a right of appeal to the High Court. Frankly, if I am able to find any virtue in this legislature it is that, superficially, challenges to the traditionally held interpretations of the High Court could be lessened and the new and enlightened approach to the Constitution that has been embraced so fully by the High Court in recent times could be slowed. However, of course, that will not be the case, because the right of access to the High Court will now rest exclusively, in the case of such appeals, with the High Court.

By and large, putting aside recent constitutional determinations, the work of the High Court has been performed admirably well. If there is one area of its operation that has attracted any criticism, it is its performance in selecting cases as appropriate for granting special leave to be heard. Applications for special leave are heard by a varying number of judges-I believe from one judge to three judges-depending upon who is available. It is inevitable that there will be variations of opinion upon which cases should or should not be granted special leave to be heard by the High Court. Therefore, the situation undoubtedly will arise where one week a case might be granted special leave and a few weeks later a similar case heard by a different judge could be denied special leave.

In addition, the reasons for granting or denying special leave are not given by the High Court judges. It becomes impossible, therefore, to know even whether it would be worth applying for special leave for an appeal to be heard by the High Court. If it is the case that an appeal against a judgment can be referred to the High Court only through the process of applying for special leave, the system inevitably will become fraught with resentment and, in my view, frustration, and ultimately faith in the judicial system itself will be undermined to some degree. Furthermore, such a move might open the way for an American type system of applications for cases to be heard by the High Court. I am sure I am right in saying that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has shown some real attraction towards the American judicial system. The United States Supreme Court deals mainly with written applications for an appeal to be heard by the Supreme Court judges. The judges confer behind closed doors and make their decisions, largely-this is a matter of record with which I am sure very few will disagree-on a political basis. In other words, whether or not a case is heard by the United States Supreme Court is decided by the political views of the judges. That is easily done, of course, because all the judges have to do is to keep declining to accept the appeal, wait for the right case to come up, and then make a judgment that is compatible with their philosophic approach to the interpretation of the Constitution or the law upon which they are being asked to make judgment.

Already there is some concern about the politicisation of the High Court. If this section of the Bill, which would allow cases to be heard by the High Court only where special leave is granted, becomes law, it can represent only a move towards even greater politicisation of the Australian judiciary. If cases can be heard by the High Court only through the granting of special leave, inevitably this will give rise to an increase in the number of special leave applications. In turn that will increase the time taken up in the hearing of special leave applications, and thereby result in pressure for applications to be in a written form rather than oral submissions, as is the case at present. We would then have a situation in Australia akin to that which exists in the United States of America of judges making political decisions behind closed doors, a practice that in my view is completely alien to the Australian law practice and completely alien to Australian notions of justice.

One further point I make on this matter relates to the question of expense, which has been referred to by previous speakers. It is extremely costly to lodge an application for special leave. The High Court holds its hearings on special leave applications in Canberra. Thus, barristers are compelled to fly to Canberra, and from some of our capitals that is a long and expensive haul, only to find themselves spending most of the day waiting in the High Court for a case that may take only 10 minutes to hear. As I have pointed out already, there is little basis upon which to make a judgment on the likely outcome of an application, so this expensive trip has to be carried out purely on a speculative basis. There has been mention of the possibility of establishing guidelines upon which the High Court should base its considerations of applications for special leave. This would be a step in the right direction, but it would still leave us with the point that this Bill is seeking to take away a basic right to have a case heard by the High Court in certain circumstances.

In its submission to the Attorney-General of August last year the Australian Law Council set out comprehensive proposals that it believed would alleviate some of the work load problems currently experienced by the High Court judges and would also strengthen the right of people to have their cases heard by the High Court. Although, as Senator Haines pointed out, there is not complete unanimity among all legal bodies, one thing about which they are all unanimous is that there ought to be automatic appeals. That is the fundamental point upon which this legislation rests: not the process of accommodating the legislation but the fact that the legislation seeks to deny the automatic right. Every law body in Australia has expressed its grave opposition to that proposition.

By way of seeking to put some proposals before the Attorney-General to accommodate the legislation, which he is determined to put through, they first made the simple suggestion that the number of High Court judges could be increased from seven to nine. I am not suggesting for one moment, particularly while the Labor Government is in office, that that has a great deal of appeal to me, because it has some other distractions as well. The High Court, as I understand it, has some provision already to accommodate two additional judges. The law bodies have also suggested that cases relating to taxation matters should be dealt with only by State and Federal courts, except where an extremely fine point of law is involved. They have suggested that if the monetary criteria for granting automatic right of appeal to the High Court were to be retained, the present limit of $20,000 should be retained, and in addition the appellant should be required to show that the result of the appeal may advantage him in the requisite sum.

To strengthen the right of appeal to the High Court, the Law Council proposed that an additional right of appeal be granted where the lower court that had passed judgment on the case was divided on a fine point of law, and in fact I think it was a general point of law to which the Council was referring. The Attorney-General rejected these proposals out of hand, and has not even been prepared to explain why he dismissed them. His only reference to them in his second reading speech was when he said that the Law Council representatives had not been able to suggest a more satisfactory test to isolate those cases in respect of which there might be an appeal as of right to the High Court. He appears unable to devise a satisfactory solution to the problem himself, so his answer simply is to remove the right altogether, despite the dangerous implications such a course of action clearly has. He has ignored the Australian Law Council's point that the removal of the right of appeal will greatly diminish the benefical influence of the High Court on the work of all courts below it in the hierarchy.

I am sympathetic with the Attorney-General's difficulty in finding the criteria and the formula. That is certainly no excuse for saying simply: 'We will solve that problem by removing an automatic right'. At the eleventh hour we have now had an amendment which I understand is a compromise between the Attorney-General and the Australian Law Council. I would not want for a moment to misrepresent the real position of the Australian Law Council. I should make it clear that as I understand it, the amendment to section 35 of the Judiciary Act 1903, which is in the form of 35A, is not an amendment with which the Law Council of Australia agrees. Rather, in the Council's view it is more satisfactory than having no criteria at all. Having read it quickly this morning, I might say that it appears very hollow to me and gives almost no direction to the High Court. It refers to public importance. The meaning of public importance is a question that has never been resolved fully, and it gives the High Court enormous scope. It goes on to refer to whether the interests of the administration of justice, either generally or in the particular case, require consideration by the High Court of the judgment to which the application relates. It seems to me that it really in no way advances a sensible or realistic criterion. These criteria are so vague and inadequate as to be meaningless.

Much constructive work has been done, as I understand it, by the judicature sub -committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention of which the Attorney- General is a member, as are all the State Attorneys-General. As I understand it, they have worked in conjunction with a number of judges of the Supreme Courts of the various States of Australia. Their work has been directed towards providing a rational and sensibly integrated court system in Australia which will overcome many of the problems which face the High Court, particularly in respect of appeals. To take away that automatic right of appeal to the High Court until a suitable new structure is in place is to put the cart before the horse. In fact I am rather cynical about the reason for the rush of this legislation. Enormous work has been done. I am sure Senator Durack will agree with that. It has been going in the right direction. Of course it will take time; all these things take time. But inasmuch as the sub-committee has been set up, the work is being done and it is going in the right direction, while it may take a little time, it seems inappropriate, inexcusable and inexplicable that we have before us now legislation which seems to usurp the role and the function of that sub-committee .

Frankly, this legislation denies Australians proper access to justice. At the time of the Australian Federation the court of general appeal for the whole nation was instituted because it was believed that such a court would provide and prove to be an important unifying influence. This has indeed proved to be the case. One of the major influences of the High Court has been its work in bringing about a more uniform system in Australian law and a beneficial supervision of the State appellate courts. In the long run this Bill would greatly reduce these advantageous effects of the High Court by increasing its politicisation. The high regard in which it is currently held could only be diminished if its decisions on whether to hear a case were made behind closed doors, not on legal but on political grounds. Of course, this would have the effect of substantially shifting the role of the High Court from that of an influential unifying body, highly respected for its legal work, to that of an isolated political institution whose legal decisions would be regarded with increasing suspicion.

In closing, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard an extract from the book The Brethren, which relates to the situation inside the Supreme Court of the United States of America and which was written by Bob Woodward and Scott Armstrong. While the book itself in content may be argued not to be right in many cases, the preamble sets out, in my view, a very clear picture of the functioning of the Supreme Court of the United States, particularly in respect of appeal provisions. It gives a clear demonstration of what happens with the sorts of provisions proposed in his legislation where decisions are made behind closed doors with no requirement for the Supreme Court to give reasons for its judgments. I seek leave to have that introduction incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
INTRODUCTION

The United States Supreme Court, the highest court in the land, is the final forum for appeal in the American judiciary. The Court has interpreted the Constitution and has decided the country's preeminent legal disputes for nearly two centuries. Virtually every issue of significance in American society eventually arrives at the Supreme Court. Its decisions ultimately affect the rights and freedom of every citizen-poor, rich, blacks, Indians, pregnant women, those accused of crime, those on death row, newspaper publishers, pornographers, environmentalists, businessmen, baseball players, prisoners and Presidents.

For those nearly two hundred years, the Court has made its decisions in absolute secrecy, handing down its judgments in formal written opinions. Only these opinions, final and unreviewable, are published. No American institution has so completely controlled the way it is viewed by the public. The Court's deliberative process-its internal debates, the tentative positions taken by the Justices, the preliminary votes, the various drafts of written opinions, the negotiations, confrontations and compromises-is hidden from public view.

The Court has developed certain traditions and rules, largely unwritten, that are designed to preserve the secrecy of its deliberations. The few previous attempts to describe the Court's internal workings-biographies of particular Justices or histories of individual cases-have been published years, often decades, after the events, or have reflected the viewpoints of only a few Justices.

Much of recent history, notably the period that included the Vietnam war and the multiple scandals known as Watergate, suggests that the detailed steps of decision making, the often hidden motives of the decision makers, can be as important as the eventual decisions themselves. Yet the court, unlike the Congress and the Presidency, has by and large escaped public scrutiny. And because its members are not subject to periodic reelection but are appointed for life, the Court is less disposed to allow its decision making to become public. Little is usually known about the Justices when they are appointed, and after taking office they limit their public exposure to the Court's published opinions and occasional, largely ceremonial, appearances.

The Brethren is an account of the inner workings of the Supreme Court from 1969 to 1976-the first seven years of Warren E. Burger's tenure as Chief Justice of the United States. To ensure that our inquiry would in no way interfere with the ongoing work of the Court, we limited our investigation to those years. We interviewed no one about any cases that reached the Court after 1976.

We chose to examine the contemporary Court in order to obtain fresh recollections, to deal with topical issues and to involve sitting Justices. This book is not intended as a comprehensive review of all the important decisions made during the period. The cases we examine generally reflect the interest, time and importance assigned to them by the Justices themselves. As a result, some cases of prominence or importance-but which provide no insight into the internal dynamics of the Court-have been dealt with only briefly or not at all. The Court conducts its business during an annual session called a term, which begins each October and continues until the last opinion is announced in June or early July. The Court recess runs from then until the next October.
Normally, there are seven decision-making steps in each case the Court takes.

1. The decision to take the case requires that the Court note its jurisdiction or formally grant cert. Under the Court's procedures, the Justices have discretion in selecting which cases they will consider. Each year, they decide to hear fewer than two hundred of the five thousand cases that are filed. At least four of the nine Justices must vote to hear a case. These votes are cast in a secret conference attended only by the Justices, and the actual vote is ordinarily not disclosed.

2. Once the Court agrees to hear a case, it is scheduled for written and oral argument by the lawyers for the opposing sides. The written arguments, called legal briefs, are filed with the Court and are available to the public. The oral arguments are presented to the Justices publicly in the courtroom; a half-hour is usually allotted to each side.

3. A few days after oral arguments, the Justices discuss the case at a closed meeting called the case conference. There is a preliminary discussion and an initial vote is taken. Like all appellate courts, the Supreme Court is bound by the facts already developed from testimony and information presented to the lower trial court. The Supreme Court can reinterpret the laws, the U.S. Constitution, and prior cases. On this basis, the decisions of lower courts are affirmed or reversed. As in the cert conference, at which Justices decide which cases to hear, only the Justices attend the case conferences. (The nine members of the Court often refer to themselves collectively as the conference.)

4. The next crucial step is the selection of one of the nine Justices to write a majority opinion. By tradition, the Chief Justice, if he is in the initial majority, can assign himself or another member of the majority to write the opinion. When he is not in the majority, the senior Justice in the majority makes the assignment.

5. While one Justice is writing the majority opinion, others may also be drafting a dissent or a separate concurrence. It can be months before these opinions-a majority, dissent or concurrence-are sent out or circulated to the other Justices. In some cases, the majority opinion goes through dozens of drafts, as both the opinion and the reasoning may be changed to accommodate other members of a potential majority or to win over wavering Justices. As the Justices read the drafts, they may shift their votes from one opinion to another . On some occasions, what had initially appeared to be a majority vanishes and a dissenting opinion picks up enough votes to become the tentative majority opinion of the Court.

6. In the next to last stage, the Justices join a majority or a dissenting opinion. Justices often view the timing, the sequence and the explanations offered for ''joins'' as crucial to their efforts to put together and hold a majority.

7. In announcing and publishing the final opinion, the Justices choose how much of their reasoning to make public. Only the final versions of these opinions are available in law libraries. The published majority opinion provides the legal precedents which guide future decisions by lower courts and the Supreme Court itself.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was just a lad in primary school in 1946 an elderly lady of very deep religious conviction gave me a card with the portrait of a man described as one of the very great ambassadors of Christ. That man was Pastor Frederick Niemoller. He died on Thursday, 8 March 1984. Martin Niemoller was born in Germany in 1892 and as a youth grew up in a Germany that was overtly dominated by military ideas and imperialist aggrandisement. In fact he was caught up in the spirit of militarism, though later in life he was to be moved by an opposing ideal. During the First World War Niemoller was a U-boat commander in the German navy but on his discharge he studied theology at Munster and took his vows in the Protestant Church. He joined many right wing groups, most of which, it could be safe to assume, after 1930-31 would have identified themselves fairly closely with Hitler's nazis. Yet it soon became very apparent that Niemoller would not go the way of so many of his countrymen of that era.

SPEECH.PARA: Niemoller had become a pastor in Berlin in 1931 and two years later, in 1933, he founded the Pastors Emergency League. During this period he confronted and attacked very fervently the racist policies of the nazis. The following year, in 1934, he became one of the leaders of the Confessing Church, one of the few organisations to protest against the regime of Hitler and the nazis. Before his arrest by the Gestapo on 1 July 1937 Niemoller had the opportunity to engage in a face-to-face confrontation with Hitler when he was amongst a group of clergymen being admonished by Hitler for their so-called meddling in the affairs of the German nation. Niemoller, while maintaining a firm grasp of the Fuhrer's hand, proceeded to make it clear that the affairs of the German nation were the affairs of God and that he had no intention of leaving God's affairs to any man. The impact of this meeting was not lightly forgotten by Hitler because he ordered Niemoller's arrest and imprisonment in 1937. It was not until 1945 that he was freed by the Allies.

Throughout those eight long dark years of his imprisonment the pastor never forgot his God. He never doubted for a moment that God was on his side. He never entertained the thought of silencing his urge to speak out against the horrors and the inhumanity he witnessed almost daily. After his release, during the post -war reconstruction period of Europe, he argued very strongly against the remilitarisation of Germany and eventually became somewhat disillusioned by the apparent lack of remorse or penance on the part of the churches and the German people as a whole. But he did not desert his church, as he could have done had he been a man of lesser faith. Instead, he again took an active and leading role in its affairs, becoming for 11 years after the war the head of the German Evangelical Church's foreign relations office. During this period, in 1954, he made the conscious decision to become a pacifist.

Sitting in the comfort of this chamber some 30 years on, it is difficult to appreciate the position the pastor found himself in because 1954 was the year of the height of the cold war. He had visited Moscow two years previously. His decision cannot have been an easy one in the sense that he knew he would be attacked by some quarters as a fellow traveller of the communists. In fact, criticism of him increased with his calls for international reconciliation and improved social justice. From 1961 to 1968 he was one of the six Presidents of the World Council of Churches, an organisation often labelled as being soft on communism. In fact Niemoller drew criticism for his role in this organisation also. This was especially so after he was awarded the Lenin Peace Prize in 1968. Yet nothing could have been further from the truth. All his life he remained implacably opposed to the atheism of communism. He was not weakened in the moral fight against tyranny and oppression.

Latterly he was committed actively to seeking universal disarmament, a view not widely held by the powers that be in the West or, indeed, even in the Eastern bloc countries. Pastor Niemoller stood out for five decades as a burning light of hope for this turbulent world, a man very much committed to his belief that everybody should render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's. I think this world is blessed by people who have such strength of character and vision. I believe we will mourn his passing.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a very important subject in the minds of many South Australians; that is, the question of the wine excise that was applied to fortified wines as a result of last year's Budget. You may know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in the last day or two there have been Press reports attributed to the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, in regard to his visit to that very important area of South Australia, the Riverland. It is recorded that the Minister has admitted that the imposition of this wine excise last August was a grave mistake on the part of the Hawke Government. That is a great revelation to all of us, especially South Australian senators on the Labor side of the Senate. I know that Senator Elstob and Senator Foreman, who are present in the chamber at the moment, support the remarks of the Minister for Primary Industry. I hope that their efforts in bringing to the attention of the Minister the concerns and worries of people in South Australia over this most important issue have brought a great flash of light to the Minister's eyes and that he has recognised the problems. However, I am afraid that the Minister's recognition is really only the first step in the battle to convert the whole Hawke Cabinet to that viewpoint. As we all know, the destruction of the wine industry in South Australia is nigh in the light of the imposition of that savage wine tax last August in the Hawke Government's first Budget. Consequently, it is most important not only that the Minister himself recognise it as a grave mistake but also that the Hawke Cabinet recognises the same thing and reverses its decision immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: As you will probably appreciate, Mr Acting Deputy President, the wine industry in South Australia is currently in a state of vintage. It has harvested the grapes. It is in the process of making wine and spirit. It is at a vital stage of planning for the current year's production. Consequently, it is most important that the industry itself knows exactly the plans that the Government has afoot in order either to raze the excise-that is, take it off altogether-or to seek some other alternative. We on this side have been pleading for the last six months for the razing of the excise. Alternatively, we want the establishment of some basis of payment which is not as onerous upon the industry , as has been demonstrated by various industry submissions over the last several months. Failing that, we would like to have as soon as possible, on behalf of the industry in South Australia, a clear statement from the Hawke Government of its immediate intentions with regard to this tax. The result of a clear statement in favour of a decision to get rid of the excise would probably be the saving of many thousands of jobs in South Australia. If we wait several months from now we will see the opposite occurring and several hundred jobs will be lost.

I think those points need to be brought to the attention of the Government at this very vital time in order to ensure that the wellbeing of the people of South Australia is enhanced as much as possible. I repeat that what I have said is against the background of the Minister's admission of there being a fundamental mistake by the Government in introducing this tax in last year's Budget. I think that all of us on this side of the Senate have recognised the stupidity of that action. It is pretty clear that the Minister has now acknowledged it as well in the light of representations from this side of the Senate. However, I think the Hawke Government now has to make a clear statement and, hopefully, a decision in favour of the abolition of the duty which it imposed last August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This time last week I was in China. On the day that I visited Nan-ning, the capital of Guang-Xi province, I had the opportunity of going to the Dong Min forestry project at which six Queenslanders are engaged in promoting the growth of different trees. I want to pay a tribute to the Queenslanders who are working on the Dong Min forestry project helping the Chinese to decide which types of eucalyptus trees should be growing there. Twelve hundred acres are going to be planted and I feel sure that Ted Mannion and his offsiders are doing a job that will be of great help and benefit to that part of China. Actually, the people of Guang-Xi province are so impressed with the Queenslanders and what they are doing to help them that the Governor and Deputy Governor expressed to us the desire that Queensland become the sister state of Guang-Xi province.

SPEECH.PARA: I was certainly very glad to have the opportunity to accompany the Premier of Queensland on his visit to China, but nothing I saw in China convinced me that communism is a better way of life than the democratic philosophy of private enterprise and initiative. Indeed, in terms of both the economic situation and the spirit of the people nothing made me feel that I wanted to pack my bags and go to live in China. However, we had a very interesting week. I found the people of China to be very friendly and hospitable. For those who have not been there it would be hard to accept that there are 1,000 million people in China and six million bicycles in Beijing. China is certainly a land of contrasts. Centuries ago, of course, the Chinese had a very advanced culture. Over 2,500 years ago they built the Great Wall of China. The wall is 6,000 kilometres long and I am told that it took one million people to build it. On my return I was asked whether the Great Wall of China was any different from my expectations. I replied that it was certainly a lot wider than I thought and it gave plenty of room for what seemed like the hundreds of thousands of other people who were there on that day to walk along it.

The Ming tombs have existed for hundreds of years. When one realises that centuries ago the Chinese introduced their own alphabet and even produced gunpowder, it seems to me that their technology must have stood still for many centuries because the Western world now appears to have overtaken the Chinese. It must be remembered that they went through the period of the cultural revolution when academics were not appreciated. During that time Chairman Mao decided that the academics needed re-education and they were sent to rural areas to obtain it. It is interesting to note that academics needed re-education in rural areas in China. Sometimes I think Australian academics could do with a little period of re-education in rural areas in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was out your way while you were away.

—I am pleased to hear that comment from Senator Colston. I feel that Western civilisation certainly has caught up to the Chinese, and indeed it has passed them. China now has plenty of people but not enough technology. China is seeking technology from and joint ventures with other countries so that it may gain not only finance but also the expertise which it badly needs. In the province of Guang-Xi I was told by the Governor that up to $ 4m of joint ventures can be approved by that province without reference to Peking.

SPEECH.PARA: We also looked at the Bao-Shan steel works outside Shanghai, a tremendous project which is being built with Japanese involvement. That project when completed will be very large. The Queensland Government was hoping to sell coal to that venture, but when one hears that firms such as Occidental are putting in half a billion dollars to develop coal deposits in China, one wonders whether eventually the Chinese coal may not be able to be sent to Japan at a lower price than the coal produced in Australia-even the coal that is produced in Queensland . In view of the lower wages paid in China, I feel that China will eventually become a competitive nation in the export of coal. Japan is always looking for cheaper coal, as was evidenced recently in the price negotiations between this country and Japan over the price of coal. It was argued that the Australian Federal Government was not allowing Queensland with its cheaper coal prices to get the exports into Japan that were really wanted.

I examined with interest the wage structure in China. Many people work for the princely sum of $40 a month. As for holidays, Chinese workers get seven days a year, plus 52 Sundays-and that is all they get. They work a six-day week and certainly do not enjoy any holiday loading.

TALK.START.PARA: —No free trips to Kingaroy from China, Senator.

—That might be right, too, but a number of Chinese people are coming out to visit Australia. I do not know whether members of the Christian delegation which came out here recently were enjoying a free trip from China. However, that delegation got here and we were glad to meet them at lunch the other day and talk with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the Chinese people need unions or whether Australia can learn from the Chinese how to work harder. There is one lesson I feel the Chinese can learn from the West. I refer to the need for incentive-a factor that is gradually being appreciated in the rural industries of China. For example, in the rural area of Nan-ning we visited we were told that once people on the farms make the quota given to them by the Government they are allowed to keep what is over for themselves or to sell what they make over and above their quota. It was obvious that some of the people on the land do not like the idea of their having to keep down the birth rate to one child per family. They feel that the more children they have, the more help they will get on the farm. They will thus reach their quotas more quickly and be able to make more for themselves. Obviously they feel that there should be reward for initiative. Perhaps a farm worker may want to buy a motorcycle instead of having to pedal a push-bike; another worker may wish to buy a small tractor.

I heard of one instance in which three young Chinese wanted to farm an area on their own. The area had been previously farmed by the commune. The men were give permission to farm a citrus orchard. When the orchard was run by the commune, it produced 3,000 tonnes of citrus fruit a year. However, when the three young men adopted a type of private enterprise system to work that farm, they brought the citrus production up to 27,000 tonnes. That happened because those young men thought they would make more money for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the trees were older.

—That might have been a help, too. Whatever happened, the situation improved-so much so that the commune then wanted to take the trees back. The matter went to a court which ruled that the young men were entitled to keep on growing the trees for themselves and could keep the money they made over and above the quota.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested on my visit to meet many people who were employed in work on arts and crafts. The Chinese are very clever people. I went to an arts and crafts factory in Beijing where people were carving ivory. While I was there they were carving a fine looking horse and saddle. I wished I could have got hold of one to bring back to John. I thought it was a fine example of their work .

I also saw the Shanghai industrial exhibition where refrigerators, washing machines and many other items were on display. The interpreter on that trip told me she had managed to save a year's salary to buy a refrigerator. Her unit was so small that she had to have the refrigerator in the bedroom; it was only a one -room unit. Nevertheless, she was very grateful to have that refrigerator. She also told me that she was now saving up to buy a washing machine which would also probably take a year's salary. I saw a number of instances where I am sure many Chinese women would have been glad to have had a washing machine. As a woman I know the advantage of owning and working a washing machine. It is different from the earlier days when one washed clothes by hand and put them in the boiler.

I also saw evidence in China of equality of women with men. I saw women working on the roads, digging with picks, getting gravel off the trucks and really working hard. I saw a woman bent nearly half-way down to the ground pulling a big load behind her. If that is equality, it is not the sort of equality I want. I must admit that I did see a woman vice-chairman in the Guang-Xi province, who was very nice and looked after me very well.

I also had the opportunity of going through a kindergarten in Nan-ning where I saw 580 children that day. Some 160 of them were day students; the remainder, some 420, stayed from Monday to Saturday. There were children aged from three to six living in a boarding atmosphere because their mothers and fathers went to work. I thought that was rather sad because probably the loveliest time in children's lives is when they are little. However, that is the way they work it over there. I must say that it was a very well run kindergarten, and the children gave a little concert which included a lovely display of magic from a little boy of five years. It was altogether a very interesting time. I was also very pleased to find that in China there is a resurgence of religion and that people are free to attend churches.

I had the opportunity to go with the Premier to see the Chinese Premier. The Chinese Premier received Joh very cordially and spent about 25 minutes talking with him. The Premier said that China's economy had developed well in recent years but that, compared with Australia, China still remained a developing country. He also said that China was willing to expand trade relations and economic technology co-operation with Australia and other developed countries on the basis of equality and mutual benefit. I came away from China feeling that it is a country commencing to reach out through private enterprise to the rest of the world. As it reaches out and its standard of living develops, so potential markets for Queensland and, indeed, Australian goods will develop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I was not going to rise in the first reading debate on the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, but I believe I have a duty as a South Australian senator to answer Senator Messner with respect to the wine industry. It is true that both the previous Government and the present Government have taxed the wrong areas of the wine industry. As 80 per cent of Australian wine is produced in South Australia, such taxes hit that region very hard. The Liberal Government imposed an excise duty on wine. The Whitlam Government eliminated that tax.
—What did we get in its place?

—The point is that, if we consider its history, that tax hit the industry. I agree to some extent that governments have not had a firm understanding of the industry. There is a better understanding now, which is of benefit. I believe that both the previous Government and the present Government did the wrong thing with the wine industry. It is not right to say that the wine industry should not pay some form of tax. The Hawke Labor Government is in power now and will be for a long time to come, but no matter what government is in power it cannot resist pressure from brewers and other people in the community to impose a tax of some sort on the wine industry. In the past the wine producers have resisted any form of tax whatsoever, and it is true that taxes have hurt that industry tremendously. It was the Liberal Government that increased the tax on brandy. All these problems could have been overcome with sensible discussions between governments, producers, growers and everyone else in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that any tax imposed on this industry has a depressing effect. It is a very volatile industry and it takes five years to adjust to any upsets. It takes five years to adjust to the planting of new varieties of grapes or to overproduction in an area. It takes five years for new varieties of grapes to come into production. I understand that the wine producers have now come their senses and are talking about a 2 per cent sales tax, which would be far better than an excise. Had the industry, perhaps up to five years ago, talked to governments about a 2 per cent sales tax and doing away with the excise, I believe these problems could have been avoided.

I advocate this 2 per cent sales tax being put not only on wine but also on brandy production. Most South Australian senators have an understanding of the wine industry and we all know that it takes four to five times the amount of grapes to produce brandy as to produce wine. When the brandy tax was imposed, whole varieties had to be pulled out and that caused a great upset in the industry. Governments should be considering this because there would be more money for them if there were a 2 per cent levy on wine and brandy. It would be much easier to collect and there would be no pressure from the brewers. It is inevitable that the wine industry will pay either a sales tax or an excise duty, and anyone who says anything different is not facing reality. I think that is the sensible solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to get the Government to take the wine tax off?
—It was the representation of the South Australian senators to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that got the excise on alcohol reduced.
—Oh, rubbish. It had no effect at all.

—It did. There is no doubt about that. I maintain, nevertheless, that that is the wrong way to go about it. I do not think that this Government will get $3m out of that levy on alcohol, and it is hurting the industry. I was up there only last week, and I do understand the problems.
—Well, get them to take it off.

—The main problem is that it has taken years for the wine producers to realise that there has to be some sort of tax. They had always said there should be no tax at all, and they fought the introduction of any tax. I believe that they were remiss in doing that. It would have been far better to have advocated a 2 per cent sales tax instead of the excise duty. It was inevitable that there would be a tax of some sort, but they would not talk about the possibility. I understand that they are now coming around to realising that it is inevitable. All governments have to collect revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that this should be looked at as a special case. If common sense prevails governments will be able to get more revenue and the industry will be better off. I suggest to the Government that if an agreement can be reached on a sales tax of, say, 2 per cent this should last for a period of five years so that the industry can have stability. Long before any increases to that rate are made there should be talks within the industry. If there is to be a lift in that rate after five years, the industry should be aware of that so that it can adjust its plantings and whatever. It is vital for the whole area to produce brandy. As we all know, in Australia under law brandy must be produced from grapes; no grain can be used in the production of brandy. Yet we allow the importation of cheap brandy that most certainly is produced from grain, with a small percentage of grapes. Our brandy industry cannot survive while we allow into this country cheap brandy that is manufactured from grain.

I still maintain that if the excise were taken off brandy and a sales tax were imposed on wine and brandy the industry would be better off and the Government would increase its revenue. The previous Government lifted the brandy tax. This Government had a responsibility to do something about the alcohol that was being produced. The Auditor-General in his report--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—It is no use Senator Messner saying that he did not. People were using the alcohol and not paying the levy. This Government had to take notice of the Auditor-General. I do not agree with the way the excise was imposed on alcohol. I agree to some extent with what Senator Messner has said, but this Government would have been remiss if it had not done anything about the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I still maintain that it was the fault of the industry in not coming to the realisation that taxes of some sort were inevitable. I believe that sensible arrangements can be made with the industry and government. The industry then will be in a position to flourish. I know that the Minister for Primary Industry , Mr Kerin, has had prolonged talks with the industry and people in that area. He understands the problem. A fault of all governments in the past has been that they have not really looked at this industry. It is different from many other industries. Other industries can adjust far more quickly than can the wine and brandy industry. This has to be looked at in a special light. I believe that is being done now and we are well on the way to achieving a sensible compromise between the industry and this Government.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 12.53 to 2. p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer him to reports which have appeared in the media over the past two days about a paper said to have been prepared by him which aims to change the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy when it is discussed at the July national conference. I preface my question by saying that the Opposition welcomes any move which would bring some rationality into the current policy which is completely devoid of both logic and principle. In view of the likely liberalisation of the policy at the conference, will the Government act immediately at least to allow companies which wish to negotiate in the market- place for new contracts to do so? Has he noted the reply of the Deputy Prime Minister in the House of Representatives yesterday, when Mr Lionel Bowen relied on the existing spot price as a reason for dismissing the relevance of new contracts? Does the Minister accept that the current spot price is not a significant factor when it comes to prospects for long term contracts with so little of Australia's uranium being traded on the spot price basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The significant point of Senator Chaney's question-I think he would agree-is the question of the issuing or granting of negotiating determinations to potential suppliers. That, as he knows, of course, is administratively a matter for the Minister for Trade and not for me.
—You represent him.

—I represent him, yes. I will refer the question to him. But I would not expect that the Minister would be issuing such new determinations prior to the review of the Party's policy on all matters at the National Conference, which is now only three and a half months away. I would agree that the spot price at any particular time is not necessarily a reliable indicator of the prices that are likely to prevail when delivery is actually made, which for uranium contracts is frequently anything from five to 15 years from the time of signing to final delivery. However, an indicator of the general weakness of the market is the fact that stocks currently held are equal to five to six times present consumption and that production is still in excess of consumption, in other words, that high level of stocks is still accumulating.
—What about by 1990?

—If every uranium mine in the world closed down as from next year, the world would have run out of uranium by 1990. That, approximately, is the position and that gives some indication of the magnitude of oversupply of the product.
