No other commodity, even those which are heavily recessed, such as tin and copper are at the moment, carries stocks anything like five to six years' annual consumption. The projections of demand in the 1980s and the 1990s have been substantially reduced.

ANSWER.PARA: For all these reasons, the market is extremely slack. This confirms the judgment made by the Government last year that on commercial grounds alone there would be no room, almost for the rest of this century if not for the rest of it, for any uranium in Australia other than that that can be produced by the two existing mines and Roxby Downs, should the joint ventures make a decision to go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. If there is no commercial possibility of making contracts, on what basis in logic does the Government deny companies the opportunity of going out to sell the uranium that they have under their control, given that if the Government is right they will not be able to sell it but if the Government is wrong the basis which the Minister has put before us is clearly wrong?

—Subject to confirmation by the Minister for Trade I state now that there are two companies with negotiating determinations which have the right to do just what Senator Chaney has said; that is, the two present miners. So far as I know they have not submitted any applications for endorsement of additional contracts, but I will check that with the Minister for Trade and see whether he has anything to add to what I have already said.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to Press reports that the records of a private hospital in Victoria disclosed that a foetus had survived, gasping for air, for some 10 minutes, having been aborted after 18 to 20 weeks gestation in its mother's womb ? Is it a fact that a joint sub-committee of the British Paediatric Association and the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists is expected soon to recommend to its parent bodies that a legal time limit of 24 weeks be set for the termination of a pregnancy and that the World Health Organisation has recommended that the limit be set at 22 weeks? In view of the very considerable advances in medical science, allowing the survival of babies born at a markedly premature stage in their development, will the Federal Minister enter into urgent discussions with State colleagues and professional bodies with a view to ensuring that, at the least, terminations of pregnancy are not carried out in cases where the foetus may be viable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see, I believe in the Melbourne Age, the article that Senator Tate refers to. It reported on the alleged record of an abortion at a very late stage carried out at a Melbourne private hospital. As I understand it, this matter has been raised in the Victorian Parliament by the Victorian Minister of Health, and investigations into it are under way in Victoria. I understand also that there is a move in the United Kingdom to recommend a time limit on abortions of 24 weeks. The Lane parliamentary inquiry in 1974 recommended such a time limit. It is my understanding that moves are under way in the United Kingdom to put such a time limit on as a result of the recommendations of the Royal College of Paediatricians and the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. I think Senator Tate's reference to the time limit in fact refers to the World Health Organisation's definition of viability, which is a pregnancy of 22 weeks or a birth weight of 500 grams. This definition has been adopted in Australia since 1979 or 1980, but it is a definition for statistical purposes and not one referring to the possibility of abortion at that stage at all.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Tate has inferred, legislation on abortion is largely the responsibility of the States, except in the Australian Capital Territory. Only the Northern Territory legislation specifies an upper limit of 23 weeks pregnancy in the case of grave risk to the mental and physical health of the mother. There is also some inconsistency in State laws on abortion, on infanticide, on child destruction and on concealment of birth, where definitions either relate to the duration of pregnancy or to vague things such as a child capable of being alive, et cetera. These inconsistencies were noted in the report of the Royal Commission on Human Relationships, which was tabled here in 1977. They have been a matter for discussion between the State Ministers in recent times. My understanding is that Dr Blewett will refer this and other matters to his State colleagues in the hope that we can get some consistency in this country so far as legislation in this area is concerned. I will certainly make sure he refers this case, along with others, to the State Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government and ask whether it is the intention of the Government to announce a national inquiry into the financing and operations of local government. If so, will the inquiry panel include at least one elected representative from local government? Has the Australian Council of Local Government Associations been consulted on the composition of the inquiry panel and the terms of reference of this inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is considering the establishment of a national inquiry into the operations, functions and financing of local government, although local government falls largely within the purview of State administrations. On 6 March, the Prime Minister wrote to all State Premiers suggesting terms of reference and proposed membership of such a national inquiry . As far as I am aware, only the State of New South Wales has so far indicated its approval for the project in detail, although I think other States have, in formal and informal ways, indicated their general agreement with the proposal. The Federal Government is awaiting final confirmation from the other States. It is proposed that the Australian Council of Local Government Associations will be officially involved. Formal discussions about the inquiry have been held with that body. It is an inquiry for which it has been seeking support for a considerable number of years. So, naturally, as it represents local government associations from the States, it is clear that it will have an important part to play in such an inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: It ought to be stressed that the Australian Labor Party in post-war years has been strongly supportive of the principle that local government should be strengthened and that it has a particular role to play in the three arms of government that operate in this country. In fact, we invited local government representation at the National Economic Summit Conference, and, in an informal capacity, at a number of other national conferences which Labor governments have convened from time to time. I understand that it is the Goverment's intention to have an inquiry and, given the support and endorsement of the States, to have it begin somewhere around the end of May this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Will the Minister for Health discuss with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and State Health Ministers the possibility of facilitating the entry into Australia of overseas specialist medical personnel where necessary to staff Australian public hospitals if doctors here carry out their threat of mass resignation and open defiance of the law covering the charging of scheduled fees and if Australian replacements for specialists cannot be found? If not, can the Minister assure the Senate and the Australian people that patients in public hospitals will not suffer unduly as a result of the threatened irresponsible behaviour of some self-interested members of the medical profession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my answer by saying that what is needed in this dispute is a more rational approach, particularly by those medical specialists who are using publicly funded facilities and the skills they acquired at the taxpayers' expense. They should take a calmer approach.
—Didn't you?
—I did too.
—You are not even using them. What a waste!

—It is good to hear that Senator Walters is back. She has been home and scratched the Rolls; now she comes back here and tries to annoy us and carry on. It is nice to hear her voice again. We need a rational approach, an approach which Dr Blewett has been trying to get from the medical profession. But the medical profession, as Senator Jones knows, will not at the moment accept any concessions; it just wants the right to charge what it likes in public hospitals which, as I say, are provided for it at taxpayers' expense.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer Senator Jones's suggestion to Dr Blewett, but I doubt whether at this stage, or at any stage, this country will reach the point where such a solution to the problem is considered, although I remind honourabe senators opposite that that very solution was used in Saskatchewan, Canada, some years ago much to the disquiet of the medical practitioners in that province. What we need is recognition by some sections of the medical profession that they do have some social responsibility, that they cannot just dictate to the taxpayer how much they should receive without some consultation and without some sensible approach. I hope that the dispute will settle down. I will refer Senator Jones's suggestion to Dr Blewett, but certainly I do not think any member of the Government contemplates such action.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy whether he agrees that the most deceitful election promise in recorded Australian history is:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp referred to an election promise and then quoted a passage from the Australian Labor Party platform-it seems to me that it was quoted accurately-which is not the same thing.
—What is not the same thing?

—I am about to explain that. An election promise, at its tightest definition, is a commitment given by a party leader before an election or by some other parliamentarian on behalf of the party. What is in a platform is somewhat different from that. It is conceptually different. Everybody would agree that the present Labor Party uranium platform is certainly something which can be interpreted in various ways. Some people describe it as a dog's breakfast . Senator Chipp has chosen to quote one line from it, and in isolation it seems to support the proposition he puts forward, disregarding the error that, as far as I know, nobody on behalf of my Party-certainly not the Prime Minister or the then Party leader-made any such commitment in his policy speech. Other lines in that platform say, for example-I quote from memory-'until such time as the Labor Party is satisfied that these problems have been overcome'. That precedes, and it could be argued qualifies, the line which Senator Chipp quoted. Until the Labor Party is satisfied that these problems-that is, problems of waste disposal and weapons proliferation-have been overcome, those actions will be taken. One could have said that the Labor Party is satisfied. Logically it would be possible to say that and therefore everything that follows thereafter is inoperative. I do not want to get bogged down quibbling about this. But I agree, and I have said here before-and I do not think anybody has contradicted me-that the present Party platform on uranium is an untidy piece of English which could be interpreted, and has been interpreted, in a wide variety of ways.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. It stems from the Minister's answer that there were pre-conditions about the total, unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry. He said one could say that the Party is satisfied that those conditions have been met. Are those conditions the safe storage of wastes and the fact that international treaties are binding on Australia and other nations? Is the Labor Party now satisfied that wastes can be stored safely and that treaties do mean something?
—The answer is that probably not everyone is satisfied that the waste disposal problem has been satisfactorily resolved. Some people are.
—I reckon they are.
—Apparently Senator Jessop is satisfied. If Senator Chipp is asking me personally, I am satisfied that it has been resolved, but not everybody would agree.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to the 1986 International Year of Peace program in Australia. Has the Minister considered the potential of developing an intensive pro-peace community awareness program as a possible highlight of the Australian program for the International Year of Peace? Would the Minister welcome the concept of peace awards being made available to private citizens and community and business groups which have contributed to or developed specific peace oriented projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, has advised me that his Department has held a series of consultations with other relevant government departments and agencies to start planning for a comprehensive program of activities to commemorate 1986 as the International Year of Peace. It is envisaged that the IYP program will encompass a diverse range of activities in fields such as the media, the sciences, the arts, sport, business and government and will involve as many sections as possible of the Australian community from both the private and public spheres. Consequently, it is intended that the IYP program, by its nature and scope, should serve as an intensive pro- peace community awareness program.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the suggestion about a system of peace awards being made available to private citizens, the Foreign Minister has advised me that he is attracted to the idea of peace awards for private citizens and community and business groups which have contributed to or developed specific peace oriented projects. He thanks the honourable senator for that suggestion. He has asked his Department to study the proposal carefully as a possible International Year of Peace initiative and report to him. He has told me that he will inform the honourable senator in due course of the result of his consideration of that advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I remind the Minister of the specific promise made by the Australian Labor Party before the election to provide $111m for the general support of government schools over three years and of the criticism that has come from Mr Van Davy and the Australian Teachers Federation of the failure of the Government to deliver the promised $37m first instalment. Will the Minister inform the Senate now when the government schools can expect that first instalment of $37m still outstanding from last year? Can she assure honourable senators that the full amount promised-that is, $111m over three years-will be provided over the next two years of the triennium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Baume and Mr Van Davy of the ATF are well aware, our Government is determined to improve the standards in government education throughout Australia. We are determined to do that because 75 per cent of Australian children are educated in government schools. We are determined to do that because, after seven years of neglect and, to some extent, hostility by the Fraser Administration, many government schools in Australia-not all, but many- are not able to operate at the high standards to which we believe all children should have access. I do not think there can be any doubt in the mind of any observer of the education scene or our Government's education policies about our commitment to improving educational opportunities for children in government schools, particularly in those government schools which have deteriorated as a result of neglect and hostility by conservative governments.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I point out to Senator Baume that we have specifically, in the area of the participation and equity program, for example, made a special commitment of, I think, $24m to improve those government schools which are having poor results in terms of maintaining the participation of children to the end of secondary schooling. There are a number of other programs through which we have increased resources to government schools. In our commitment of capital to government schools, we gave the first increase in capital funding to government schools that had been made for a number of years. Our record in this respect is a good one. There is a great deal more we would like to do with regard to government schools.

I am very hopeful that, when the time comes for me to issue the Government's guidelines for the funding of education, those guidelines will contain more goods news for the government school sector. However, as Senator Baume will be very well aware, I am not in a position, nor is any Minister in this place in a position, to put a dollar tag on any particular program. I will be going in to the Budget negotiations with our commitments to government schools very much to the fore. I believe that, just as in our first Budget we made significant improvements in the standards available to children in government schools, we will improve those standards in the next Budget and over the next triennium.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I want to repeat the very simple question I asked the Minister. Her party did put a dollar tag on the election promise it made. Will the promise of $111m for government schools over the three years be redeemed or will it not?
—Senator Baume will learn all at the time of the publication of the guidelines.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, concerns the community employment program. How does the rate of absorption of funds for the program in South Australia compare with that for other States? How many unemployed people have been employed so far on CEP projects in South Australia? Is the Minister pleased with the general response and the level of assistance being given by the South Australian Government in administering the program?

—As at February of this year 2,482 jobs were approved in South Australia involving over 300 projects. South Australia was the first State to formally agree to participate in CEP, doing so in July last year and having projects approved in early October 1983. The South Australian Government has told the Federal Government that, whilst its absorption of funds under CEP is slightly down on that of other States at the moment, it expects to meet its target expenditure of $21.7m by 30 June this year. The applications received in that State to mid-February under CEP have totalled 783. The Commonwealth Government is pleased with the overall progress in South Australia and with the general response and assistance which has been given by the South Australian Government in the administration of the project. I may be able to provide Senator Foreman in the next few days with some update on the February figures, which are the last ones available.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General in that capacity and also possibly in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the constitutional position of the Queen of Australia when she is in a foreign country. I hasten to say that the question in no way implies any criticism of the Queen, who has my loyalty and admiration. My question is this: When the Queen makes a political speech in a foreign country, as she did recently in Jordan with a speech that obviously expressed the views of the British Government, is it constitutionally clear that she is speaking solely in her capacity as Queen of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and that the views are not necessarily those of the Queen of Australia? Is this fine distinction clear to other countries, if it is not specifically stated, as it was not in Jordan? If not, what can be done about it?

—I do not expect there are too many people, with the obvious exception of Senator Hamer, who would be likely to take the view that when the Queen is in Jordan she is acting in her capacity as Queen of Australia. However, for those souls around the place who are besotted with this particular form of exotica, I will endeavour to find out an answer to that question and advise the honourable senator accordingly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What is the Commonwealth's response to the call by the South Australian Government for the release of documentary evidence about the atomic bomb and hydrogen bomb tests at Maralinga in the 1950s and 1960s? Has any information now been supplied to the South Australian Government concerning the tests? Is the Commonwealth Government stalling over the release of information, as claimed by a legal adviser to former ex-servicemen in a recent article in the Adelaide Advertiser?

—What can be said about all this is what I have been told by the Minister for Defence and it is as follows: On 21 March the Minister for Defence stated that the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council-AIRAC- advised the Government on the effects of ionising radiation exposure on the population and environment. AIRAC's report No. 9, which was issued in January 1983 and was tabled in the Parliament, reviewed the safety of British nuclear tests in Australia. That report is publicly available together with the Department of Health study on the health of atomic test personnel. Department of Defence documentation was made available to AIRAC and similar access, I am told, could be given to the South Australian Government. I am not sure whether the South Australian Government has asked specifically for such access. No doubt, if it does, the material will be made available.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It relates to the Minister's announcement at the weekend of a new pricing formula which reduced the price of liquefied petroleum gas by about $60 a tonne on the current price. At the same time he reduced the subsidy from $80 a tonne to $20.31 a tonne. Recognising that the Government's decision will mean no extra cost to the consumer but a saving of $21m, and recognising the fact that there is an added freight cost of $94 a tonne on LPG going across Bass Strait, will the Minister give consideration to transfer some of that money saved and apply it as a subsidy in areas such as Tasmania which are remote from LPG refineries and which have no natural gas? Does the Minister think that may be an appropriate matter to refer to the Interstate Commission?

—It does not seem to me an appropriate matter to refer to the Interstate Commission. I will think about that a bit more. In any case, I am not the Minister in control of that. Senator Harradine referred to a subsidy. The continuing arrangement is not a subsidy per se; it is a deficiency payment. More relevant to the question, Tasmanians are in exactly the same position vis-a-vis other consumers as regards a subsidy or the present deficiency arrangement.
—Tasmania gets it transported by ship.

—I ask the honourable senator to allow me to finish. Tasmania is not the only part of Australia which has a transport cost added to the wholesale price of LPG. If responsibility were accepted to reduce or pick up that cost for Tasmania there would be equally valid demands to do it in every other part of Australia including, I might add, Sydney, because about one-third of Sydney's gas is transported from the Bass Strait. A freight charge is applied to that and for gas transported to New South Wales in general. Some people might say: 'Why not subsidise it everywhere?' Some people approve of all expenditure propositions and oppose all revenue raising propositions. Governments, of course , cannot behave in that way. Governments have a responsibility finally to reconcile income and expenditure. The Government would be in a better position to consider claims for additional expenditure if half the Senate stopped obstructing the Government's taxation legislation, particularly the legislation to recover from tax dodgers money that ought to have been paid years ago.
—Order! The honourable senator is reflecting on a vote of the Senate. I ask him to desist from that course.
—Mr President, I apologise.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is reflecting on a vote of the Senate and he is not stating the facts. I ask you to call him to order.
—I have already called the Minister to order. I ask the Minister not to reflect on a vote of the Senate. I call the Minister.
—I am not reflecting on a vote of the Senate. I am stating a fact, that precisely half the Senate knocked off a piece of taxation legislation this week.
—Order! The Minister is again reflecting on a vote of the Senate.

—People in opposition and so-called independents can luxuriate and indulge themselves by simultaneously opposing revenue measures and advocating expenditure measures. However, governments do not have that luxury or that potential for self-indulgence. Governments must finally reconcile income and expenditure. I will consider the proposition that Senator Harradine has put up, although administratively it would not be in my area of responsibility. I will discuss it with some other people in the Government, subject to some of the question marks I have put over it.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I understand that the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister have had discussions with the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory concerning the Northern Territory Criminal Code. As this matter is of great concern to Territorians and, indeed, concerned citizens in all parts of Australia, is the Attorney-General in a position to inform the Senate of the outcome of those discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to advise Senator Robertson and the Senate that following those discussions in Sydney a fortnight ago and a subsequent exchange of telexes, the last of which went off today, agreement has been reached today between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory Government on the outstanding differences between us so far as the Criminal Code is concerned. There were four matters ultimately in issue. It will be recalled that the Commonwealth expressed to the Northern Territory the view that those matters had to be amended, in accordance with international standards and prevailing standards of criminal justice in this country, and the Commonwealth would be advising the Governor-General, under the Northern Territory (Self- Government) Act, to make recommendations to the Northern Territory if, in fact, such amendments were not forthcoming.
—Is this an agreement or did you impose it?

—I am saying that there were four matters in issue in respect of which the Commonwealth has indicated that it felt strongly enough to be willing to pursue that course. The Northern Territory Government felt equally strongly about the inappropriateness of that course and an interesting political situation developed as a result. In respect of three of those matters, the Northern Territory Government has now acknowledged that there were real problems with the original drafts of the legislation and it has agreed to amend the legislation accordingly at the first parliamentary opportunity in accordance with the principles proposed by the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: Very briefly, the three matters were as follows: The first concerned section 7 of the Code in which the matter in issue was a request to restore the traditional onus of proof of intent in cases where an offender was intoxicated. The second concerned section 383 of the Code in which the Commonwealth was proposing the deletion of a reference to a fine and to imprisonment and release on bail in circumstances where an accused was acquitted in cases involving intoxication. The third matter, which is extremely important, concerned section 51 of the Code which created a category of prescribed organisations without any provision for judicial review. In respect of all those matters the Northern Territory Government has agreed, as I say, to amend the Code in accordance with the principles I have indicated.

In respect of a fourth matter concerning unsworn statements from the dock, there has been an agreement to disagree. That provision of the Code was not of quite the same standard of offensiveness in the sense of not involving any obvious breach of international standards which seemed to be involved with the other matters. It is a matter in respect of which some jurisdictions in Australia have removed the right. It is also a matter in respect of which lawyers are very much in disagreement among themselves as to its appropriateness . Therefore, the Commonwealth took the view essentially that that was a matter about which reasonable legislatures might disagree. Although we still express our disagreement with that, as indeed we do about many other provisions of the Code, we do not regard that as a matter on which there should be any question of intervention.

In the outcome, as a result of the Northern Territory Government agreeing to amend the law in the way I have indicated, there is now no question of the Commonwealth proceeding down the path as was originally foreshadowed. Although it has to be acknowledged that there have been a considerable number of difficulties along the way in reaching a resolution of this matter, I believe the final outcome has represented something of a triumph for reason and moderation. It does show the utility of a quiet consultative approach being adopted by the Commonwealth in this respect rather than any question of reliance on a big stick. I hope that in the circumstances we can look forward to a period of fruitful co-operation with the Northern Territory Government on other matters that might divide us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which he has quoted.
—If you reckon you will get any help from that, you are welcome to it.
—I meant the telex.
—I was not quoting from the telex. You can have whatever you like. You can have the whole deskful. This is a kindergarten performance.

—My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and seeks clarification of a matter that consistently is raised by veterans. I refer to the pamphlet 'Medicare and Repatriation' issued by the Department. The section headed 'Medicare or Repatriation-a matter of Choice' indicates that repatriation beneficiaries will have a choice of taking health care under their entitlements in the repatriation system or under Medicare. I ask whether this is really a choice, since repatriation entitlements are significantly different from Medicare, which covers only public patient situations with no choice of doctor, and no other services. The pamphlet further suggests that there is no need to take out private health insurance if you are prepared to accept the treatment to which you are entitled under the repatriation system and/or that available under Medicare. Is not the inference here that the two entitlements are the same? I believe they are not. Is this not therefore a dubious piece of advice? I ask the Minister to clarify it.

—The Department has issued a pamphlet which indicates to veterans that they do have now freedom of choice in respect of their medical entitlements. Those who are eligible for repatriation benefits can still have their entitlements recognised, in every respect, at repatriation general hospitals. They can now elect to have basic health care attended to at any of the public hospitals situated anywhere in the State in which they reside. In addition, if they are entitled to specific benefits as a result of being recognised repatriation beneficiaries, then the Department also takes that into account in respect of any additional benefits or assistance they need in regard to their incapacity, illness or otherwise. The beneficiary can elect in the first instance to go to a public hospital rather than to a repatriation hospital . That freedom of choice is available to him. He can have such assistance rendered to him, if he is eligible for that assistance, in the public hospital system.

—I address my question to the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Has the Minister seen the suggestion that at least half of the 23 new Federal seats should be named after women? Will the Minister write to the Chairman of the Electoral Commission supporting such a proposal?
—Call one 'Daisy'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When my colleague Senator Grimes can restrain himself I will answer the question Senator Robert Ray has asked. I was fortunate and pleased to be in the chamber during the adjournment debate last night when Senator Maguire made his very interesting, and I think very important, suggestion. I interpreted Senator Maguire's suggestion that at least half of the new Federal electorates should be named after women as a recognition by him of the contribution made by Australian women to public life and the past neglect of recognition of that contribution.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out that there is no self-interest in my enthusiasm for Senator Maguire 's suggestion, since there is already a Federal electorate called Ryan, though clearly not named after me as I am not yet dead. I think it is a very good suggestion. I must say that it is satisfying to those of us in this place who have been trying to achieve greater recognition of the contribution of Australian women to public life that not only are the women of this chamber raising suggestions as to how we can recognise the contribution made by Australian women, but now some of our male colleagues are joining us in that exercise. Certainly I will make whatever formal expressions of endorsement of Senator Maguire's suggestion to the Electoral Commissioner it is proper for me to make. In the meantime, I ask honourable senators on both sides of the chamber to support Senator Maguire in pursuing this thoughtful and constructive suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of allegations made by a Labor member in the Queensland Parliament relating to the Sunshine Association of Australia and the apparent mismanagement of funds within that organisation? Is he aware that on 22 August 1983 the Australian Democrat member of the House of Assembly, Mr Gordon Walsh, wrote to the Hon. Tom Uren, MP, with similar allegations about the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Sunshine Association of Australia? In particular, is the Attorney-General aware that the Community Development Fund file on this Association reveals that its projected budget for 1983-84 indicates that $67,048 will be spent on salaries and expenses , but no mention is made of anticipated expenditure to assist terminally ill children? By the way, this body is apparently assisted by a $73,000 loan from its parent body in Queensland. Does the Attorney-General agree with Mr Uren's response of 29 November 1983, which indicated that the matter was very sensitive ; that the interests of all parties needed to be protected; and that there was no scope under the Associations Incorporation Ordinance 1953 to undertake any investigation into the allegations? If he does agree, will he say who could undertake the necessary investigation, and whether or not he is prepared to recommend such an inquiry?
—I am not at all sure that this is within my portfolio.
—According to Mr Uren it is.

—That is interesting. My knowledge of this is confined to two small facts. One is that I recall seeing that the Queensland Attorney- General recently made some noises about this particular Sunshine Association and about the inappropriateness of its continuing to be registered under the Queensland voluntary associations legislation. I know also, as a fact, that there is a degree of concern about the inadequacies of certain provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Associations Incorporation Ordinance, in respect of which some remedial action is now taking place. As to the linkage between those two phenomena, I know nothing. I will endeavour to give the the honourable senator further and better particulars in due course.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the prospects for Christmas Island, in the Indian Ocean, after the projected exhaustion of high grade phosphate deposits on the Island in about 10 years time ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of Christmas Island has been a matter of consideration by governments for quite a number of years. In fact the previous Government commissioned a report to be made by a Mr Sweetland. That report was presented to the Parliament within the past 18 months. So far as I am aware, the report has still not had any response from the Government, although it is contemplated that it will shortly be placed before Cabinet for consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the high grade phosphate on Christmas Island has a very limited period ahead of it-about nine or 10 years-and the question of the future of the Island is therefore a matter to be considered by the Government. As I am advised, the previous administration was jointly operated by the British and Australian Governments. The company concerned with extracting phosphates from Christmas Island has closed down its operations or is in the process of doing so . The Australian Government has formed a new organisation called the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd. It aims to establish new markets because of the depressed state of marketing of phosphate. There is a possibility that, as a result of initiatives taken by the Australian Government, we will be able to find some new markets not only for the high grade phosphate which has been a feature of Christmas Island but also for the low grade phosphate which hitherto has been regarded as not a commercial proposition. It should be possible to open up new markets in South East Asia. If that does not eventuate, the Government will look seriously at alternative industries, particularly a tourist industry on Christmas Island. I can assure Senator Colston that the Government has this actively under consideration and will shortly make a response to the report of the Sweetland Commission of Inquiry into the Viability of the Christmas Island Phosphate Industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General see any conflict between his proposals for amendments to the Trade Practices Act relating to unconscionable conduct with regard to contracts and one sided contracts and section 17 of the Health Insurance Act giving Dr Blewett complete power to change doctors' contracts at any time yet denying doctors the right of appeal?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What action does the Minister propose to take in relation to the further prosecution of the suspended Foreign Affairs officer, Mr Don Witheford, which the Acting Chief Magistrate, Mr Dobson, said on 16 March was conceived in prejudice and borne in bias on the part of some officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs? What action does the Minister intend to take in regard to apparent instances of perjury by prosecution witnesses? What action does the Minister intend to take regarding a new allegation by Foreign Affairs staff that the Secretary, Mr Peter Henderson, evaded customs duty, freight charges and possibly quarantine regulations by bringing in the diplomatic bag from the United Kingdom a riding saddle?

—As to the first two matters, I have received certain representations, as might be expected. I have referred them, as might now also be expected, to the statutory officer whose job it is to deal with them, the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Ian Temby, QC. As to the third matter mentioned, the alleged importation of a riding saddle, I will refer that to the Minister of Foreign Affairs so that he can make such inquiries about this as he deems appropriate.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy and refers to the Government's proposal for a resource rent tax on off-shore oil . Is the Minister aware that such a tax would reduce Australia's self- sufficiency in oil production through increased taxation, leading to more oil imports, less government revenue and less jobs? Does the Minister realise that Australia's oil prospectivity is close to the lowest in the world and that an RRT would further reduce exploration? Is the Government aware of the theoretical and practical problems involved, including the fact that the prospect of high rewards is the driving force in oil exploration and that forcing an RRT to fit Australian circumstances would create costly, time consuming and long lasting administrative tangles, and doubtless lead to the discovery of less oil?

—I am aware that all the assertions made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen have been made by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd recently in a booklet and by Esso Australia Ltd. Almost without exception they are based on a myth and an inadequate analysis of the proposition that the Government has put up and are either a misunderstanding or a misrepresentation of it. I note that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has faithfully learned the lines that have been put to her by APEA.

—Can the Minister for Social Security report on current negotiations with State governments regarding the organisation of the women's emergency services program? In particular, is the Minister aware of concern that realistic salary increases for women's refuge workers may not be implemented by the Queensland Government? Furthermore, can the Minister assure all Queensland women's refuge organisations that the new funding arrangements will be expedited through that State so that women's refuges will not experience the serious delays of past years?

—I am at the moment negotiating with the States for the distribution of the women's emergency services money. Replies to this Government 's offer for the use of that money are now coming in. We have offered to use those funds to increase the salaries of all funded positions in refuges in each State and to upgrade to four the number of positions in those refuges where there are less than four. I received a letter from the Minister for Welfare Services in Queensland in the last couple of days accepting the conditions for the distribution of funds. He says that he is at the moment talking to Queensland refuges to decide how those funds will be distributed. Provided his concept of the conditions is the same as mine, I see no reason why the funds cannot flow to Queensland very quickly. A similar situation prevails in some of the other States. I am still awaiting replies from others. I hope that within the next month I will be in a position to distribute all those funds, the initial aim being to upgrade the wages and conditions of women who work in refuges who, as Senator Reynolds knows, are amongst the most exploited workers in this country. It has been a long process, largely because of the wariness of the States, I believe, that the Commonwealth will fund something this year and leave them holding the baby next year. However, I think we have managed to reassure most of the States that that is not the case and that the money will go out very soon.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and is asked in light of the new approach he is adopting to uranium policy. Will he as a matter of urgency, first, give the green light to the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia to recommence its final study of the market possibilities and technology of uranium enrichment, bearing in mind the projected future markets for enriched uranium as from 1990, the strict control that Australia could exert on its processing and marketing and the employment prospects for Australia? Secondly, will he re-institute full research on uranium enrichment at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission? If he will not go along with those suggestions, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney referred to giving the green light to UEGA. The Government has neither given the green light nor the red light to UEGA.
—Oh, cut it out. You denied it facilities.

—No. We said that we were standing by and not doing anything about it. I do not know what will be done. The Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia did put a pro position to the Government that we should assist it to pursue this study further. We did nothing. We responded neither positively nor negatively. We have not stopped it.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the second proposition relating to the Atomic Energy Commission and uranium enrichment, the Atomic Energy Commission, like all other qangos or subsidiaries, will of course be subject to pretty stringent financial discipline this year. At this stage, if only for that reason, I could not make such a forecast. However, I think it unlikely that the relative emphasis will be changed towards enrichment and away from waste disposal. I am sure Senator Chaney will know that last year there was a qualitative change in the Commission 's activities towards waste disposal and away from enrichment. I do not expect that that will be reversed even apart from the overriding financial constraint which will be applied to all Government expenditure this year and the limitations therefore on the adoption of new programs or the expansion of existing ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask for some clarification from the Minister of the early part of his answer. Does he deny that the operations of UEGA were frustrated by the Government's refusal to co-operate with the study and to obtain for it information which could only be obtained by the Government?

—I cannot remember the precise details but it would have been of assistance to the consortium, or whatever one should call it, if the Government had conducted negotiations with other governments. An exchange of information was relevant to that, as I recall it. The Government did not approach other governments on behalf of the Group in that way. But we did not close down the study.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen the editorial in the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 28 March, entitled 'Just How Super?' which outlines some possible alternatives for the operation of a national superannuation scheme? Does the Minister agree that the accumulated funds of a national superannuation scheme would place considerable strains on the total Australian market for investment capital in absorbing the amounts involved? Can the Minister assure the Senate that plans for a national superannuation scheme are under way and will be in place as soon as practicable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I read the editorial in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, which was basically on a national superannuation scheme and how such a scheme may or may not be introduced. It is an interesting and reasonable article . Senator McIntosh's reference to the comment in the article on the effect of accumulated funds on investment in this country relates, I think, to the projection of the Australian Government Actuary, Mr Ford, who pointed out that if we had a superannuation scheme in this country funded by 5 per cent of income tax the figure could reach something like $45 billion in 1991 and $307 billion in 2051 and that would, indeed, have a considerable effect on investment in this country. My personal belief is that the introduction of such a funded scheme is not appropriate or likely. I do not think the taxpayers of this country would take very much to the introduction of a funded scheme which would not provide benefits for another 20 or 30 years or so. The usual proposal is, in fact, to introduce a pay-as-you-go scheme to make sure that more than the present 35-odd per cent of people who have access to superannuation can get access to superannuation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is still looking at this matter with the intention of introducing a contributory superannuation scheme in this country. I suppose one should welcome articles or editorials such as the one in the Australian Financial Review so that we can raise the level of debate on this subject. I commend the editorial particularly to Senator Haines, who the other day announced in this place that we could introduce a national superannuation scheme and provide benefits without putting on a levy or without increasing taxation on the grounds that the present pension system costs a fair bit of money. I think Senator Haines should be disabused of that little theory and this article will in part do that.

We are still at both the departmental level and the ministerial level looking at the introduction of a national superannuation scheme which I believe will have to be introduced. But one needs at the same time to make reforms to the occupational superannuation system in this country. As this is such a large industry, we must negotiate with both the unions and the industry itself before taking any precipitate action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Townley asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism regarding the launching of the domestic tourism campaign in Sydney last week. I undertook to seek a reply and my colleague the Hon. John Brown has provided me with the following: On Thursday, 22 March, the Australian Tourist Commission launched the domestic tourism campaign in co-operation with the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. The advertising agency to the Commission and a professional promotions company were involved in the launching. The program is aimed at encouraging Australians to holiday at home. I am advised by my colleague the Minister that if the domestic tourism market could be expanded by a mere 5 per cent as a result of the launching of this program some $600m would be injected into the Australian economy and some 20,000 extra jobs would be created. Surely, even the small-minded Opposition could see that the launching was the sprat to catch a mackerel.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has, through the ATC, embarked on a major advertising campaign featuring the well known comedian Paul Hogan to promote this initiative . The evening was also the occasion for the launching of a motivational booklet which will appear in the April issue of the Australian Women's Weekly magazine. Some two million copies were printed and these will also be available in airline offices and from travel agents. Some 300 people attended the launching, including State Government representatives, captains of industry, the leaders of all facets of the tourist trade and the airlines. As well, more than 50 media representatives attended. The Channel 10 studios were chosen because of the advanced technical facilities available. The ATC has produced a videotape of the program which will be distributed Australia-wide. This, of course will be made available to all parliamentarians should they wish to see it.

The cost of the production was in the vicinity of $100,000 and Mr Brown resents the undertone of alleged misappropriation insinuated by Senator Townley in framing his question. This expenditure was approved directly by my colleague Mr Brown. The function started at 4 p.m. and finished at 8 p.m. A buffet dinner was provided which could in no way be called extravagant. The launching was considered an extremely successful event by all concerned and the honourable senator may, if he wishes, see all the congratulatory letters and telegrams the government has received following the launching. Indeed, the ATC received $1.6m from private contributors to promote the domestic campaign. Major contributors include General Motors-Holden's Ltd, Trans Australian Airlines and Ansett, to name just a few, and we are still receiving contributions following the launching on the 22nd.

The big failing in the promotion of tourism by the previous Government was its lack of professionalism. The launching on the 22nd was typical of the professionalism now being applied and the proof of the Government's success is the fact that industry contributions towards the promotion by the ATC this year are six times greater than ever achieved by the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statement which has just been made by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs in response to the question asked by Senator Townley and then I will seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to go on about this matter but I must because of extra material on pages 790 and 797 of yesterday's Senate Hansard report of Question Time concerning an exchange between Senator Grimes and me following my legitimate and genuine question about Medicare. I asked for a withdrawal of the inference by Senator Grimes that I was not telling the truth in asking that question. He withdrew that. However, Senator Grimes, when making a personal explanation, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest Senator Teague read the Hansard to see what I answered.
When I read the Hansard to my surprise and to the surprise of a number of people in the Senate there were some extra words spoken of which I was not aware at the time. They are these:
. . . instead of telling lies, as he is doing now.
Those words are directly contrary to the trumped up assurance that Senator Grimes gave in his personal explanation yesterday when, as recorded on page 797, he said:

I was referring to the fact that members of the Opposition on occasions get up and tell lies about Medicare. I was not referring to Senator Teague's question, as he put it this afternoon. I was not referring to the items in his question. I suggest Senator Teague read the Hansard to see what I answered.
So I read the Hansard and it says:
. . . instead of telling lies, as he is doing now.

This is directly contrary to what the Minister said in his personal explanation. I raise this matter only to say that if I am challenged by a Minister I will look up the Hansard and make my remarks accordingly. I do not believe that honourable senators should be subjected to the kinds of remarks and abuse, for which there were no grounds whatsoever, of the sort made by Senator Grimes in the Senate yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the matter raised by Senator Teague, my attention was drawn this morning to the page of Hansard referred to. I did not hear uttered at the time the last words of Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, because at that time I was in the course of calling the next questioner, Senator Bolkus. Had I caught Senator Grimes's words at the time, I would have asked for a withdrawal of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by the story in the Australian Financial Review today headed 'Consumer Safeguards Urgent in Introduction of EFT-Evans'. That headline and the opening paragraph of the story wrongly ascribe to me a statement that I had said there was an urgent need for legislation to deal with certain issues arising from the introduction of electronic funds transfer systems. That article was based on an answer I gave in Question Time yesterday to a question from Senator Crowley.

SPEECH.PARA: In that answer, I at no stage said that there was an urgent need for laws to address EFT issues. I said that other people, including Mr Landa, Justice Kirby and interested groups had expressed themselves to this effect, but also pointed out that, on the other hand, the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System had said there was no pressing need for legislation.

I said that the Government was giving consideration to the issue. Indeed, the whole thrust of my answer was that there are arguments both for and aginst regulation. I at no stage indicated a view favouring regulation. The urgency that I was stressing was for consideration of the question given the concern that had been expressed. The first principle that governs the Government's response in this matter was spelt out in the Government's election policy on business regulation, namely that: 'A Labor Government has no interest in regulating business for the sake of regulation'. I fear that a contrary impression may well have been left with a reader of the Australian Financial Review article this morning. It is on that basis that I take this opportunity to correct it at the first opportunity.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Coleman proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The pressing need for Australia and other world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put forward this matter as one of public importance because I consider the Senate an appropriate forum for such a discussion. I hope that it will not be the last and I hope also that discussion is not confined to these hallowed halls. I firmly believe that if Australia and other world powers do not become involved in that constructive discussion of international nuclear disarmament now, it may well be too late. I believe that the most important, relevant and overwhelming fact is that, unless moves are made to control and eventually halt the arms race, our planet will experience a nuclear war. It is no longer a matter of choice. I believe that if we do not act soon nuclear war is not only possible but inevitable.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now lived with nuclear weapons for some 40 years and perhaps we have become accustomed to having them around. In the first instance one country had two bombs. Now, nine countries have a total capacity in excess of 47,000 bombs with about one million times the explosive power of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. Those figures are pretty awe inspiring. It is not simply a matter of the number of weapons available or the strident rhetoric of world leaders that are the real causes for concern. The problems include the fact that agreements are being made and disregarded, that people are sitting down to talk and not saying anything, or are getting angry and walking out of disarmament talks when things do not go their way. The problems also include the fact that we are reaching the stage where the decision about what button to press, and when, is being taken away from human beings. It is being passed over to computers.

I sometimes wonder whether there is an appreciation of the amounts of money spent on defence. I quote from a paper by Desmond Ball of the Australian National University headed 'Management of the Superpower Balance'. The paper was written for the Conference on International Security in the Southeast Asian and Southwest Pacific Region in July 1982. As that document relates to 1982, in all probability the figures are understated, but the important point made by Dr Ball was this:

Over the next five years the United States plans to spend some $1.3 trillion on defence and the Soviet Union will undoubtedly spend something similar-equivalent in sum to more than $1m a day for the last 7,000 years!

To most people those figures are absolutely incomprehensible. I think I can handle figures up to seven digits. I can recognise the possibility and probability of millions of dollars, but figures such as $1.3 trillion create tremendous confusion and the majority of people find them incomprehensible. Certainly to those people who are dying as a result of abject poverty and disease, those amounts of money spent on 'defence' are incomprehensible.

It would be true to say that disarmament moves have been a crucial component of world peace since the cold war, but in the 1980s I believe it has taken on a greater urgency as more and more countries have become involved in the nuclear arms race. The stockpiles of nuclear weapons have reached such proportions that the potential for mass destruction has become an overwhelming reality. Later, I shall ask leave to incorporate three tables in Hansard. They relate to the arms race, the situation as at 1983, who has got what and where; what they are; the types of materials that are available; the tests that have been done, and, in addition, the arms control and disarmament agreements that apply to nuclear weapons. I shall read from those in a moment.

It would also be true to say that in the 1970s the general move to detente was at least receiving a little encouragement from most of the world leaders. It is in the 1980s that we have found those negotiations reaching a stalemate. With trillions of dollars being poured into defence budgets, there are people in the Third World and developing countries, and even in developed countries, who are dying of starvation, poverty and disease. If that money were transferred into those areas, those problems could, in the main, be cured next week, next month or perhaps, at the outside, next year. What is required is a transference of funds.

In some of those developed and developing countries there are people who are uneducated, unfed, unclothed, not properly housed and without access to proper medical care. We are talking about an expenditure of $1.3 trillion within five years. I believe that the need for a nuclear disarmament program is clear enough , but it is always easy to lay down programs to instigate world action. It is not so easy to put them into operation. Therefore, I appreciate the opportunity to raise this as a matter of public importance. I hope that we shall have more of these discussions and that more members of parliament will become involved. It is interesting to note from the list of speakers, which to a large extent is pre-arranged, that four speakers are co-conveners of the newly formed parliamentary Disarmament Group, and that a fifth is the secretary of that group which encompasses all parties. It includes Senator Teague from the Liberal Party , Senator Boswell from the National Party, Senator Mason from the Australian Democrats, myself, and Senator Hearn who is the secretary of the organisation.

I believe that in any program for international nuclear disarmament discussion, Australia has a great role to play. The program itself would require the end of research, development, manufacture and sale of nuclear weapons, including those space-based initiatives we now hear so much about-the laser beam technology which frightens the daylights out of many people. It would also require the destruction of existing nuclear stockpiles and an end to military blocs based on nuclear weaponry and the establishment of international security checks on clandestine military nuclear activity. I repeat that it is easy to lay down programs, but not so easy to put them into operation. To put them into operation we must have consultation of thinking around the world, with people agreeing that disarmament is necessary at present.

In most regions we find that there is already a vicious circle. The most typical example is what is currently happening in Iraq and Iran. Money is spent on arms, for instance in Iraq, and Iran has to have provided to it or has to purchase weapons that are a little more technologically advanced. Iraq then purchases something that is a little better. No country makes an appreciable gain while the barons of the arms manufacturing area are making millions of dollars, keeping us poised on the edge of destruction. Horizontal nuclear proliferation is a dramatic threat to world peace and the world as we know it. It is also taking away from people their right to survive with dignity. I have mentioned already those people who are dying of poverty, starvation and disease.

I believe the potential for world destruction is a reality we must all face. Australians cannot consider themselves safely hidden away just because they happen to reside in the southern hemisphere. Scientists have already confirmed the fear held and spoken about by a number of us over many years that whatever happens in the northern hemisphere will affect us too. We cannot simply say that if there were a limited nuclear war in the northern hemisphere we would not be involved. That is fiction, not fact. For those honourable senators who may not have been aware of it, within the last two weeks in Western Australia a Nationwide segment showed that the United States, one of the super-powers, has not only fought and won a third world war but is already arming and planning for a fourth world war. The United States was shown in the program as seeing a third world war as a nuclear war of limited duration, an exchange lasting perhaps two months. What the program did no show and what it is not possible to show is the utter devastation of any nuclear exchange. That is precisely why there has not been a nuclear exchange. If there is, there will be utter and complete devastation at the point of contact and a certain amount of devastation in the immediate surrounding areas. If it occurs in Europe, with the prevailing winds Australia will be affected.

Despite all the attempts at political detente about which I have spoken, there has been no progress in the area of disarmament. There have been many arms control and disarmament treaties. We have, for instance, the Antarctic Treaty of 1959, the Hot Line and Modernisation Agreements of 1963, the Limited Test Ban Treaty of 1963, the Outer Space Treaty, the Latin American Nuclear-free Zone Treaty, the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the Seabed Treaty, the Accidents Measures Agreement, the Prevention of Nuclear War Agreement, the Threshold Test Ban Treaty, the Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty , plus a plethora of other talks and conferences, including the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks Nos I, II and III.

I raise the question at this time of how these agreements can be secured. To use the buzz words of today, how can consensus be achieved? The answer, of course, is not simple. It is a very complex question and involves consideration of the social, economic and political climate as well as consideration of the perceptions, understandings and values of individuals. I believe that individual changes are interwoven with social, political and economic changes. They are mutually dependent. One cannot be achieved without the other. Basically, an international order of co-operation, understanding and peaceful co-existence is needed. That situation can be achieved only if there is a greater degree of universal equality, economic, social and political, because disarmament measures will be universally accepted only if they are of equal benefit to all. One super -power will not make a move if the other super-power is advantaged. A figure of $350 billion is being spent annually on military arms. That figure could be a little higher now, but it is the latest in the SIPRI Yearbook. If that money were deployed into other more humanitarian areas we would see a reduction in that polarisation of poverty on the one hand and wealth on the other, and political security would be enhanced by that social security.

Expenditure on nuclear arms is senseless, immoral, and an irresponsible waste of human, technological and financial resources. Military expenditure throughout the world exceeds that for health services by two and a half times and that for education by one and a half times. Forecasters see the world population doubling by the year 2019. They also forecast that the poor will constitute 90 per cent of the world population at that time. If we continue to spend in excess of $350 billion a year on nuclear arms and armaments-weapons of destruction-even greater problems will exist in the future time than exist today. I believe there would be greater economic independence with the advent of nuclear disarmament. The free flow trade would be enhanced by nuclear disarmament. The economic independence of countries would be enhanced, and that is an element essential to what we are talking about. Wealthy countries would have to spend a certain percentage of their gross national product on foreign aid to bring up the levels of the underdeveloped countries to those of the developed countries. It would mean the international co-operation of all scientific, technical and technological resources, the end of the colonialism and neo-colonialism that still exists in its various forms throughout the world, the removal of foreign bases from all countries, and the abolition of arms sales. That is a big program .

Today, because time is limited and I want as many people as possible to join in this debate, I will just talk for a moment about discussions I had this morning with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden. He was most supportive of the Parliamentary Disarmament Group and what it is endeavouring to do and of the fact that we are having this debate in the Senate today. The year 1986 is the United Nations International Year of Peace. In my discussions with Mr Hayden this morning he was most supportive of a number of proposals that will be put forward and given due consideration for a build-up to 1986. These may include a number of forums such as this, but not, as I said before, inside these hallowed halls.

Given that that year has already been declared as one of peace, there is a proposal that Australia could perhaps play a much more significant role than it has in the past or than it is playing now. We have got to the stage of appointing an ambassador for disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, but that in itself is not enough. It is very nice to have Mr Richard Butler, an extremely competent and capable person, wandering around the world talking about disarmament, but it is not enough. Australia is a force on the world scene. There are some who would say we are a small voice. Believe me, we are recognised on the world scene as a powerful force. Not only should we instigate discussions of this nature and bring together people from other countries, possibly in our own region, to debate the issues that are required for nuclear disarmament, but we should look further. Perhaps we should be looking at acting in the role of mediator or conciliator. I know that those are more of those 'buzz' words, but is there any reason why Australia could not be the conciliator between the two super-powers, which are having such difficulty at the moment in sitting down and having a comprehensive discussion about the very real problems we here today see in nuclear disarmament? Is there anything wrong with our putting forward the proposal that we will go to the Geneva talks and act as chairman in those discussions, and God help either one of the super-powers if they decide to move out of those places.

Let me just say this in the short time remaining: I believe the role that the media has to play is a most important one. I have noticed with interest-and I am sure other honourable senators who have a concern in this area have noticed also -the prominence that is being given to recent stories about nuclear weaponry and nuclear disarmament. Educational-type stories are being placed where people now read them. They are no longer being consigned to the back pages of the newspapers but are appearing on the front pages. They express concern at articles such as the one in the Age on Thursday 16 February entitled 'Soviets have moved subs to Atlantic', according to the United States. That is cause for concern. People read those articles and that gives them the ability to go out and discuss competently with other people, who express the same concern, what they have read.

I believe there are a great number of things we can do. The speakers this afternoon all come from the Parliamentary Disarmament Group-or the majority of them, as I recognise that Senator Sir John Carrick is not one of the co- convenors of that committee. He and I crossed swords many times in this chamber on matters relevant to the discussion but never, ever on this subject. We are always totally in agreement that Australia has a tremendous role--

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we put our swords down?

—Yes, we could indeed. With the budgeting of funds for the establishment of the institute of peace and research development, we perhaps will have a greater input-once that institute is established at, I understand, the Australian National University-from this chamber into what that institute is doing, just as I hope it will be putting into these hallowed halls what it is doing over there.
