SECTION ONE: THE MILITARY CONNECTION
HISTORY OF THE NUCLEAR WEAPONS RACE
*Atomic bomb-In 1945 the U.S. exploded the first atomic bomb. The U.S.S.R. followed in 1949.

*Intercontinental bomber-In 1948 the U.S. started to replace its World War II propellor bombers with jets. These intercontinental (strategic) bombers needed refuelling between continents. In 1955 the U.S. started deployment of an all-jet bomber force and the U.S.S.R. followed suit the same year.

*Thermonuclear bomb-The U.S. exploded the first H-bomb in 1954. The yield was 15,000,000 tons TNT (15 megatons), about 1,000 times more powerful than the Hiroshima atomic bomb. In 1955 the U.S.S.R. tested a 1 megaton thermonuclear device.

*Intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM)-The U.S.S.R. successfully tested an ICBM in 1957 and the U.S. did it in 1958. By 1962, both countries could deliver 5 to 10 megaton payloads over 6,000 miles by ICBMs.
*Satellite in orbit-In 1957 the U.S.S.R. launched Sputnik 1 and the U.S. followed in 1958. More than half the U.S. and Soviet satellites launched have been for military purposes.

*Submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM)-In 1960 the U.S. introduced the third leg of its nuclear triad, the long range missile fired from a submerged nuclear submarine. The Polaris submarine carried missiles with a range of 1,200 nautical miles. The U.S.S.R. had developed a similar capability by 1968.
*Multiple warhead (MRV)-The U.S. developed MRV'd missiles with three warheads in 1966. The U.S.S.R. developed them by 1968.

*Anti-ballistic missile (ABM)-In 1968 the U.S.S.R. deployed 64 defensive missiles around Moscow. The U.S. began the Safeguard system in 1969 but a treaty in 1972 restricted each country to one site each. The missiles were not considered effective and the U.S. site was closed.

*Multiple independently-targeted warhead (MIRV)-The MIRV missile carried three to ten individually targetable warheads capable of hitting targets 100 miles apart. The U.S. deployment began in 1970 and Soviet deployment in 1975.

*Long-range Cruise missile-The U.S. developed the small, relatively inexpensive , highly accurate and low flight profile Cruise missile with a range of 1,500 miles in 1982. The missile can be launched from air, sea or land and can use natural ground cover to escape detection. U.S.S.R. technology is reportedly 7-8 years behind in this area.

*Neutron bomb-The U.S. developed the 'enhanced radiation yield' neutron bomb and announced it was producing and stockpiling the bomb in 1981. The U.S.S.R. announced it was deferring production but possessed the productive capability.
*Anti-satellite weapons-The U.S.S.R. began testing anti-satellite weapons in 1968. Both countries are developing laser and particle beam anti-satellite weapons.
(Source: SIVARD, 1978)

Comment: It can be seen that the U.S. has been the initiator of most new weapons developments. It can also be seen that none of these new weapons has increased global stability or security, and has always led to a new weapons development. It is evident that once a weapon is developed, it is a matter of only a small-time interval till it is acquired by the opposition. It is apparent that the arms race will only end through mutual disarmament or mutual, and global, destruction.
ALP Federal Platform Reference: P81, P83, P73-75, P88, P33
NUCLEAR WEAPONS TESTING
Between 1945 and end 1982, 1,375 nuclear tests were carried out.
Nuclear tests U.S. 700; U.S.S.R. 500; U.K. 35; France 113; China 26; India 1.

In 1983, 48 nuclear tests were carried out. The U.S. carried out 12 tests, France seven and the U.S.S.R. 27, 13 of which were ''peaceful'' explosions for excavating underground reservoirs. China resumed atmospheric testing after a break of three years.
(Source: ''World Military and Social Expenditures, 1983'', by Ruth Leger Sivard .)

Comment: In 1963 the Limited Test Ban Treaty was signed by 111 states which banned nuclear testing in the atmosphere, outer space and underwater. This ban was largely achieved by the efforts of some radiation experts who questioned the effects of fallout from such tests on local populations. China, however, resumed atmospheric testing in 1983.

French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll, in contravention of the expressed view of regional governments has been a continual problem. Reports persist of increased cancer and other health problems in the area caused by the tests and the atoll itself is said to be breaking up from the effects of the tests.

In Australia, the long term effects of British atomic tests on Australian personnel involved in the tests and people in surrounding areas is still in contention. Tests were carried out at the Monte Bellos islands off the W.A. coast and Emu Field and Maralinga in South Australia.

South Africa may have exploded two nuclear devices already. It is likely, however, that that country has the capability to produce nuclear weapons when wanted, as does Israel and Pakistan, but does not actually test them.
ALP Federal Platform Reference: P73-74, P81, P83, P136.
MILITARY SPENDING AND SOCIAL COST
*World military spending $618,744,000,000 (1982)-Increase of 4% per year 1979- 83.
*U.S. Military spending: $169,691,000,000 (1982)-Increase of 7% per year 1979- 83.
*Nato military spending: $285,747,000,000 (1982)
*Soviet military spending: $135,500,000,000, (1982)-Increase of 2% per year 1979-83
*Warsaw pact military spending: $148,280,000,000 (1982)
(Source: Sipri Yearbook, 1983)

*Between 1960 and 1981, the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. spent $3,100,000,000,000 on military power, well over the figure for all other countries combined. Their combined population is less than one eighth the global total.
*The U.S. ranks 9th out of 142 countries in economic-social standing (i.e. quality of life) and the U.S.S.R. 25th.
*Worldwide, 2,000,000,000 people have incomes below $500 per year. One person in five lives in abject poverty. In the U.S. 34 million people are classified as poor.
*Worldwide, 600,000,000, are unemployed and less than fully employed. In the Third World, one in three can't find regular work.
*Worldwide, 11,000,000 babies die before their first birthday and 5,000,000 children die of common diseases annually.

*Worldwide, 2,000,000,000 do not have a regular supply of safe drinking water and three quarters of the Third World has no sanitary facilities. Most Third World sickness is attributable to these two problems.
*Worldwide, 450,000,000 people suffer from hunger and malnutrition.
*Worldwide, 120,000,000 school age children get no education.
*Between 1960 and 1982, military spending by developed countries rose by over $ 400 billion. Foreign economic aid rose by $25 billion.
In 1982, military spending was 17 times greater than aid spending.
Source: ''World Military and Social Expenditures 1983''.

Comment: The problem with the arms race is not just its probable conclusion in nuclear war, but also the sheer waste of resources, material and human, consumed by the weapons industry, which should be solving global environmental, health and poverty problems.

As the Brandt Report pointed out, it is not simply our moral obligation to ease global wealth inequality, but the key to economic progress as well. However, the rich and powerful countries not only waste their own money, resources and people on the arms race, they also suck the poor countries into it. Weapons sales to underdeveloped countries are booming with the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. the bigger merchants. In 1980, the U.S. sold $18 billion worth of arms and the U.S.S.R. $15 billion worth, mainly to Third World countries.
The reality regarding the arms race and its social cost was stated clearly over twenty years ago by the then U.S.President, Dwight Eisenhower when he said:
'Every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired, signifies in a final sense a theft from those who hunger and are not fed and from those who are cold and are not clothed'.

ARMS CONTROL AND DISARMAMENT AGREEMENTS
NUCLEAR WEAPONS
TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS
Antarctic Treaty, 1959-26 states
Bans any military uses of Antarctica and specifically prohibits nuclear tests and nuclear waste.
Outer Space Treaty, 1967-83 states
Bans nuclear weapons in earth orbit and their stationing in outer space.
Latin American Nuclear-free Zone Treaty, 1967-22 states
Bans testing, possession, deployment, of nuclear weapons and requires safeguards on facilities. All Latin American states except Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Cuba, are parties to the Treaty.
Non-Proliferation Treaty, 1968-119 states
Bans transfer of weapons or weapons technology to non-nuclear-weapons states. Requires safeguards on their facilities. Commits nuclear-weapon states to negotiations to halt the arms race.
Seabed Treaty, 1971-71 states
Bans nuclear weapons on the seabed beyond a 12-mile coastal limit.
TO REDUCE THE RISK OF NUCLEAR WAR
Hot Line and Modernization Agreements, 1963-US-USSR

Establishes direct radio and wire-telegraph links between Moscow and Washington to ensure communication between Heads of Government in times of crisis. A second agreement in 1971 provided for satellite communication circuits.
Accidents Measures Agreement, 1971-US-USSR
Pledges US and USSR to improve safeguards against accidental or unauthorized use of nuclear weapons.
Prevention of Nuclear War Agreement, 1973-US-USSR
Requires consultation between the two countries if there is a danger of nuclear war.
TO LIMIT NUCLEAR TESTING
Limited Test Ban Treaty, 1963-111 states
Bans nuclear weapons tests in the atmosphere, outer space, or underwater. Bans underground explosions which cause release of radioactive debris beyond the state's borders.

Bans underground tests having a yield above 150 kilotons (150,000 tons of TNT equivalent).
Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty, 1974-US-USSR*
Bans 'group explosions' with aggregate yield over 1,500 kilotons and requires on-site observers of group explosions with yield over 150 kilotons.
TO LIMIT NUCLEAR WEAPONS
ABM Treaty (Salt I) and Protocol, 1972-US-USSR
Limits anti-ballistic missile systems to two deployment areas on each side. Subsequently, in protocol of 1974, each side restricted to one deployment area.

Freezes the number of strategic ballistic missile launchers, and permits an increase in SLBM launchers up to an agreed level only with equivalent dismantling of older ICBM or SLBM launchers.
Salt II, 1979-US-USSR*

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The pressing need for Australia and other world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament.

I commend Senator Ruth Coleman for bringing the subject forward. The principle within the matter of public importance ought to be supported. I believe it is supported by every member of this chamber. We may differ in methodology but I think the goal is clear.

It is a sad fact that this chamber, the chamber in another place, and the Australian community have rarely directed their attention in a detailed and comprehensive fashion to discussing a subject which transcends all other subjects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge Senator McIntosh in this. Let us hope that this initiative is the start of better days for us all. All of us would start off on one premise-that all war is horrendous and barbarous and that it must be outlawed if possible, provided of course that we can, by its outlawing, get peace with dignity and freedom.
—And social justice.

—Justice and freedom, yes, so the goal is common for us all. I would have made only one small but I think significant amendment to the wording. I would have added 'and conventional warfare' because I believe one cannot tackle the subject of nuclear disarmament without also tackling the subject of conventional disarmament. I wonder whether Senator Coleman has read the statement of the present Secretary-General of the United Nations, quoted by our own Ambassador at the United Nations Committee on Disarmament in February of last year. Mr Peres de Cuellar said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . international public opinion wants the two main nuclear countries to start discussing nuclear disarmament. But I insist no less on the necessity of discussing conventional disarmament. I think both problems have to be considered . . .
He went on to say:

I always want to relate together the nuclear arms race to the conventional arms race. It is very easy for some countries to use the nuclear arms race as a kind of smoke screen in order to make us forget that there is the real and more immediate problem of the conventional arms race. At the same time we have to remember that conventional arms are becoming more and more sophisticated. I wonder whether they are not much more of a threat than nuclear arms . . .
I think that is important, and I notice that Senator Coleman acknowledges that point. That was said by our ambassador and he obviously gave Australia's support to it.

The dilemma we face is this: We all agree on the goals, but the methodology is the problem. One of our problems is that I do not believe there is a clear definition of the real facts in this question of nuclear armament and the arms race and, arising from those facts, what should be done. I want to dwell on that . It is important for Australia to participate in discussions in the world scene , to be a good neighbour and to be, if possible, an international mother-in-law helping to resolve problems. But I put as a prior necessity the vital need to uplift this dialogue in Australia, inside this Parliament and out, and to try to get consensus within Australia on the facts, the issues and the methods of getting our goal.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has talked of consensus. I do not cavil at that. If we can bring the Australian people together on any issues, it will be an achievement. On this above all issues, above all industrial issues-after all, we are talking about international industrial strife-let us seek consensus. The first thing I would say is: Let us raise the level and the comprehensive nature of the dialogue in Australia and let us try between ourselves to get the facts.

Today I propose to put down a number of statements which I believe to be true. If they are not, let somebody challenge them so that we can weave our way. Yes, we can do things by discussion. I put down some 10 or 11 matters of immediacy, apart from the one I have just mentioned, the great dialogue in Australia. We can, of course, insist on more debate and more specific debate in the United Nations and its agencies, and that we should do. But we should not leave it only to the experts. We want every ambassador from Australia and every member of our staffs overseas to be ambassadors for disarmament, well-equipped in themselves with facts. Everybody overseas in our Department of Foreign Affairs is there to be good neighbours and to work for constructive peace. We should raise the level of our debate and participation in the Committee on Disarmament. I commend to all honourable senators the reading of the documents on the Committee on Disarmament from which I read a moment ago. They make good reading.

The third point is that we should more actively participate with the International Atomic Energy Agency. As the Minister some years ago, I called upon that agency in Geneva and had discussions. I understand that the Director of the Agency, Dr Blix, is in Australia and will be having discussions. I commend to all the opportunity to have that kind of talk. We do not in this chamber or elsewhere, fully understand the immense political and mechanical problems of the IAEA, including the question of being able to carry out surveillance, to get verification and compliance. These are the very hubs of the issue. My view is that we should, after this more general debate, home in on specifics and on a debate with the IAEA and look at the problems. I would be very interested to upgrade the reports from our representatives at the IAEA so that we can debate the matters here and give that agency some lead to follow.

Along with that, it is important that all in Australia should understand the nature of the Australian Safeguards Office. I think very few do. I was privileged to obtain such an understanding when I was the Minister for National Development and Energy. I believe it is necessary for the Office to be expanded and to undertake more specialist activities and I believe there is a need for it to play an even wider role.

We should continue to increase our research into the disposal of nuclear wastes and the research which I was privileged to start at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission on Synroc and other matters-which I acknowledge the Hawke Government has continued-should be continued because we will do a great service to the world at large if we can find a solution.

I believe-there may be controversy about this-that we should supply uranium and its processed products to the world, but provide it on the most strict conditions. The Government's Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) has made the statement that on balance there is greater safety if we supply material than if other countries with less strict safeguards supply it. I therefore advocate that we supply uranium, and advocate that we should develop uranium enrichment processes because that is another step in the control of this material. I would go to the utmost limits to ensure that our controls of the monitoring and movement of fissionable products are the most intense in the world. I think they are now.
We should work with greater intensity to achieve nuclear test bans. That is one of the great and constructive things we can do in our dialogues.

We can promote regional discussions but above everything, although we are not ready to do this yet, all of us on both sides of the chamber must identify clearly what we want to do. Before we become good neighbours, before we become the interveners, we need to know not only the principles-Senator Coleman has expressed them with great clarity-but also the particularities of the journey. That is the important part of this debate.

I want to venture on to the present scene. I do not want people to believe as a result of the comments I make that I am taking some pro-American and anti- Russian side. I am quite conscious of G. K. Chesterton saying: 'No one should say my country, right or wrong; it is like saying my mother, drunk or sober'.
I want, if I can, to weave my way through this because I want to state some principles and some figures and have them checked. If they are wrong, let us have the correct information.

The first point in this disarmament debate is that a belief, frequently put forward by the media, is that we have a nuclear arms race and that America is leading that race. Unless I am wrong, that is fundamentally incorrect. I put it to the test. As I am advised, since 1960 the United States of America has steadily reduced its warheads and its explosive power. Today, some 8,000 fewer weapons are deployed world wide than there were in 1960 and the megatonnage, the explosive power, is barely one-quarter of what it was 20 years ago. I do not say that in any puritanical sense. I am well aware that as one gets more expert, as one is better able to home in on targets, less megatonnage does the same damage. I merely want to put those figures forward. I am advised that in 1980 the United States unilaterally withdrew 1,000 warheads from Europe. Is this right or is it wrong? The United States says that in fact it is not escalating weapons at all; it is simply making strategic modernisations and is actually reducing weapons. Is that right or wrong? I accept it. The United States says that in the past 20 years it has suffered grave obsolescence and reduction in its weaponry and that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the other of the two most important nuclear nations, has upgraded by way of modernisation and an increase in numbers . It says-let us challenge it if it is wrong-that only 4 per cent of United States warheads are on launchers less than 15 years old. That 4 per cent is in one Trident submarine. It says that 94 per cent of Soviet weapons are on launchers less than five years old. Is that right or wrong? We must get to the facts. Where are the facts? Is this a nuclear arms race or is it something different? How can we evaluate the introduction of Pershing and cruise missiles into Europe unless we know the truth?

I want to get to the truth of this because, as I said at the beginning, it is important to look at conventional arms as well. If we put down our nuclear weapons and one side has an overwhelming advantage in conventional weapons, we will have the same kind of destruction. Perhaps we will not suffer the same magnitude of destruction or the genetic damage but, after all, raids on German cities in the last year of the war did more damage than the bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. No doubt modern conventional weapons, including nerve, germ and other chemical weapons, are equally horrendous. In any case, all it would do would be to put into the hands of one nation the ability to control the world. None of us wants that. I have sought and received agreement from the Government to incorporate in Hansard a series of tables and statements taken from the document entitled 'Soviet Military Power-1983', an official publication of the Defense Department of the United States of America. I seek leave to incorporate that document.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
''SOVIET MILITARY POWER''
Second Edition March 1983
Official Publication of the Department of Defense, United States of America
PREFACE

''There is nothing hypothetical about the Soviet military machine. Its expansion, modernization, and contribution to projection of power beyond Soviet boundaries are obvious. A clear understanding of Soviet Armed Forces, their doctrine, their capabilities, their strengths, and their weaknesses is essential to the shaping and maintenance of effective US and Allied armed forces.''

Those words from Soviet Military Power, published in September 1981, provide a fitting point of departure for this updated second edition. Soviet Military Power 1983 reports on the size, capabilities, and deployment of the Soviet Armed Forces-and documents the improvements and the R & D which are shaping the increased capabilities of the Soviet Strategic Rocket Forces, the Air Defense Forces, the Ground Forces, the Air Forces, and the Navy-forces numbering more than 4.9 million men.
Since late 1981:
The USSR has begun test flights of two new land-based Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles, while continuing modernization of the deployed SS-17, SS-18, and SS-19 ICBM force.
The USSR has begun test flights of a new generation of strategic manned bombers -the BLACKJACK bomber, larger than the US B1.

The USSR has begun test flights of a new generation of ground, sea and air- launched cruise missiles, missiles with nuclear capabilities with ranges in excess of 1,600 kilometers, significantly expanding the flexibility of Soviet strategic options.

The first of the USSR's 25,000-ton TYPHOON-Class strategic ballistic missile submarines has test fired its MIRVed, nuclear-warhead, 8,300-kilometer-range, submarine-launched ballistic missiles. A second TYPHOON has been launched.
Modernization and forward deployment of increasing numbers of Soviet intermediate nuclear forces-land, sea, and air-have proceeded at an unparalleled pace.

More than 330 mobile launchers for the SS-20-a Longer-Range Intermediate-Range Nuclear Force (LRINF) missile with three nuclear warheads and reloads for each launcher-are now arrayed against Western Europe, the Middle East, parts of Africa, and most of Asia, including China and Japan.

Su-24 FENCER ground-attack aircraft have been forward-deployed to nations of Eastern Europe and to border bases in Asia, extending the combat radius of these new nuclear-capable aircraft to include Japan and most of NATO Europe.

The USSR has introduced additional nuclear-capable weapons systems to its forward-deployed division in Eastern Europe. The new SS-21 mobile, short-range ballistic missile system is operational in Eastern Europe as is the 152-mm self- propelled gun, adding to Soviet conventional, chemical, and nuclear war-fighting options.

The USSR's T-80 main battle tank, in development in 1981, is in the field with Soviet Tank Division in both the USSR and Eastern Europe, adding to the extended combat capabilities of the more than 190 Soviet ground force divisions.

In 1981, two Soviet KIEV-Class aircraft carriers were operational. Now, three units are on the high seas; a fourth unit has been launched; and development continues on a newer, larger class of aircraft carriers.

In shipyards on the Baltic and Black Seas, series production continues on four new classes of surface warships-a new generation of nuclear and conventionally powered Soviet cruisers and guided missile destroyers enhancing the Soviet Navy' s air defense, antisubmarine warfare, and cruise-missile, surface-strike capabilities.

Five Soviet shipyards have continued to produce new attack submarines for the world's largest submarine force. In 1980, the first of the new, extremely large OSCAR Class guided missile submarines was launched, a submarine capable of firing up to 24 long-range antiship cruise missiles while submerged. That lead unit is now on sea trials, and a second unit has been launched.
The USSR's military related space program has grown in manned missions, more reconnaissance surveillance targeting satellites and antisatellite space systems .
The USSR's combat operations have continued to expand in Afghanistan, and now involve more than 105,000 Soviet troops with some of the newest Soviet weapons.

From Indochina to the Caribbean, the USSR has continued to expand its global military presence. To cite just one example, a Soviet Navy task force operated in the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico from November 1982 to February 1983.

Expansion of the USSR technology and industrial production base has matched the growth and deployment of its armed forces, reflecting a top priority investment in defense production aided by continuing acquistion of Western technology.

Despite economic difficulties the USSR allocates an estimated 15 percent of GNP to its military buildup, an increase from the 12-to-14 percent reported in 1981, which in turn represents a continuance of the trend of the last 21 years.

To place this modernization and growth of the USSR's Armed Forces in perspective, Soviet Military Power 1983 includes substantial data on US and Allied forces enhancement as well as some comparative US-USSR and NATO-Warsaw Pact tables. Comprehensive information on US forces, of course, is regularly made available to the public in such publications as the Secretary of Defense's Annual Report and the Military Posture Statement of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Ours is a free society; the Soviet Union is not. The updated facts presented in this report leave no doubt as to the USSR's dedication to achieving military superiority in all fields.

It is our duty to have a full awareness of Soviet military growth, modernization and capabilities and to shape our defense forces and our deterrent capabilities accordingly. We can do no less if we are to provide fully and wisely for our security, and that of our Allies. Ours is a formidable task, made more difficult by a decade of our neglect coupled with two decades of massive Soviet increases. But, we and our Allies can accomplish the task if we have the will, the courage, and the resolution possessed in ample measure by our predecessors who won our freedom, and who have kept it for us all. This is at once our most precious heritage and our most solemn responsibility to prosterity .
Caspar W. Weinberger March 1983 Secretary of Defense

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is true that the United States has downgraded its position and is now simply modernising its weapons, what again are the facts ?

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, in 1981 the United States sought a reduction in intermediate weaponry-in fact, it wanted to wipe them out-but did not get far because the Soviet Union would not go ahead. Indeed, it sought to have a progressive reduction but it did not get far. It wanted to wipe them out so that there could be a balance between the countries. The Soviet Union has said that it will not enter into these discussion unless, when all weaponry is taken into account, its weaponry shall be equal to all other weaponry outside the Iron Curtain, that is, including the weaponry of Britain and France. I raise this matter again for consideration by the Government. I have seen it said as well as I can state it in these words:

The Soviet position amounts to a claim that they be permitted to maintain nuclear forces equivalent to those of all other potential adversaries added together; in effect, that they must be stronger than any other single power, and equal to all of them combined. Furthermore, it implies that, in matters of nuclear weapons, the Soviets can dismiss the national interests of individual European nations by lumping their military forces together without distinction. This view violates the basic principle of equality in U.S.-Soviet arms control agreements, and is a reversal of the earlier Soviet position in the first and second strategic arms limitations talks (SALT I and II), when the Soviets acknowledged that British and French missiles were strategic systems.
The British and French governments, moreover, have categorically rejected any consideration of their nuclear deterrent forces in the INF negotiations.

I ask again: Is this right or is it wrong? Who is right and wrong in the present discussions on the Pershing II and cruise missiles? As I am advised, unless there are such missiles in Western Europe, and staked in Western Europe, Russia has breached the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks agreements by changing SS4 and SS5 weapons into SS20 weapons and thus completely altering the balance. The SALT talks provided that the intercontinental ballistic missiles which were to be weapons of a capacity of 5,500 kilometres should be limited in number, that a ceiling should be put on them. As I understand it, the Russians took their SS4s and SS5s and put multiple MIRV warheads on them-that is, multiple independent re -entry vehicles-which included three warheads. This gave them a range of 5,000 kilometres so that they can get inside Europe. I am advised that the situation at the moment is that Russia has the capacity to penetrate any part of Western Europe whereas Western Europe is powerless to retaliate. Is that true? If it is true, quite clearly what the Americans and NATO are seeking at this moment is to be supported.

The picture is as I have described it. The Warsaw powers have conventional weaponry, armaments, men and materials which, as shown in the document which the Senate has agreed to have incorporated in Hansard, vastly outnumber those of the NATO forces. So simply to put down the nuclear shield will not get us peace.

As I understand it, the question at the moment is not one of escalation but of modernisation. Let us get the facts. Let us get a dialogue going in Australia-in the Senate and elsewhere. When we have the facts we can go out and preach. Sadly I say to honourable senators that, except by my own searching, the facts have not appeared clearly.

I invite the Government to give us a White Paper on this matter. Let us have a White Paper that we can worry out and debate in this chamber. Let us get the facts and take the dialogue to the community in the streets, in the halls and in the media. When we do and we get the feedback from the people-that is what we need because we represent them here-we will be in a position to go abroad. I have set out 10 or 11 ways in which we can do this on the international scene. I am a passionate advocate of peace with dignity and freedom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance introduced by Senator Coleman is about the pressing need for Australia and other world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament. Usually when I follow Senator Sir John Carrick in a debate I find myself bouncing into him because he always very eloquently and strongly puts the view of the Liberal Party of Australia. However, on this occasion I agree with him. I certainly do not agree with all the things that he said, but I agree with the thrust of his contribution, which was that we must uplift the dialogue on this most important matter. When he speaks of his abhorrence of war he speaks from his experience of the difficulties and horror that war means.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party is unique in that it set out in its platform its basic principles and objectives, which include the maintenance of world peace, an independent position in world affairs, the recognition of the right of all nations to self-determination and independence, and regional and international agreements for arms control and disarmament. We go on, in our platform, to adopt principles of action in a co-operative process that involves constitutional action through the Australian and State governments and, in addition, call for ongoing action organised community groups, including trade unions and local government bodies. So it is fundamental to us that we be involved in, as Senator Coleman said, the constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament. That means that we should participate in this Parliament, in the international forums and, most important of all, in community discussions. I believe that part of the success achieved in trying to turn round the nuclear arms race is due to being able to involve the community. I am fortified by a current publication entitled The Forgotton Treaties, which was written by Allan McKnight and has an introduction by Dr Keith Suter. There is a reference at page 16 of this book to the late Lord Noel-Baker who, in referring to the period 1932-33, but highlighting the importance of the participation of a community movement in disarmament negotiations, said:

The Conferences and Commissions have proved that all the technical problems of Disarmament have been solved; that the further Disarmament were taken, the more swiftly and completely would the difficulties disappear. The only problem that remains unsolved is that of creating the popular support that will enable-or compel-the statesmen to see it through.

That was absolutely true in 1932-33 and it is absolutely true today. I have the privilege of being involved in the anti-nuclear movement in this country. I certainly agree with Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks when he said that it is a more important issue by far that we face today. Indeed, it is the major priority of today. It is a major priority of the Labor Government.

I refer briefly to some of the improvements and initiatives taken by the Labor Government in its first 12 months, not the least of which was the appointment of Richard Butler as Ambassador for Disarmament to upgrade the whole area. Australia's major initiative in the nuclear field in the last six months has been the promotion of a new approach to the objective of having negotiations started on a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. Our policy is that there should be such a treaty open for universal signature banning all nuclear testing by all states in all environments for all time and fully verifiable. The resolution to this effect which we put before the General Assembly of the United Nations in December was adopted by a vote of 117 for, none against and 29 abstentions. Three other countries which were absent for the vote stated that, had they been present, they would have voted for the resolution. Clearly that was a significant result. No other such resolution has attracted no negative votes. It is more of a truism to say that perhaps none of this would be necessary if human beings had been properly educated in regard to the virtues of peace rather than in the heroics of war and conflict. I shall refer in detail later to the massive community self-education program that is part of the anti- nuclear movement in Australia at this time. Ambassador Butler said:

What is fascinating, and encouraging to me, is that talk about education for peace was seen only a dozen years ago as ephemeral and peripheral to main concerns. Today very many teachers and citizens see it as a central if not vital concern.
He went on to say:
I am delighted that good progress is also being made towards the establishment of the Peace Research Institute which is a part of Federal Government policy.

The architect of so much of the Labor Government's initiative is the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden, who emphasised at the United Nations when he spoke there on 4 October the high priority that we give to arms control and disarmament. He said:
We must re-commit ourselves to the maintenance of peace at the lowest possible level of armaments and to disarmament as one of mankind's highest practical goals.

The need for that is urgent and it is what the people of the world are telling us. That is what this matter of public importance emphasises. People will not accept that the system is out of control. One of the problems that we face in the world today is that people will not accept the arms race mentality. The Australian Labor Government is committed to the arms control and disarmament goals of the United Nations, both as enshrined in the charter and in the substantial fabric of the international law that has been developed since the United Nations organisation came into existence.

Australia is determined that there be an end to the nuclear arms race and a reduction in the number and kind of nuclear weapons held by nuclear weapons states. The Australian Labor Party is determined that the Treaty on the Non- Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons be strengthened and adhered to universally. Linking those two objectives, we are determined that there should be an end to nuclear testing in all environments for all time. To achieve some of those objectives the Government has doubled the resources available in Canberra to allow work to be undertaken on these issues, to allow study to be undertaken, to advise on arms control and disarmament measures and the policies required to maintain peace. Senator Sir John Carrick said that he would like to see a White Paper. I am sure that type of thing will be the inevitable product of a beefing up of the activity in these areas.

We will establish an independent peace research institute and examine the integration of peace studies into school curricula, which is one of the great weaknesses we have had in this country up until now, so that young people might be able to see both sides of the argument that is taking place in the world. In the Pacific we have opened up debate with our partners and neighbours on the possibility of establishing a nuclear-free zone in the South Pacific.

As I said earlier, I believe that the strength and the movement for nuclear disarmament will be finally resolved by the peoples themselves. In Australia there is a tremendous movement in every State. I am proud to say that I am the convenor of a rally and march that will take place commencing in Hyde Park south in Sydney on 15 April. It will go to the Sydney Domain. We have held two similar rallies. Last year 60,000 Australian citizens attended a rally to demonstrate their concern. I invite honourable senators to consider the growth of this movement. In 1981, 100,000 people marched throughout Australia and last year 200 ,000 people marched. I am sure we will exceed that number this year. At our first rally in Sydney novelist Patrick White was the principal speaker. Last year David Williamson spoke. This year Dr Helen Caldicott, a leading Australian who has lived in America for some time and who has been particularly active in the American movement of Physicians Against Nuclear War, will attend the rally.

I suggest the movement is one of the most democratic movements in which it is possible to be involved. It is a very pleasing experience. It shows that people can co-operate, even though they do not agree on many other issues. They march in a rally and carry their own slogans. Therefore, they are able to treat the subject just as we probably treat it in the chamber, that is, in different ways. Those people are led by Ministers of state, parliamentarians and community and church leaders. The participation is quite diverse. It includes Aboriginals, women's organisations, students, peace and disarmament organisations, environmental groups, churches, trade unions, professional groups such as doctors, scientists and lawyers, ethnic organisations, community organisations, solidarity groups, public officeholders, members of parliament, aldermen and shire councillors and political and other groups. One can appreciate why the people in Sydney on 15 April will feel the solidarity, the feeling of strength which one gets when one realises that thousands of people share that concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every capital city.

—I was giving my own State a plug. These rallies will take place in every State. In the nuclear disarmament movement in Sydney-it is the only one to which I will have time to refer-we have an educational program which I have referred to earlier. I emphasise that in 12 months thousands of people have undertaken what I would call self-education programs. We sell a system whereby four cassettes from the lectures address the problems to which Senator Sir John Carrick has referred. This means that people can study at their leisure the issues that are involved. That is what we must work on. If we do not allow people to consider the facts and if we cannot force them into facing the problems, we will fail.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that we as politicians must realise that the peace and disarmament movement affects the way people vote. I also acknowledge that most of us here are members of the all-party Parliamentary Disarmament Group. That, I think, is an acknowledgement of the great concern we all have. I suggest that the sheer size of the membership of disarmament organisations gives the lie to the view that is often perpetuated in the Press that it is just a fringe group of fanatics which is involved. The truth of the matter is that there has been a tremendous development in this area. From my experience in New South Wales in the last 12 months, I can say that the nuclear disarmament groups have increased by 30 to 40 per cent. Whereas we had 12 regional or community areas represented 12 months ago, there are now between 60 and 70 in existence in New South Wales at this moment.

Time does not permit me to go into all the areas, but when we look at the multi -cultural nature of our community we find that so many people who are concerned with the threat that exists in Europe at present have added their weight because they know that despite what might happen in Australia there is a real threat to the people in Europe of an accident or war occurring based on the dangerous situation that exists there at present. I urge people to take action. We in the Labor Party believe that people should participate within Parliament but they should go to the ultimate democracy and march with their fellow citizens in the streets. In that way they can show the community that both the people holding the highest posts in the land and those holding the lowest positions in the land might unite together on such an occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The pressing need for Australia and other world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament.

This is a bipartisan debate, as of course it should be. We are not talking about the run of the mill political issues. We are talking about the future of civilisation. In February of last year Andrei Sakharov said:

It should be said that all out nuclear war would mean the destruction of contemporary civilisation, hurl man back centuries, cause the deaths of hundreds of millions or billions of people, or, with a certain degree of probability, would cause man to be destroyed as a biological species and could even cause the annihilation of life on earth.

The nuclear arms race is the most emotive level, because of its potentially catastrophic consequences, of the wider subject of the total arms race. The cost of that arms race to civilisation, particularly the poor, is enormous. I reflect upon my observations in the Horn of Africa. Mr Acting Deputy President, my observations will be known to you as you were with me on an occasion. We learnt that one third of the budget of some of the poorest countries on earth was spent on armaments and defence. How much better off they would be if an alternative method of conflict resolution, a peaceful method, could be found. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute estimates that world military spending for 1982 was between $700 billion and $750 billion. More dramatic, I think, is the effect upon the third world and poor countries. I refer to a figure in a speech made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in Adelaide in his Evatt memorial lecture last year. He said that roughly 75 per cent of the global trade in conventional arms in the 1970s consisted of deliveries to the third world. That is a most depressing figure. To put the position in perspective, he said:
The current expenditure on arms for one year would pay off all the debt of developing countries, which is threatening the fabric of the world financial system.
I remind the Senate of what was said in the final communique of the first Special Session on Disarmament at the United Nations. It was said:

The economic social consequences of the arms race are so detrimental that its continuation is obviously incompatible with the implementation of the new international economic order based on justice, equity and co-operation.

So, the cost in diverted resources is enormous. Perhaps that cost could be justified if it were making for a safer world. The Stockholm Institute, which monitors the number of wars, as broadly defined, from the end of the Second World War to 1980, has recorded 133 separate conflicts at a cost of tens of millions of lives. What is now clear to the United Nations and accepted by Australia is that the acquisition of weapons has led inevitably to an arms race which threatens the very security that the acquisition of arms was designed to protect. The legitimate security objectives of states is not in question. The question is: How best to provide that security? It is clear that the answer does not lie in an arms race competition. That was well expressed by Richard Butler, who now has the position of Australian Ambassador for Disarmament, in his speech at the commencement of this year's Committee on Disarmament in Geneva, a speech that was given on 14 February. He said:

Another matter of concern to my Government is the extent to which the notion of not 'peaceful' but desperate competition has come to underlie and fuel the arms race. The implication of competition in arms is not that there can be a winner. We all know that in the nuclear age there are no winners, only losers. Competition in arms does not ensure security. It ensures escalation, massive and increasingly draining expenditures, and growing dangers.

If the arms race is not to give the world the security to which it is entitled, where does the answer lie? I submit that it lies in a new order of international relations which would have as its centre the maintenance of peace and security through international co-operation. They should be familiar words to this Senate , because it was a desire in those terms which led to the formation of the United Nations. Nevertheless, it has largely failed to work, and it has failed largely because there has not been sufficient determination to make it work. Security through disarmament rather than the conventional thought of security simply through armament is a challenge which the world community must face. It requires us again to look at the causes of conflict, the institutional framework we have developed to allow a diplomatic alternative to conflict resolution, the reasons for the lack of faith in the institutions that have been so developed and all of the many related questions.

The subject we have before us today specifically is to look at the role Australia should play. I want to look at that question in the context, firstly, of the bilateral and multilateral negotiations that have been taking place; secondly, the subject of collective security; and thirdly, our role in contributing to overcoming the pre-conditions to destabilisation. In regard to bilateral and multilateral negotiations, it is not widely recognised that Australia has taken a prominent, and on occasions leading, role in the multilateral disarmament process which has been taking place under the auspices of the United Nations through the General Assembly, particularly the two special sessions on disarmament, and the work in Geneva of the negotiating Committee on Disarmament.

I have spoken before in this place on the role we have played in the Committee on Disarmament. I was privileged to attend the last session on disarmament in New York and to witness the prominent role we played at that conference of the United Nations Second Special Session on Disarmament. I reported to this Senate after that event. Unfortunately, in multilateral talks progress has been disappointingly, and to many states frustratingly, slow. Many reasons are suggested for this. I take this opportunity to suggest two. The first is the continual reference to the international climate not being conducive to constructive progress in disarmament negotiations. The United Nations General Assembly President, Ismail T. Kattini of Iraq, put the failures of UNSSOD II in perspective when he recognised that it would be an illusion to expect the United Nations to insulate itself from the general climate and relations among states- where mistrust, conflict, a growing sense of insecurity and the resort to force continued to prevail-and to produce miracles. Australia must not adopt this explanation as accepting the inevitability of little progress. Again I refer to the speech of Andrei Sakharov:

I am convinced that nuclear disarmament talks are of enormous importance and of the highest priority. They must be conducted continuously-in the brighter periods of international relations but also in the periods when relations are strained-and conducted with persistence, foresight, firmness and, at the same time, with flexibility and initiative.

The second reason I wish to suggest to the Senate for the failure of multilateral talks is that there is a tendency to accept that such talks should play a subservient role to negotiations between the super-powers. Throughout UNSSOD II there was a clear impression, certainly in my mind, of acceptance that the real decisions had to be made by the super-powers. That certainly appeared to be the attitude of the super-powers and, as a result, little in practice has been achieved in the Committee on Disarmament where, fortunately, the total world community has had the opportunity of representation in those multilateral negotiations.

The right to be involved in efforts to reverse the nuclear arms race must not be limited to the possessors of those weapons. I suggest that we all have a right to be involved. We occupy an integral role in the American nuclear deterrence. We have, therefore, a direct involvement and we should have views and attitudes that we should press upon our allies. In fact, accepting as I do that there will be no limited nuclear exchange, all the world community has a right, and I believe a responsibility, to press their views upon the principal players.

There is an interrelationship between the multilateral and the bilateral talks. Australia has been a leading proponent for a treaty to ban all nuclear tests in all environments. Such a treaty would limit proliferation horizontally, in that non-nuclear states would be unable to test weapons, and would limit it vertically, in that nuclear states would have difficulty in improving the quality of their warheads. In particular, we have recognised that such a treaty would not come about without adequate methods of verification and compliance, and we have been contributing to that challenge through the development of different methods of seismic verification. Unfortunately, when the United States finally indicated to the Committee on Disarmament that it was prepared to join a working group, China and France immediately announced that they would not take part, since in their view the two major nuclear powers, the United States and the Soviet Union, should make substantial reductions in their nuclear arsenals before other states should be required to adhere to a nuclear test ban treaty. I think that shows the interrelationship between multilateral and bilateral talks.

Similarly, Australia has been a strong supporter of the non-proliferation treaty. If I had time, I could give examples again of the interrelationship between multilateral and bilateral negotiations in that regard and where frustrations have occurred. If I may say also, our good relationships with our super-power allies may well be important if the two multilateral negotiating projects, one of which has made considerable progress in recent years and the other at its infancy, are to be kept on the rails. I refer to the treaty to prohibit development, production and stockpiling of chemical weapons and, secondly, that for the prevention of an arms race in outer space.

The second subject I want to mention, which is close to the hearts of all of us with faith in the United Nations system as an alternative to the ever escalating arms race, is collective security. Governments cannot and do not hazard their security. They will not disarm or even slow down their ability to arm their neighbours without substantial assurance that no harm to their interests will result. Andrei Sakharov has said that genuine security is possible only when based on stabilisation of international relations, a repudiation of expansionist policies, the strengthening of international trust, openness and pluralisation of the socialist societies, the observance of human rights throughout the world, a rapprochement or convergence of the socialist and capitalist systems and world -wide co-ordinate efforts to solve global problems. They may be prerequisites for genuine security but, if that is so, genuine security is a long way off. In the meantime a more effective method of collective security may provide a basis for slowing and reversing the arms race.

In the very limited time we have, I wish to refer to the report by the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues, the Palme report, and the comments of the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth in this city late last year when he advocated a strengthening of the UN security system by a return to the concept of collective security, at least initially in the Third World, with a structure of collective peacekeeping, involving fact finding sessions, military observer teams and military collective security forces. This is an area in which Australia has made a significant contribution in the past and has a record upon which we can build.

The third and final aspect that I have time to touch upon in looking at the contribution Australia can make in providing greater security is the role it can play in contributing to overcome the root causes of destablisation in the world, for example the contribution we can make to overcome starvation and poverty; in other words, our contribution to overcome the North-South dichotomy, our obligation not to refuse to supply our natural resource wealth on reasonable terms and conditions to the benefit of those less fortunate states; and our responsibility to contribute diplomatically to overcome regional disputes before they escalate into armed conflict. The list is really endless. We have made practical contributions in the past upon which we can build in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several basic points to consider in the matter which we have before us. The first is that the need for international nuclear disarmament is indeed a most urgent one. It is a matter which has been debated in many world councils and, I gather, many chambers like our own for many years, without apparent success. We must recognise that this cannot continue. If it does, the events will overtake the discussions and that is the basic point of fundamental importance. It is a matter of concern. As one reads through quite responsible scientific journals and others, one sees that over the last six or seven months there has been a growing number of articles by very responsible people expressing concern at the growing risks of nuclear conflict. The risks are not seen as diminishing but rather, in the last six months to a year, as increasing at an alarming rate. Just this morning I was looking at a publication in which it was said that the world was now at the greatest risk it has ever been in its history.

SPEECH.PARA: The second major point is that the five nuclear powers will not voluntarily give up the use of nuclear weapons. Somehow they must be persuaded, compelled or argued into doing it. The third point, which is concomitant with that second point, is that nuclear disarmament can hardly be unilateral under those circumstances. It has to be something carried out by all five nuclear powers. So in a sense we must come to the point that the five nuclear powers and the rest of the world are indeed opponents because the five nuclear powers, by persisting with nuclear armaments and the escalation of nuclear armaments-all of them are doing it-are placing the rest of the world, which does not have nuclear armaments, at risk. Therefore, in the most fundamental and serious sense the nuclear powers are as such the opponents, even the enemies, one might say, of the rest of the world. I do not think they recognise themselves as such. They see themselves as protectors of their zonal areas and somehow as conferring protection or some sort of benefit on people in the rest of the world. The point has to be made very strongly to them that they are not doing that. The result is completely the opposite.

There is a pressing need for Australia and other world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament. In other words, we are one of those countries on the sticky end of the situaton. We cannot contribute to a nuclear war but we would suffer if one ever happens. It is the representatives of the smaller countries who probably will have to face up to and solve the appalling problem of nuclear war. So Australia is directly involved, or ought to be.

Clearly, multilateral disarmament talks are vitally necessary and these must be aimed, firstly, at a nuclear freeze and no more nuclear weapons and, secondly, at a comprehensive test ban treaty-no more testing of nuclear weapons. In recent months a disquieting tendency has emerged towards satellite weapons and space weapons. There is a need for the world to have some sort of early agreement or pact that those weapons will not be researched, built or used. If they ever come into use the situation will obtain in which the world will be in grave danger because of the impossibility of controlling weapons in space. Warning times will go down. The degree of automation and technical control of those weapons will increase and the human factor will diminish. To the extent it will become an impossible dangerous situation, most amenable to accident and to disaster and not at all amenable to patching up or preventing a disaster if indeed there is some kind of accident or some flaw even in a communications system.

This has been brought home to many millions, possibly billions, of human beings recently by films which very properly have explored that area of the subject. It is partly because of that that this whole issue of disarmament has now become a major one in every country. It will become increasingly so in Australia. Not surprisingly is this the case, because at this moment as we debate this subject in the Senate about 47,000 nuclear bombs are stockpiled throughout the world in one place or another. As it would take only 2,000 at the most to destroy totally all human life on earth, the other 45,000 appear to be rather excessive, to say the least. Many are obsolete weapons or inefficient because of their age. The demolition and disposal of the materials alone in those weapons presents a major problem for the world which has not been solved and which will become an even greater problem as time goes on. We will have littering the world increasing numbers of aging atomic weapons, possibly which are becoming technically faulty, which at any stage might cause some horrendous accident somewhere, and there is no real attempt apparently to dispose of them.

One might ask: What is the use of the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics each having the capability to destroy the world 10 times over? The imagination boggles at this point. In one of my favourite Patrick Cook cartoons one sees a general explaining to someone that the last nine total destructions are just for fun. It is that sort of sardonic view that most human beings turn to for some sense of relief from the intolerable situation which now obtains.

If two enemies have enough bombs to destroy each other they are said to have what our Government calls mutually stable deterrents. What does that mean? When the Americans developed nuclear weapons in the 1950s they held a massive advantage over the Soviets-so massive that they could credibly threaten the Soviets with nuclear devastation if they stepped out of line. In other words, at that stage one could see that nuclear weapons were an instrument of policy for the United States-a powerful if perhaps not too moral deterrent. But it could only work and be credible while one side held all the cards. Once the Soviets obtained the capability to devastate American cities in return, which capability they had by the 1960s, the deterrent had lost its impact and its credibility, and has done so ever since. Any talk, any rhetoric about there being any mutual deterrence is absolute nonsense, and has been over the past 20 years.

Nuclear warfare cannot advance any national policies. Therefore, nuclear weapons are not weapons in the traditional sense of the word. They are not weapons of war because they cannot advance the policies of any individual country no matter how many weapons that country may have.

Which United States President would threaten to obliterate Moscow if the Soviets did not withdraw from Afghanistan knowing that the Soviets could take New York off the map? From that time I think this became known as the real politics of the world. No President would ever do that again. This dilemma led to a change in United States nuclear thinking. The label 'deterrence' remained for public consumption but the action, of course, became different. Targets became military bases and one's opponent's weapons and one's own weapons were to become smaller and more accurate. The purpose of this change, which is known as flexible response, was to demonstrate to one's enemy that one's deterrent was credible because one was prepared to use it. This is the central unanswerable paradox of deterrence in the 1980s. The plan is to deter war by planning for and being equipped for war, and by war in this sense I mean nuclear war. So, while the public's concept of deterrence remains one of a defensive nature, the military one has changed it into a policy of trying to use nuclear weapons in a controlled way and developing first strike weapons, of saying: 'If we can get in soon enough and fast enough against the other side we may get in enough weapons to intimidate them, cow them, win the war and not be hit back'. That, in point of fact, is utter madness.

There is a need for international extension of the concept of the rule of law. That should not be all that difficult or impossible to achieve. When one looks back through history to the city states and the gradual evolution of the human race one sees a gradual increase in the size of political units. Within political units, of course, there is rule of law. The people in Madrid do not think it is ever likely that somebody in Barcelona will drop a nuclear bomb on them, but it is conceivable that somebody in Paris or Rome might. There is not a great deal of difference between those cities or the people who live in them. It is really a matter of extending the rule of law, which has been accepted within the nation states for lengthy periods-for centuries. I might say that this has been done with increasing competence because of modern communications.

Europe of the Middle Ages would have regarded the modern nation states as an impossibility. It would have said that having such a political unit is obviously crazy. If one had gone to the people of Europe then and said that one could have a world like that they would not have believed it. Now we have reached the stage where there are virtually two nation states of the world-the two super-powers with those who are, as it were, dependent on them. So here we have a last bridge to cross. It must seem to us that it is the most difficult of all bridges to cross, but that may not necessarily be the case. We may only be in the position of those people who lived in the Middle Ages who could not foresee the modern nation state, much less the super-power. Perhaps if we look at that bridge carefully we will find that there is a crossing for it and that the crossing of it is something on which the whole future of the human race depends.

Finally, I turn to another point which Senator Coleman touched on. I think this point is of such importance in debating the matter in Australia that it is worth taking it a little further. I refer to the question of whether Australia is safe from the consequences of a Northern Hemisphere-based nuclear war.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Indeed, that is so. But it has been said for many decades that we are. I think it is a very gross misinforming of our people to say that.
—Nobody is.

—I do not think anybody is saying it now, Senator Teague, although there are still people who believe it. I have discussed this matter with people and they have said: 'There could be a terrible nuclear catastrophe in the north but we are not going to get it here'. The latest scientific research shows that no part of the the world is safe from the effects of nuclear war.

SPEECH.PARA: The research into the nuclear winter shows a global climatic catastrophe will result from a nuclear war and that climatic catastrophe will affect the Northern and Southern Hemispheres alike. According to a recent copy of Science, which is published by the United States Society for the Advancement of Science, even a relatively limited conflict in the Northern Hemisphere would break down those barriers at the Equator which prevent a mixing of the winds to the extent that, indeed, there would be a leakage through to the Southern Hemisphere of nuclear contamination. This would happen quite quickly. It would not be a matter of decades or centuries. It could happen all of a sudden as the huge and unstable cloud masses building up in the Northern Hemisphere disturbed the equatorial balance completely.

But in the worst case possible, in an all-out nuclear war using a considerable number of the stockpiled bombs-I think we must anticipate that as a possibility because of the delicate nature of the control of these weapons-the latest research shows that up to one billion people from the world's population would die immediately, up to one billion people would suffer immediate and serious injury and many would die subsequently from radiation sickness and from the sheer dislocation of society. The ozone layer would be largely destroyed, increasing the amount of ultraviolet light on to the surface of the planet by several hundred per cent, which would be a major catastrophe in itself even if there were no other consequences. The atmosphere would be clogged with obscuring smoke, dust and radioactive debris. Daytime light levels would become, for a considerable time, twilight gloom or worse. This would happen every day all over the world. Temperatures would fall some 30 to 40 degrees. These levels of sub- zero temperature are likely to last for at least some months. I think it is axiomatic that very little that is growing on the earth-certainly annual crops, which most of our food crops are-is likely to survive that. So, even if we could survive the other things, there would be no food left in the world and no food crops before that nuclear winter had ended.

These effects would not be limited to the Northern Hemisphere. In some 10 to 20 days, according to the best estimates I can find, the enveloping cloud would cover the Southern Hemisphere. Comparatively small nuclear war can result in climatic consequences which are just as bad. The detonation of 500 to 2,000 high yield bombs-that is only one per cent to 4 per cent of the world's stockpile- could be sufficient. It is obvious, then, that the use of nuclear weapons, even if it could be done on a successful first-strike basis, would be an act of national suicide. It would be more than that. As a study by Dr Paul Ehrlich demonstrated:
It is clear that the ecosystem effects alone resulting from large scale thermo- nuclear war could be enough to destroy the current civilisation in at least the Northern Hemisphere.
Since he said that, of course, the Southern Hemisphere has become involved.
I conclude with the words of United States Senators Kennedy and Hatfield when they held the joint American-Soviet scientific forum on nuclear war and its consequences:

What is the conclusion? I think the conclusion is very simple. The nuclear device is not at all the weapon which will serve any military purpose. It is not the weapon which it is possible to use with any policy. It is just the weapon of suicide.
I would add to that: The suicide is not individual; it is not even national; it is global.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All war is destructive. War is about death and dying. War is entirely tragic, fruitless and futile. Nuclear war is utter madness. Debate on the threat of nuclear holocaust is so current in the world, not least Australia, that we are right in saying in this Parliament that such a matter is of primary importance. Yet there have been only two such debates in the six years in which I have been a member of the Senate. As Senator Coleman and Senator Sir John Carrick said, we should go on from this general debate calling for disarmament to the specifics of the debate. I believe we would be assisted by having a White Paper on the subject. The responsibility of initiating and helping Australia in this way always falls on the government in office. We are asked why we did not take that initiative ourselves when we were in government for seven years. Whatever the past may have been, let us go on from this general debate in which the voices are all leading in the same direction to the specifics, including those that honourable senators who have spoken in this debate have raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only do we have to face the threat of a nuclear holocaust that could result from a deliberate war, a war in which there would be no winner, but also we have to consider the other horror of an accident occurring. Many writers and many distressed persons of various nationalities have put before us the scenario of an accident occurring and the beauty and complexity of the world as well as its culture and history and the personal lives of grandmothers, babies and families of every nation being turned into an ash heap. I have in mind the singing of Simon and Garfunkel that so attracted me as an aspect of protest when I visited the United States of America in 1969. I think also of a film I saw in China on this topic when I visited that country; or of my discussions with people-in the Soviet Union-bona fide, genuine discussions to try to see how the world can come to peace; or the discussions I had in the United Kingdom where I was a student for several years; or in France. There is a world awareness-whichever country one has in mind, regardless of the language spoken-of the threat of nuclear holocaust. This Parliament has among its highest priorities the security of this nation and of the Australian people and the need to make a contribution to the security of the world.

The matter of public importance before the Senate relates to the pressing need for Australia and other world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament. Australia is a nation of 15 million people and I believe we have a significant influence in the world. We are not powerless ; we have special relationships with our near neighbours in the Pacific and in the Association of South East Asian Nations and, through them, with the non- aligned, disadvantaged and smaller nations of the world. Furthermore, Australia is an essential part of the Commonwealth. We have a special relationship with the United States, one of the super-powers. We conduct major trade with Japan and China. We have a heritage that flows to us from the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe. We have links of importance with all those parts of the world. Let us not despair and take the view that Australia cannot talk, think about and reach conclusions on this matter. Australia can make a significant contribution. Whether Australia will rise to the challenge of being a mediator between the super-powers is yet to be seen, but we should seek to be a part of the mediation that will lead to genuine disarmament in the world.

The Australian people are reflective about values. Australia has the fortune of being affluent in what is sometimes called the post-industrial era. Questions relating to the quality of life are of real importance to the Australian people, as is clear from statements by all political parties. The people of Australia, including the young people, particularly women, are well aware of the questions of life issues involved in the subject of disarmament. I refer to youth because one constantly hears the most dramatic responses expressed by young people at the overwhelming threat of holocaust. I must say empirically that it is women who raise this subject most frequently with me, but there are many men, including myself, who feel these matters keenly. Parliament needs to respond to that feeling. I mention these aspects because Australia is in a significant position, in its affluence, to go beyond bread and butter debates to consider this complex and high priority matter.

The Parliamentary Disarmament Group was formed only last year. I am proud and claim it as a privilege to be with Senator Coleman, Senator Mason and Senator Boswell, representing each of the four parties, as co-convenors of the Disarmament Group. But we have not yet got very far. We have gained encouragement from the Australian people, but have yet to get on to an action agenda which will express in specifics the constructive discussions for which we are calling today. That is not new. We are saying that we have a long way to go, but will press on towards that goal.

As the representative of the Liberal Party in this respect, I must acknowledge that I received personal encouragement from Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition, from Senator Sir John Carrick, very specifically from Mr Peacock, from the Opposition Foreign Affairs spokesman in the other place, Mr MacKellar, and other honourable members such as Ian Macphee.

I wish to turn to a number of controversial questions that arise under this topic. One is the issue of peace-an all-embracing, large word that includes many concepts. Throughout the last centuries there have been minority groups in all countries whose members have described themselves conscientiously as pacificists . When I was a student, I contemplated the philosophical foundations of pacifism , and I am aware that one or 2 per cent of the Australian people are conscientiously pacifist. I applaud them for their personal values. However, although I seek to be a Christian and to be challenged by Jesus's encouragement to turn the other cheek when struck, I am not led to be a pacifist. I always want to see in Australia the ability for conscientious objection to participation in war or any kind of fighting and I would even allow conscientious objection to particular wars. However, I am not myself a pacifist.

Similarly there is a small group that will seek unilateral disarmament. Some of the philosophical foundations of that movement are similar to those in pacifism. The argument is: 'Let us be the first. We will disarm, get rid of all our bombs, especially nuclear, as well as all our guns and armies'. The view is that that example will then be followed by others in the world. I do not believe it is realistic so to argue. I believe that one of the conclusions of my analysis of pacifism and unilateral disarmament is that it may lead to worse evils. I believe that peace will be found through strength and not through self-imposed weakness. Time will not allow me to recall the various instances in history to underline this point, but I shall refer to only one. We are all aware that in 1938 the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Mr Chamberlain, returned from the Munich Conference claiming 'Peace in our time'-as if the terror of the totalitarian nazis in Germany had been restrained and as if to suggest that everybody should be at ease. The feeling was that the nation did not need to prepare for immediate war. Yet Hitler's agression followed within a year when Czechoslovakia, Poland, Belgium, and so on fell and people faced the terrible holocaust of the Second World War. Though we all speak with the same voice on disarmament, I still see as a welcome part within that vanguard those who are genuine pacifists and those who are promoters of unilateral disarmament. But I am not in those two groups.

Another relevant issue is that of uranium. Many people involved with disarmament would urge that because the nuclear holocaust depends on uranium as the fuel for the bombs, all uranium mining should cease and that uranium should not be developed for industrial purposes. I do not agree with that view. I believe that uranium is required to meet the energy needs of the world and, not least, the needs of the poor countries. The resource development of our uranium is important for the development of Australia.

I concur entirely with the present Government's views and with Senator Sir John Carrick's references today to strict safeguards. But just as bushfires bring great tragedy in Australia, one does not argue that people should not have heating and cooking in their homes.
