Although electric power is of such great benefit in our homes, obviously if one were to climb a power pole outside one's home and touch the wires one would be dead. Such arguments would not lead to the abolition of electricity or the use of heating. Similarly, I would beware of a false bipartisanship-that is, that each super-power is equally wrong in having nuclear armaments and that each is equally dangerous. I do not agree with that.

I genuinely seek disarmament by all the super-powers, but this does not restrain my direct criticism as one Liberal senator of the Soviet Union as the major threat to world peace as an expansive and totalitarian power whose actions create the greatest danger for the peoples of the world. One has only to ask the people of Afghanistan, Kampuchea, Israel, the Caribbean, Poland, and Eritrea. I know from first hand that the people of the Soviet Union seek genuine solutions to the threat of a holocaust, but I will not necessarily be drawn to some false bipartisanship on the grounds that all super-powers are equally wrong. We need to be careful and factual in our statements about this aspect of the arms race and the other threats to world peace. What we all call for is much greater public support and general discussion of disarmament issues. There should be teaching, study and discussion in all schools, universities and communities.

Although I was born only in 1944 I remember that as a teenager I read David Hersey's book Hiroshima and was devastated by it. I continue to be devastated by it. Similarly, I read Alan Moorehead's book Gallipoli, with its terrors of trench warfare. Those of us in the Senate who were born since the Second World War have learnt from discussion with our elders and from books and films. The film currently circulating, The Day After, is an important part of this. We should encourage awareness not in a context of doom, despair and pessimism but, as in this debate, in a search for constructive answers. I believe we can act immediately for a nuclear-free Pacific, and for a complete ban on nuclear tests and on space weapons. There are constructive calls beyond discussion for such clearly defined goals, but disarmament must be measured, mutual, and meaningful. We must not seek some merely utopian peace, but a realistic, practical, achievable peace. We must seek a peace through strength, not weakness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this matter of public importance I am very mindful of the United Nations Charter which begins in its Preamble with these words:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the peoples of the United Nations, determined to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war . . .

I believe this points to the fact that it is the political will of the people of a country as well as those people who represent them in the parliament who must be active in seeking peace. But peace is not the absence of war. Peace is an activity using three capacities of the human being: Thinking, feeling and willing. An ever-increasing number of people throughout the world are acting on the responsibility placed upon them by that Preamble to the Charter. As we see the growing movement of people protesting against nuclear weapons in the world, we realise that it is this activity, this participation in the democratic process, which will be important. The scourge of war is already with us. I ask the Senate to picture just for a moment the latest nuclear missile, together with a child suffering from starvation in one of the under privileged countries. If we picture that we see the ultimate in obscenity. The world spends $1.4m a minute for military purposes and every minute 30 children die for want of food. In developed wealthy countries production of food is being cut. In a year when United States farmers were paid to take nearly 40 million hectares of crop land out of production, 450 million people in the world were starving.

The North-South report calls for the implementation of a new international economic order. Only people and the will of people can implement that new order. It calls for a change not only in our governments' arrangements and planning, but also in people's values. John Kenneth Galbraith said that there is a technological trap in military expenditure, with each country striving to develop weapons that protect it from obsolescence. More than $18.3 billion worth of major weapons were exported to the Third World in 1980. Military institutions represent a major force influencing the social, political and ideological development of a country. Military expenditure is a drain on resources which should be used for civilian purposes, to accelerate growth and modernisation in industry and agriculture, to promote health and education, and to raise the standard of living and the quality of life.

If we look at the comparison of per capita income for 1978-79, the latest figures available, we see that Australia is comparatively wealthy. It had a per capita income of $9,100; India, $190; Ethiopia, $130; Chad, $110; Tonga, $355; and so on. John Kenneth Galbraith again reminded us that however large or small a nuclear exchange, socialism, capitalism, communism, whatever system we develop these weapons to protect, will be shattered. They will not exist. We are the curators of the earth. It is we the people of the earth who are responsible to future generations. We are responsible for the plant and animal kingdoms and we hold all that has been given to us in the past by humanity, all that people have struggled for. The face of the earth in the future will be the result of our action or inaction today.

At present the most dangerous thing after a nuclear weapon is for people to think they do not mean much, that they are of no value, that they are merely grains of sand on a stormy beach. Though there is alarm for the future of humanity in many people's hearts, it should not engender blind fear and despair. It should not deprive us of the intelligence and courage which all people need, the capacity to face and probe the reasons for the present situation. It is the courage to oppose the values which lead to war and to develop the political will to bring change that we need. If we look at our society we see that the beginning of those nuclear weapons, the beginning of any weapons, has its roots in the values we support. Thus, it is very necessary that we oppose those values , which many of us recognise as being destructive. We must not remain silent. We have to remember that much of technology is now getting out of hand. It is controlling people's destinies, people are not controlling their own destinies. We have to look at the kinds of weapons that are being developed by scientists. It was recently announced that a laser weapon was being developed which would blind people, and yet there was hardly a ripple in the community about that announcement.

I think we have to look at our education system. Over the last 20 or 30 years very great emphasis has been placed on the development of the intellectual side of the human being at the expense of the emotional and creative side. I think there is a need for a much greater and more effective democracy in our country. An effective democracy demands informed participation. I think it is the duty of everyone, and particularly of people in the Parliament, to ensure that they have the information which is necessary for them to make informed and democratic decisions. One of Einstein's more remembered quotes is this:
The unleashed power of the atom has changed everything save our modes of thinking, and we thus drift toward unparalleled catastrophe.

It is in people's thinking and in people's values that we are going to bring about the changes that will build peace in our world. I do not think we can any longer make national interest our one and only priority. International threats demand international co-operation and care. They demand international work for peace. The Mayor of Nagasaki, in an address on the anniversary of the dropping of the bomb on Japan, said:

. . . just now we are standing at the edge of the abyss of mankind's destruction. Stop producing nuclear arms. If part of the expenses for the production of nuclear arms would be used, the hunger of millions in the world would be alleviated, the poor of the Third World would disappear.
He said we must establish an endeavour of never looking at any other country in the world as our enemy. Archbishop Hunthausen stated:
I have not dealt directly with the question always asked in regard to unilateral disarmament: What about the Russians?
What about our enemies? He continued:
I do not believe that we are the only nation in the world to cherish our homes, to love our children, to yearn for peace and to feel compassion for human misery .
Nor do I believe that all the people of Russia are pounding their shoes in the forums of the world in a universal cry for war.

The tragedy of today is that the youth of the world sees no future. A report on the North-South dialogue expressed special concern for the place of the youth in the world. It is very important that peace studies in schools are developed urgently because peace studies in our education system are the right of all children. In listening to Mr Martenson, the Assistant Secretary-General for the Centre for Disarmament at the United Nations, it became very apparent that he hoped the people of the different countries of the world-he was speaking to the people of Australia-would promote the Charter of the United Nations and the Declaration that came from the United Nations and encourage the community to communicate its wishes to governments, as the United Nations must be the focus of international activities devoted to disarmament. It was Lord Louis Mountbatten who said what I think is the final thing that anybody can say when speaking about nuclear weapons. He said:

In the event of a nuclear war there will be no chances-there will be no survivors, all will be obliterated. Nuclear devastation is not science fiction- it is a matter of fact. Let us all resolve to take all possible practical steps to ensure that we do not through our own folly go over the edge.

There are many people in every small community who deeply long to be able to do something to prevent the thing that they fear most. I think it is our responsibility to find the ways to do that. The Palme reports make particular emphasis of the fact that people must recognise that because they share a common threat they must also work together for a common security. Each of us in our own way does that. I hope that those of us who have joined together in the Parliamentary Disarmament Group will demonstrate that differences between individuals and individuals' thinking can be overcome. We can work together and demonstrate that it is possible. I remind honourable senators that tonight we are showing the film Bringing Greenham Home. This is not a film about Greenham Common; it is about the effect of a peace activity on the development of the human personality and the capacity to care. I hope everybody will be able to attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the four co-ordinators of the Australian Parliamentary Disarmament Group to represent the four parties in the Senate I wish to make a contribution to this debate and to put my Party's position on record. My Party is very mindful of the tremendous misuse of money, manpower and misdirected effort that is applied to the nuclear arms race. We support the resolution expressed in the wording of the matter of public importance. I believe that last night the Leader of our Party, Mr Ian Sinclair, expressed the view that he was totally opposed to the export of uranium for anything other than peaceful use. I think that the policies of the three parties -the National Party of Australia, the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party-are probably in accord on this position.

SPEECH.PARA: When one considers that the world's military spending in 1981 totalled $625 billion, which is about $110 for every man, woman and child on earth, and then contrasts it with human suffering, such as one child out of four suffering from malnutrition and four out of five children not having modern health care, and when one considers the overall spending of huge sums of money on defence as well as nuclear and conventional warfare, one wonders if this matter of public importance is getting to the heart of the problem. However, the matter under discussion is the pressing need for the world powers to be involved in constructive discussions on international nuclear disarmament. Information exists showing that 50,000 nuclear weapons are now deployed. Together the combined explosive power is one million times greater than the bombs dropped on Hiroshima. There is the everlasting fear of a Third World nuclear power. Trouble spots exist in the world, which are at the moment of great concern; for example, the explosive political nature of the Middle East. This emphasises the need for the world powers to be involved in a positive and constructive talk on nuclear international disarmament.

The starting point for such international discussion is the International Atomic Energy Agency. It appears to be looking at enlarging its role. The Agency 's Director-General, Dr Hans Blix, is in Australia to give evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. He said that the Agency could act as an arm on diversion of peaceful nuclear material for weapon production. He was quick to point out, however, that the Agency could not look into the minds of countries which were known proliferation signatories.

One has to face reality; much of the nuclear energy for peaceful purposes is here. In this debate we must be careful not to make out a nexus between the peaceful use of uranium for domestic electricity generation and the proliferation of nuclear weapons. Nuclear weapons were developed before the peaceful use of nuclear power. It is my understanding that the product used in domestic nuclear power stations is not necessarily or generally regarded as suitable in a technical sense for nuclear weapons purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Capable of being used, Senator, but not necessarily.

—I take the honourable senator's point. The trend is towards the peaceful use of nuclear energy. Dr Blix is of the belief that the world is increasingly turning to nuclear energy for the production of electricity. It seems there is genuine concern about the possible use of nuclear weapons in countries using nuclear material. Some 119 countries have become non- proliferation signatories. These countries believe it is not in their interests to acquire nuclear weapons and want to reassure other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, here lies the basis for international talks and action. Action can be taken in the area of policing. It is reported that the International Atomic Energy Agency, the authority charged with monitoring safeguards, has only 138 inspectors to cover 774 known facilities. It seems to me that this is one area in which action is required. Probably the greatest action can be taken by the people themselves by putting pressure on the government of the day to participate honestly in talks. Australia has been a member of the International Atomic Energy Agency since its inception and is one of the nine advanced countries on its Board. Therefore, Australia should use its influence to seek constructive international talks on the subject of international nuclear disarmament. I go further. I urge talks and action to de- escalate the all-encompassing arms race. The United Nations has reported that 8 per cent of the world's total capital is spent on the arms race. That money would go a long way towards eradicating poverty and hunger in both developed and developing countries. I support the spirit of this sincerely put matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under standing order 64 for the discussion of matters of public importance has expired. The debate is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of the Bill is to increase the penalties that may be imposed upon persons convicted of offences against the quarantine laws of Australia. The Bill also makes a number of other amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908 to overcome some operational difficulties experienced with the Act, and to make it more responsive to modern situations.

I wish to impress upon honourable senators the seriousness with which the Government views breaches of quarantine. It is estimated that an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Australia would bring to a virtual standstill exports of meat and other commodities of livestock origin, and would cause a drop in rural output of the order of $2,500m in the first year.

The penalties under the Quarantine Act were last increased in 1979 to the present maximum level of $10,000 or five years imprisonment. The rural sector has strongly pressed for further increases and has also complained about the inadequacy of fines imposed by the courts.

As a deterrent to potential offenders, and as an inducement to the courts to provide higher penalties, the Bill at Clause 27 provides for substantial increases in penalties, particularly the penal sanctions. For example, the maximum penalty for importing a disease agent contrary to the Act is increased from $10,000 or imprisonment for five years to $50,000 or imprisonment for ten years, or both, or if the offender is a body corporate, $200,000. Where a quarantine emergency exists, any person who does not comply with a direction given to implement emergency measures taken by the Minister, or who hinders or obstructs such measures, will face a maximum penalty of $100,000 or imprisonment for ten years, or both. The maximum penalty that currently exists is $10,000 or imprisonment for five years.
Mr President, I now wish to turn to the other amendents in this Bill and address the more substantial provisions.

Clause 5 provides for the appointment of the Director of Quarantine and Chief Quarantine Officers by the Minister, and for the appointment of Quarantine Officers by the Director of Quarantine, instead of these appointments being made by the Governor-General. As there are about 1,700 Quarantine Officers throughout Australia this amendment will remove a considerable workload from the Governor- General.

Clause 16 provides for the amendment of section 48 of the Act relating to goods ordered into quarantine. Section 48 provides that where goods ordered into quarantine cannot be effectively treated or disinfected and ought not to be released from quarantine, the goods may be destroyed. The clause amends section 48 to provide a review of the opinion of the Quarantine Officer immediately in charge of goods where those goods are live animals by vesting the decision to destroy the animals in a Chief Quarantine Officer. The clause also includes a new provision to enable the owner of any goods to be notified where the goods cannot be treated without damaging them, so that the owner can be given an opportunity to agree to the course of action proposed. If the owner has not notified his intentions in relation to the goods within 30 days, the goods will be forfeit to the Commonwealth.

Clause 18 extends the powers of inspection of a Quarantine Officer under the Act to a vessel that is beyond the territorial sea of Australia and is bound for Australia or the Cocos Islands, to the extent that the vessel is within nine nautical miles of the outer limits of the territorial sea. The Governor-General may proclaim a greater distance than nine nautical miles under the provision. The Government considers it desirable for the jurisdiction of the Quarantine Act to be extended over as much territory to which Australia has a legal right of influence as is possible for effective quarantine control. Recent developments in international law have enabled this extension of the powers of inspection.

Clauses 20 and 21 provide powers of search relating to domestic animals in the Cocos Islands. These powers are presently contained in Regulations 14 and 19 of the Quarantine (Cocos Islands) Regulations. They are being included in the Quarantine Act following reservations expressed by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances about the powers of Quarantine Officers to enter premises in the Cocos Islands, and advice by the Attorney-General's Department that the inclusion of such powers in subordinate legislation was inappropriate. Arrangements are in train for the repeal of the relevant regulations.

Clause 25 provides for the Minister to have the power to determine the levels of fees for quarantine services instead of such fees being prescribed by regulation. Such determinations will be subject to the scrutiny of Parliament as the clause also provides that the determinations will be subject to certain provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. These provisions are for the laying of regulations before both Houses of Parliament, the disallowance of regulations, and the effect of the repeal of regulations. This provision will facilitate the introduction of new fee levels in accordance with the Government' s policy for the recovery of direct operating costs for quarantine services.

Clause 26 of the Bill provides a new regulation making power to put beyond doubt the scope of the Act to control the storage, use, movement and disposal of goods, including disease agents where the goods are permitted to be imported by the Minister or the Director of Quarantine for a particular purpose for use in a particular location, such as a research establishment or diagnostic laboratory.
Mr President, the remaining provisions of this Bill make minor amendments of a machinery or procedural nature in order to facilitate the more efficient administration of the Act.
There will be no financial impact from any of these provisions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I take this opportunity to congratulate the Chairman and Director of the Australian National Gallery on its report for 1982-83. After having read this report, it is obvious that, with the opening of this outstanding venue which is already becoming a new focus for the visual arts in Australia, set in train an extremely historic year. I mention just a few statistics in the report which I find particularly impressive. Firstly, within eight months of the Australian National Gallery opening, half a million visitors had passed through it. That is a record of which the Gallery Director and its staff can be proud. Of these visitors, 77 per cent came from interstate or overseas. Apparently this represents a 15 per cent increase in the Australian Capital Territory's tourist industry. It has been of great benefit to Canberra. Secondly, membership of the Australian National Gallery Association has already jumped to 12,000 members, which indicates the extent of interest in the Gallery and the work that it will do in the foreseeable future. Thirdly, educational programs undertaken by the Gallery in this first year are equally impressive. Some 882 school groups have gone through the Gallery in its first months of operation, comprising nearly 33, 000 school students. Some 170 lunch time lectures have been held for the public and over 1,000 tours have been organised.

I commend the very effective partnership established between the Gallery, the Government and the private sector. The founding donor fund has already attracted a very good response. Furthermore, the corporate appeal raised just on $1m, from over 100 companies, in the Gallery's first months of operation. There is also a very impressive account of exhibitions and a report on new acquisitions.

I am particularly interested in the number of outward loans going from the Gallery into communities throughout Australia, or, should I say, to certain parts of Australia because obviously it has not been possible in the Gallery's first year to make loans throughout Australia. I certainly hope that that will be forthcoming over the next 12 months and on into the life of the Gallery. It is good to see that as well as outward loans going from the Australian National Gallery to galleries in capital cities, loans also go to places such as Burnie, Broken Hill and Newcastle. I notice that a loan was made to a local authority in Melbourne, and I hope that other local authorities will have the opportunity to borrow from the Gallery; that is, we must never forget, the National Gallery. Sometimes, when we have such fine resources in our Australian Capital Territory, it is easy for people who live many thousands of miles away to feel that perhaps it is Canberra's Gallery. Of course it is not Canberra's Gallery; it belongs to the people of Australia. That is why outward loans are particularly important in ensuring that Australians living away from Canberra do have the opportunity to view works of art that belong to the nation.
This brings me to a point about which I am rather concerned. I note that, on page 18 of the annual report, it is stated:

By the end of June 1983 a five-year exhibition programme had been sighted and detailed planning for its implementation commenced. The programme does not include travelling exhibitions; they are precluded at present by budget restraints.

Certainly I will be making representations to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen, to bring his attention to this matter because it is of some concern that travelling exhibitions may not be introduced in the 1984-85 Budget or even after that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I believe that we must all take into account the tremendous job that the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee has done in establishing poultry as a basic part of the Australian diet. Poultry has come from the position where it was very much an odd meat, a luxury only to be eaten occasionally, to where it is now a dominant part of the household diet. Much of this has come about through the way this Committee has gone about its work. It has done a considerable amount of research into the various facets of production, presentation, feeding and marketing. I believe it should get full credit for what it has done. There are extraordinarly dedicated people mixed up in the Committee. It has done a great job in getting the consumption rate of chicken meat increased, improving nutrition and improving the health and housing of poultry generally.

It is interesting that some people are racing around saying that battery eggs are not fit to eat and so on. It must be remembered that the poultry industry depends very largely on the quality of its product. It has now been determined that the quality, nutritional value and health standards of battery eggs are better than those of free ranging eggs. The health and diet of poultry has been a matter of great concern. Nutrition and health generally have reached a remarkable stage. The Committee spends approximately half a million dollars a year on research. The money is provided equally by the industry and the Government. Diseases have been attacked quite substantially. I am pleased to report that fundamental industry difficulties and diseases have been largely brought under control once again and the future looks very bright for the industry generally to continue in the manner it has been going for the last decade.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Nine projects were carried out using money supplied through the Fisheries Development Trust Account. The two to which I would like to refer are the south- east trawl fishery and the octopus fishery. The south-east trawl fishery has received funds from the account for the last four or five years. In the year under review it received $78,000 for investigations in New South Wales, $39,300 for investigations in Victoria and $237,000 for investigations in Tasmania. The work has been carried out, in the main, by a mixture of both research and local fishermen. The results have been, to say the least, quite spasmodic. The fishermen have been of the highest possible calibre. I make particular reference to the capacity and ability of Peter Rockliff, a Tasmanian fisherman, who has done a considerable amount of work in the deeper waters and is now fishing in waters up to 500 fathoms, which is quite unusual for Australian waters. His interest and involvement have helped considerably in trying to establish what fishing grounds there are, especially to the west of Tasmania on the edge of the continental shelf. There are high hopes of establishing grounds for an increase in the fishing industry in Tasmania.

The octopus fishing industry is being carried out from Stanley by Michael Hardy . It has started to show some promise. It has been going for four or five years and has experienced various ups and downs. The gear has caused some difficulty. As late as today I was able to ascertain that certain equipment that is necessary in this industy will be available in the next few weeks. That is fortunate. It is difficult to establish such an industry in Australia. People here are not accustomed to eating octopus and do not consider it to be of any great value. Michael Hardy has been able to establish that there are viable quantities. He has developed methods of catching octopuses which appear to be quite satisfactory. He is now exporting to the United States of America and is looking to Japan and Europe as extensions of that market. The price, at present, is not as good as we would hope, but it is expected that, as he is able to provide continuity of supply, he will be able to supply at a better price.

It is an exceptionally good fishery for Tasmania. It may not be generally known that octopuses are the great predators of the rock lobster. To be able to catch the octopus and dispose of it will improve the rock lobster industry. That makes it a worthwhile venture. Michael Hardy is a young man who comes from a long established fishing family. At this time I wish him well and hope that the venture turns out well for him and that it expands to include other people. The money that has been spent on this industry so far is not large. However, I think it has been enough to keep him interested. It will demonstrate to others that, as the market is developed, there could be a quite good livelihood for several other fishermen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Archer, would like to make a few remarks in relation to the report on the operation of the Fishing Industry Act 1956. The report deals with grants given to the fishing industry for research. Whilst one could deal with a number of items in the report, it is my intention to deal with the reference to the prawning industry in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The sixth item on the list of projects supported by the Fisheries Development Trust Account in 1982-83 refers to the exploratory prawn trawling in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The report indicates that a grant of $54,000 was approved in 1981-82. There was a further payment from the account in 1982-83 of $50,000 which completed the project.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth while mentioning at this time that although money was paid to the industry by the Federal Government for research concerning exploratory prawn trawling in the Gulf of Carpentaria, Northern Fishing Companies Association, which carried out that research by using six of its trawlers, would have paid somewhere in the vicinity of $420,000 into the cost of that research. One has to take into consideration the fact that the trawlers used for research at that time were not returning to their bases with catches. If running costs were taken into account, plus the time spent by the trawlers and their crew, that company would have spent $420,000-odd to complete its research into prawning in the Gulf of Carpentaria. I believe the money that is being expended by the industry and the Government in relation to research will help the prawning industry in the Gulf of Carpentaria to exploit the resources that are available to it. In the future the industry will be able to plan for further fishing and prawning within the Gulf of Carpentaria.

It is worth while mentioning that the northern prawn fisheries deserve some congratulations for the courage and tenacity which they have shown in establishing a viable industry in a true frontier area of Australia. It is also reasonable to note that this industry has been established despite the problems it has faced in relation to the weather and not knowing what resource was available to it prior to the research being undertaken and completed. The prawn trawlers use Karumba as their base. Until now the prawns were processed there. There are some problems in the area, particularly the water supply. It concerns the amount of water used by residents in the area and the amount of water needed by the prawn processing plant in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the jellyfish?

—I do not know whether there are any jellyfish in that area. It is interesting to note that Normanton, a town not far from Karumba, was paid money by the Federal Government in order to establish a water supply. Although $1.7m has been spent in the Normanton area there has been no allocation of money to Karumba. This is not the responsibility of the Federal Government. But it is certainly the responsibility of the State Government to supply some money for the establishment of a water supply to the Karumba area. This would allow the trade that has been undertaken by the prawn trawlers in the area to increase. It would increase the number of people living in the area. They could have a water supply which could be used by the prawn processing plant that was established in the area. Because of neglect in this area, we are putting in jeopardy a fishing industry which would earn in the vicinity of $35m a year. I think that some request should be made to the State Government to supply some of the money at least, or a major portion of the money, to provide a decent water supply in the Karumba area.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to make some brief remarks. If honourable senators do not wish to comment now I will seek leave to continue my remarks. I have not had an opportunity to study the guidelines so at the moment I will direct my remarks to the principle. From my experience as a Minister it seems to me that the guidelines were not necessary for lobbyists, but the guidelines were necessary for those who found themselves being approached by lobbyists-that is, Ministers and departmental officers. After all, if a Minister or a senior departmental officer is appointed one must presume that that person is capable of understanding the osmotic pressures that are around in politics and is capable of withstanding any pressures or approaches that are not valid. I took the view that if someone sought an appointment with me the question was merely whether the principal for whom the lobbyist operated was a respectable person with a respectable issue. If that was so I would willingly see the principal. It seems to me that we are looking at the wrong end of the telescope in simply concentrating on the lobbyist.

If departmental officers are mature enough to do their jobs every day of their lives they will have to make value judgments on the subjective self-interests of those who approach them. I do not see that we have advanced the cause in any way by suggesting that some register of lobbyists would do any good. Clearly, all who approach Ministers or departments are coming forward in self-interest-many of which are very genuine and very fair self-interests. It does not necessarily follow that lobbyists have any more concentration of particular interests than individuals. I am puzzled over this matter. I want time to look at the paper. On that basis I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS MISSION TO COCOS (KEELING) ISLANDS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking to the statement by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) regarding the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, I note that the United Nations has accepted an invitation from the Australian Government to send a visiting mission to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to witness the making by the people of Cocos Island of an act of self-determination. I understand the delegation is going to Cocos Island between 3 and 8 April and that the representatives of the mission will be from Sierra Leone, Yugoslavia, Fiji and Venezuela. This will be the third United Nations mission to Cocos Island. The matter has come a long way. I note that the people of Cocos Island have indicated that they wish to be more closely associated with Australia and that the self-determination which will take place, I think on 6 April, will give the Islanders the opportunity of independence, integration into Australia or free association with Australia. It seems that already there has been a consensus of opinion and that on 6 April we are likely to see that the Cocos Island people will choose integration. The statement reads:

Under integration, the Cocos people would have the full rights, privileges and obligations of other Australian citizens: Local arrangements would be modified to give the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council wider powers and ownership of the plantation lands at present leased by the Commonwealth to the Cocos Co-operative . The electors of Cocos would be included in an existing territory electorate for the purposes of House of Representatives and Senate elections and national referendums.

The move for self-determination has been in the pipeline for some considerable time, at least since 1978, when the former Federal Government paid to the former owner of the islands, Mr John Clunies-Ross, some $6.2m for an 11 hectare plantation. There has been some controversy between him and the Islanders with the result that he is no longer welcome there unless by invitation of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council. The recent suggestions by the Federal Labor Government that the Cocos and Christmas Islands be incorporated into the Northern Territory, which have been stated elsewhere, indicate that the Government is totally out of touch with the realities of northern Australia. Apparently, the Federal Government machine believes the three Territory senators and one member of the House of Representatives can add two islands some 3,000 kilometres away in the Indian Ocean to their already considerable responsibilities.

During discussions with the former Home Affairs and Environment Minister, Mr McVeigh, and the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren), the people of the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island, I understand, have repeatedly expressed a desire to integrate with Australia, as I have indicated before. More specifically, they say that they wish to be included as part of Western Australia. For many years Western Australia has had trade dealings and communications with the island group, resulting in direct air and shipping services between Perth and Cocos Islands. It would seem to me to be logical that if the Cocos and Christmas Islands were to be integrated into Australia it should be through Western Australia. Traditionally the people of the Islands have had strong connections with the Australian Labor Party, and that is no reflection on them whatsoever. As I understand it, the unions on Christmas Island, which is going the same way as the Cocos Islands, are reported to have donated some $50,000 to the Western Australian ALP last year to help fund the State and Federal election campaigns. It appears to me that the move to integrate the islands with the Northern Territory is purely a political move to enhance the ALP in the Northern Territory. There is no sound economic or administrative reason for it. I wonder why the Prime Minister has such strong feelings. He has repeatedly said that the Cocos Islands should be incorporated into the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory has nothing in common with the islands and has never had any sort of economic or administrative connections .

In closing, I suggest that if the Federal Government is interested in the Northern Territory acquiring more responsibility in the Cocos Islands, and perhaps in Christmas Island, as is being suggested, perhaps it might consider the return of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands to the Northern Territory. Those Islands were taken away from the Northern Territory at the time of responsible self-government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —One might think that the subject matter of this report would be, to use an Attorney-General-type remark, a fairly esoteric and even exotic species. There has been a finding by the Industries Assistance Commission that I believe is somewhat hard to follow. It is a finding that, though there has been the clear importation and dumping of automotive filters from New Zealand by a couple of multinational companies that also have operations in Australia, no damage is being done to the Australian industry as a result. Therefore it has recommended no action. The Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) has chosen not to take the advice of the Industries Assistance Commission and has continued the special duty, which was imposed when this matter first arose under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter has been one of considerable concern. I speak to it briefly to indicate that the Senate is aware of the concern of a cross-section of Australian manufacturers who believe that they have been subjected to an unfair trading practice by our close trading partner across the Tasman Sea. That is one of the matters to which we will have to pay very careful attention, I believe, during the operation and development of closer economic relations with New Zealand. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 March, on motion by Senator Jessop:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report. This is not just another annual report. It covers a period in which there have been some years of unprecedented drought in Australia as a whole, and in this catchment area in particular. Therefore, it tells a story of the management of what is one of the, if not the, most precious natural resources in Australia, that is, the River Murray, at a time of immense difficulties. It tells a great story, because it is able to show that in that time salinity levels, for example, particularly towards South Australia, were lower then they had been in many other times. In fact, in this chamber I have reported as a Minister that it was not abnormal for something like one and a quarter million tonnes of salt to be tipped out of New South Wales and Victoria in any year, largely from the dead sea that is there, into South Australia. The report indicates that that had been in the order of half a million tonnes. That is a lot, but nevertheless is capable of being handled by dilution.

SPEECH.PARA: It tells a story of management by man so that the water could be used to the best advantage for irrigation purposes, against the contrasting needs of the various farmers and against the contrasting needs of hydro-electricity generation. The Senate will be aware of the grave difficulties that both New South Wales and Victoria have faced in keeping their coal-burning generation operating. New South Wales, which needed only 60 per cent of its installed generating capacity to be able to function, to keep lights on, was not able to do so on occasions, and the Snowy Mountains Authority had to be called in.

I make the point that the annual report quite properly pays tribute to the existence of the Dartmouth Dam and the significance of the fact that at the start of these difficulties the Dartmouth Dam had filled to something like 75 per cent. The Hume Dam which was down to 20 per cent or less-it virtually was down to a breeding ground for mud crabs-was incapable of supplying water. The existence of the Dartmouth Dam allowed a flow through Victoria. This was carefully monitored so as to avoid too much flooding. It was properly handled through the Hume and downstream.

The message from this is the importance of the new River Murray Waters Agreement. The annual report pays tribute to it and to the fact that qualitative measurements as well as quantitative measurements of water are now possible. Reports of any significant activity in the alteration of both the quantity and quality of the water in all the three States concerned can be obtained. This points to the significance of the various measures, particularly those that have been done under the Maunsell scheme in the past and, in my view, the absolute need for an early feasibility study of a new upper Murray storage. This was advocated by the Fraser Government and me when I was Minister. The aim was that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation should undertake this feasibility study. We need to set in place another major storage dam so that in the future there will never be a situation of no water and so that there will be a reasonable flow to dilute the salinity and meet irrigation needs. In my view, the need for an upper Murray storage is paramount. It is a great pity that it has been set aside but I commend the experts of the River Murray Commission and I pay tribute to their work.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the proposal in the paper to repeal sections 45, 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act will see a return to the kind of union and industrial anarchy of some years ago. Business will soon lose the protection of speedy efficient sanctions that have prevented secondary boycotts. While the Government is loosening its legal sanctions against trade unions, at the same time this document recommends a tightening of its controls over business. How can business survive in this sort of environment, with this sort of Government and these sorts of proposals? These proposals are a sell out to the militant left of the trade union movement just as we see a sellout in the appointment of Mr Carmichael and Mr Halfpenny to the Australian Manufacturing Council. Others could have been appointed who would have made a greater contribution-for example, men from the car industry whose jobs and whose members are in jeopardy at present.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no justification for a secondary boycott and no justification for the proposals to repeal these sections. The reasons that have been given are both spurious and spineless in that the authors believe that these matters are more appropriate to industrial legislation. Such argument hides the fact of life that section 45D of the Trade Practices Act has worked successfully as a sanction against mindless and often wilful industrial disputation that harms Australian business and exporters. It is not difficult to forecast that, with the repeal of these provisions, some independent truck owners will be singled out and knocked off by the big transport unions. We will find that the shipping and airline industries will also be targets of disputation once these sanctions are removed from the Trade Practices Act. The proposals will be a tragedy for business and for Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the statement by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) on Telecom and law enforcement in so far as it goes some way towards addressing the recent allegations of corruption within the Australian Telecommunications Commission. The statement has been forced upon the Minister by the perseverance of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich, who has felt compelled to follow up his report of last year in which he outlined some very serious matters relating to Telecom and malfeasance within that organisation. However, we are concerned whether the measures outlined by the Minister in his statement are adequate in view of the serious allegations raised not only by Mr Redlich but also by recent royal commissions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our view that the terms of reference given to Mr Vincent are too narrow. We are concerned also that several of the announcements made by the Minister in his statement could pre-empt recommendations that Mr Vincent might make. Allegations of corruption within Telecom have gained some currency following the reports of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, the Connor Inquiry into Legalisation of Casinos in Victoria and, more recently, the issue of the Age tapes. In the light of these, the Government should be doing its utmost to ensure that all illegal activities are uncovered and dealt with appropriately. Such allegations, if they are left unchecked, serve only to impugn the reputations of honest and decent Telecom employees. The Opposition believes that an exhaustive inquiry is essential. We take no comfort from the Minister's statement that:
. . . it is necessary to ensure that the proper efficiency of Telecom is not impaired and that the measures outlined above do not destroy the basic privacy of the telephone system.

The allegations mentioned by Mr Redlich are serious. They relate to the involvement of Telecom employees in assisting in the commission of illegal activities; the indifferent attitude of senior personnel within Telecom to these activities; the lack of co-operation by Telecom staff with internal and police investigations; the employment of staff with serious criminal records and their placement in positions of trust; and the interference by senior Telecom personnel in internal investigations into the allegations.
At this point I mention that the Minister assured us in his statement:
Telecom has co-operated and continues to co-operate with law enforcement agencies in the detection of illegal bookmaking.
Mr Redlich does not think that is the case. The Minister's statement is in stark contrast to the claims of Mr Redlich. Mr Redlich said:

One area in need of urgent rectification is the manner and degree to which senior personnel interfere with internal investigations. Past interference has resulted in serious circumscription in the scope and effectiveness of internal investigation. In some instances investigations were brought to a premature or improper conclusion.

In the case of Telecom it appears that senior personnel are able to control the efforts of investigators by directing the compass of the investigations to ensure that matters that may prove embarrassing to Telecom are not discovered or highlighted.

That is what Mr Redlich says and it is nonsense of Mr Duffy to try to assure us that Telecom co-operates. Mr Redlich's evidence is to the contrary. Who is right ? Is it Mr Redlich in his role as investigator or Mr Duffy in attempting to tell us that this is, in Dr Pangloss's words, 'the best of all possible worlds'.

Other problems outlined by Mr Redlich concern the improper use of the disciplinary power under section 58 of the Telecommunications Act, the reduction in the size of the internal investigation unit in Telecom and unsatisfactory working guidelines between Telecom and the Australian Federal Police. They are all very serious matters. The Government has appointed Mr Frank Vincent, QC, to investigate Mr Redlich's complaints, to recommend appropriate action and to report to the Minister by 30 June this year. Of course, Mr Vincent has no small task in front of him. But apart from the narrow terms of reference set down by the Minister, we in the Opposition are concerned that the recommendations Mr Vincent might make have already been pre-empted by actions of the Government.

The Minister talks about amendments to the Telecommunications Act and outlines what some of them might be. Has the Minister a predetermined set of amendments which he wishes to introduce or is he going to wait and hear what Mr Vincent has to propose? The Minister talks about revised working arrangements and policy guidelines concerning the Australian Federal Police and Telecom. Has he predetermined his position? Has he predetermined his position on the way that Telecom might collect additional information from applicants? Have Caucus decisions been made already in relation to amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act which might make some of Mr Vincent's work academic or unnecessary? This is a matter of some concern to Mr Redlich. He refers, for example, to the internal investigation unit, which has been reduced over the last three years from, I think, 21 to 11 persons.

The Opposition considers these to be very important matters. Telecom is the largest single employer of the Commonwealth Public Service, employing some 90, 000 people. It is the most influential and important instrumentality that we have. It is imperative, in the national interest, that these allegations be cleared up and that they be cleared up completely.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken the opportunity-the liberty perhaps-of bringing back for debate in the Senate the 1982-83 annual report of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd because we did not have time to debate this matter when it was last before the Senate. I wish to commend Miss Lois O' Donoghue and Aboriginal members of the board for their report. I note that the highlights of the year were a 20.7 per cent rise in funding from the Commonwealth Government, opening of the first alternative style village for Aboriginal fringe dwellers in Australia, the winning of a prestigious Australian Institute of Management award for its 1981-82 annual report and the celebration by Aboriginal Hostels of its tenth anniversary. Under the heading 'Company Operations' the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the 1982-83 fiscal year, Aboriginal Hostels Limited operated or funded 122 hostels around Australia providing 2,996 beds to meet the temporary accommodation needs of Aborigines and Islanders. This total included 64 hostels providing 1,367 beds operated by Aborigines and community organisations under the Company's Third Party Hostel Grants Program.
The remaining 58 hostels, with a total of 1,629 beds were operated directly by the Comapny.
Under the heading 'Types of Hostels' the report states:
Hostels provide temporary accommodation for Aborigines in education, employment , vocational training and for health reasons.

I note also that there is to be a review of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd's company charter. This is to take place after 10 years of very successful operation. I believe that the board, after experiencing extreme difficulties at the beginning of its operations, has done a tremendous amount of work in accommodating Aboriginal people throughout Australia. I understand that the Government has agreed to a complete review of the company charter under which Aboriginal Hostels Ltd was formed in 1973 as it is now recognised that the original charter has served its purpose.

I have always followed the operations of Aboriginal Hostels Limited with considerable interest. I have had something to do with this organisation over the years. I, too, believe it is time that its charter was reviewed. The organisation is responsible for hostels. I feel that its role could be extended considerably. The Aboriginal Development Commission was given responsibility for Aboriginal housing a couple of years ago. I wonder whether the Government, having in mind the success that the board has made of Aboriginal Hostels, would consider making Aboriginal Hostels responsible for Aboriginal housing with the assistance of the States, and I acknowledge that the States have a responsibility for Aboriginal housing. I believe that such an arrangement would result in a more efficient operation in terms of housing Aboriginal people.

I also believe that Aboriginal Hostels could offer other specialised accommodation. I believe this organisation could house young people and apprentices to a greater degree than it does at present. I also believe that the time has come when Aboriginal Hostels could offer social facilities. I believe that social club activities could be introduced in places such as Alice Springs. I think this would be for the betterment of Aboriginal people. I believe that Aboriginal Hostels should cater for Aboriginal people broadly and not for particular groups of them. I notice that the Sid Ross Hostel in Alice Springs caters for the Pitjantjatjara people. I believe that the Pitjantjatjara people should be given land for the development of village-type accommodation and that the Sid Ross type of operation should be for the Aboriginal people generally. Considerable damage has been done to the Sid Ross Hostel. I do not believe that this is the fault of Aboriginal Hostels. I believe that Aboriginal Hostels has to review this type of operation. I recommend that the Pitjantjatjara people, like the members of other tribes who come into Alice Springs, should be housed in village type accommodation. The Sid Ross Hostel, which is of considerable value, should be used by Aboriginals as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on the 1982-83 annual report of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, being, as it is, the most successful of the Aboriginal commercial or semi-commercial organisations. It was my pleasure when I was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to work with Aboriginal Hostels. I want to place on record once more my appreciation of the work done by the directors. I particularly place on record my appreciation of the work done by Miss Lois O'Donoghue, the Chairman of the board, and also the work done by my former colleague, Mr Neville Bonner, in the long period that he spent working with Aboriginal Hostels. Of the organisations I visited around Australia and the facilities that I saw operating, Aboriginal Hostels seemed to me to be far and away the most efficient and to be delivering on the ground to those who needed it the most effective services.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make one point to the Government. I understand that today a new head was officially appointed to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and that is Mr Charles Perkins. I understand he will take over his duties next Monday. I understand, too, that when he leaves the Aboriginal Development Commission the function of welfare housing will go from the Commission. That function may well go to a new organisation involving Aboriginal Hostels. This means that that organisation may be taking on the function of welfare housing which up until now has been with the Aboriginal Development Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can do the job well.

—I agree with Senator Kilgariff that it will be able to do the job well. What we need to know at an early stage, so that we can understand what is happening, is what are the new administrative arrangements which will be in effect for the functions presently carried out by the Aboriginal Development Commission. With the departure of Mr Perkins, who will head the Aboriginal Development Commission, what functions will it lose and which of those functions will go directly to Aboriginal Hostels Limited and which will be taken up in some new administrative arrangement? We ask this not in any combative way but so that those of us who are interested in Aboriginal welfare and have had some association with Aboriginal welfare, as has my colleague Senator Kilgariff, for example, will be able to know under whose responsibility some of these important functions will rest.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for its abandonment of the maintenance of an adequate defence force for Australia in relation to-
(a) the totally inadequate share of the Federal Budget devoted to the primary responsibility of Government, namely the defence of the nation;
(b) the consequential placing of the Australian Defence Forces in a position from where recovery is now impossible when faced with an armed threat to the security of the country;

(c) the abandonment of the plans to provide a platform at sea for the operation of a rotary winged aircraft for anti-submarine warfare and fixed wing aircraft for surveillance, strike and air superiority;
(d) the criminal negligence in disbanding the Fleet Air Arm whose continued existence was a national defence asset even if no seaborne platforms were available in the short-term;
(e) the failure to provide helicopters for the FFG's for the Navy;

(f) the decision to buy two more FFG's and not recognise the totally incorrect decision by a previous Labor Government to buy this class of ship for the Royal Australian Navy, a design which is completely inadequate for Australia's needs;
(g) the failure to move purposefully to provide adequate airborne refuelling aircraft for the RAAF;
(h) the failure to provide any airborne early warning aircraft;
(i) the failure to provide adequate transport, air support, ammunition, boots and clothing to units of the Australian Army, particularly the Operational Deployment Force;

(j) the very depressed state of morale in the Australian Defence Forces arising from the aforementioned factors and from poor housing, tax on Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits payments and general neglect from the Government of their needs; and
(k) the breaking of morale in the Reserve Forces by taxing payments to its members.

I move this motion because I believe that at no time since Federation have Australia's defences been in a more parlous state than they are now. Quite simply, I contend that Australia cannot defend itself against any sort of armed aggression. I recognise that the previous Government did not do as much as it might have done and that the defences of this country were not as strong as they might have been. But at least that Government had a publicly-declared target for increasing expenditure, and thereby the effectiveness of our defence forces. No such target exists for the present Government. Australians have seen a dramatic decline in the capability of their defence forces in the last 12 months. There has been a catastrophic decline in morale and a dramatic drop in the capability of the Australian defence forces. One is almost at the point of arguing that if this is what the defence vote is buying for Australia, it is hardly worth laying out 10 per cent of the Federal Budget for it.

And this comes from a Government that runs a monumental deficit that is comparable with that in the United States in terms of the percentage of gross domestic product. Given this enormous deficit this year of $9 billion or $10 billion, we have a Government that has infantry units without boots. So much for the priorities spoken of by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who talks of having an adequate defence for Australia.

Strategically, Australia is a very important country. It is not true that Australia is not coveted by other nations. It is worth defending: We must defend our country. It is our responsibility and not that of any other country. Australia has a most strategic position at the confluence of both the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Both oceans are important for the super-powers, as can be seen from the increasing deployment of air and marine units of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Australia is strategically important for Japan and its huge trade both with the United States and Europe and its oil supplies coming through the Persian Gulf and the Indian Ocean. It is strategically important to the Soviet Union in support for its client states of Vietnam and North Korea and as a passage way to the Asian portion of the Soviet Union.

Defence is one of the four great offices of state and the first duty of any government-the protection of its people. Yet Australia has negligible public debate-indeed, negligible parliamentary debate-on this topic. The Senate is the home of debate on foreign affairs and defence, but in the period of almost six years I have been a member of this chamber I cannot recall one full scale serious debate on the subject of defence. I think that I have spoken more on that subject than any other honourable senator, and when I have spoken I have usually provoked the intolerance of the Labor Party-not so much as a result of what I have said politically, but simply because Labor members begrudge the time of the chamber being devoted to this subject. In the 12 months since the Australian Labor Party has been in power it has kept very quiet about defence and has not sought to raise the subject in this place. Labor has done Australia a great disservice in its year in office. It has resurrected the no-threat doctrine, dusted it off and made it official holy writ. It is vintage Whitlam stuff. All it has done is to leave out the no-threat-for-15-years element. The Government now says that there will be no threat for many years and certainly none at present.

I shall deal with the consequences of that doctrine in a moment, but I submit that defence cannot be considered in isolation. We must look at the other Government actions which support a defence posture. On all those fronts the Government is lacking. The wealth of the country and the industrial capacity to support the high technology that is now involved in military affairs are absolutely important. The will of the nation, the determination of the populace at large to preserve their freedom, and the system of alliances of the country, regional and global, are paramount for a nation as small in population terms as Australia. On every count the Australian Labor Party has sold the country short, it has done nothing to improve the competitiveness of industry or productivity. The present Government's massive deficit is increasingly leading to higher interest payments and higher inflation. It is not creating wealth. It is making it more and more difficult for us to have money to spend on defence in this country and to buy from overseas the weapons systems Australia needs. Despite all its talk of consensus, the present Government is doing nothing to promote the will of the nation. When the present Government first assumed office, we thought it was a neutralist government, but its record in office is clearly that of a pacifist government. There is a world of difference between those two.

The way in which the present Government is promoting world peace movements and other communist front organisations, the development of an Institute of Peace at the Australian National University, the shallowness of the disarmament policies which it promotes on the world stage, with which I shall deal at a future date, are all proof of its pacifist directions. Above all, the Government has damaged Australia and its alliances. There has been a significant shift to the left on where Australia stands in the community of nations. This shift was epitomised by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) who was recently pictured on the front page of all Australian newspapers hugging and kissing the Vietnamese Foreign Minister. That was the Foreign Minister of a country which possesses the worst record of human rights and international relations in the world.

It is a militant communist regime-a country not bound by the rule of law, the conqueror of South Vietnam and Kampuchea, and the country that subdued Laos. It is a country which keeps over 200,000 troops in Kampuchea and which is resettling that country with its own nationals. It is a country with a horrendous human rights record, ranging from the persecution of the ethnic Chinese to the boat people whom they pushed out to drift on the waters of the world. It is a country whose re-education camps are notorious. How many hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese are incarcerated in those camps? The very existence of those camps was denied by Nguyen Co Thach the Vietnamese Foreign Minister when I asked him a question during his appearance before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. He is one of the most charming liars we have ever had in this country. He denied that Vietnam supplied slave labour for the Soviet pipeline, thereby giving a new definition to the phrase 'guest worker'.

These are the sort of people the ALP prefers to have as friends and allies of Australia, along with other sundry terrorist groups such as the Palestine Liberation Organisation, the South West Africa People's Organisation, and the African National Council. The ALP would rather deal with such people than support our traditional friends in the United States of America, the United Kingdom and our regional allies and neighbours.

It is impossible to estimate the damage to Australia's position by the Invincible exercise before Christmas-an exercise that utterly undercut Australia 's reputation as a reliable ally and which has been in no way corrected by the ambivalent statements by the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) after the event. I know from personal experience that the US Defense Department could not believe that Australia could be the perpetrator of such an action.

I turn now to our relationships in the region. Our position with the Association of South East Asian Nations was developed over decades of hard, consistent work by Liberal Foreign Ministers. Australia had earned a responsible position with the countries of South East Asia, a position we did not enjoy before the Second World War. Because of the preference of this Government for the cause of the communists in Vietnam, in September last year we had the debacle over whether the coalition of Kampuchea would take a place in the United Nations and the effect that had on the alliance.

We are retreating from Butterworth although every military analysis points to the need for Australia to maintain our place there. Because Mr Hayden and Mr Hawke want to kowtow to the Vietnamese and because Mr Thach has said it would be a good idea if we got out of Butterworth because it is a bit of a threat to them , we are now packing up and getting out. Butterworth is important to us. It is not a matter of forward defence or any of those semantic arguments. By retaining a presence in Butterworth we dominate the Straits of Malacca, the pathway between the Indian and Pacific Oceans and the South China Sea. We have the ability to monitor and do intelligence-gathering of the Vietnamese in South Vietnam and the whole of the Indo-China area. That is why the Vietnamese communists have put it to Australia that the best thing for international relations between the two countries is that we pack up and go and we are accepting their advice.

Again with respect to relations with ASEAN, we had the dreadfully dishonest position when we misled the ASEAN group as to whether we would support it in co- sponsoring a motion to vote for the coalition Government of Kampuchea being the recognised representatives of Kampuchea in the United Nations. We misled the ASEAN group and turned around and attacked the United States on the ground that it had provoked the ASEAN group to raise a protest. What a travesty! What a lot of good that did the Australian-United States alliance! Never before in the history of Australia have our regional and traditional alliances been strained to the degree that they are today.

It is against this background that the defence of Australia has to be assessed because we stand very much alone at present. The doctrine of this Government, as I said earlier, is the no-threat doctrine. That has a profound effect on Australia's defence capabilities because it paralyses the whole system. It paralyses the development of a force because if there is no threat it logically follows that we do not know what to prepare for. It follows that there are no objectives set for that force. There are no priorities and, most importantly, there is no urgency. We just drift along in an eternal dream time of 'she'll be right', because that is the corollary to the no-threat doctrine. A very damaging aspect of this doctrine is that it creates in the civilian element of the Department of Defence-a large component of the Department, being something in excess of 38,000 people-a feeling of utter cynicism and nihilism. They just do not believe that what they are doing is worth while because they do not believe it is ever going to be put to the test. It would sharpen up their thinking no end if they knew that their necks would be on the block if they made a miscalculation with respect to the defence of this country.

I cannot emphasise stongly enough how inappropriate and destructive this no- threat concept is to the security of this country. I have seen it all before. I was eleven in 1945 at the end of World War II and my memory is good of the six years, between the ages of five and eleven, when we were at war. I remember very clearly the day Darwin was bombed and hearing the news on the radio and going next door to tell the neighbours. I remember the state of utter unpreparedness in which the Labor Government of the time had Australia. Thousands of Australian 18-year olds, hopelessly under-trained in emergency conditions, with obsolete weapons were sent to the front line. They lost their lives in those desperate days purely because we then had a Labor Government which had the same priorities as the Government in Canberra today.

It also follows from the no-threat doctrine that we will have a long lead time. When we talk about a long lead time for defence preparedness in the 1980s we are really in mythology. We will not have any advance warning at all; there is no such thing in the nuclear age. The lead times we had in 1914 and 1939, when we could spend a year or more preparing, are things of the past. We must have a force in being, a force that is ready to go. This is a high technology age. I am not saying that Australia will be involved in a major nuclear war. We could be involved in local conflicts and we could be involved with great rapidity because of the technology of the age. Transport capabilities, communications and weapons systems are such that this country must plan on having no lead time to prepare to look after its essential interests.

We must change from the negativism of the no-threat doctrine to the positivism of the protection of our national interests. Our national interests are quite simple: The defence of Australian territory and the defence of the Australian maritime zone. That means that, as well as being able to hold mainland Australia , we must be able to hang on to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island, Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Island and deny them to the enemy. It means being able to cope with the lodgment of some army force on the Australian mainland. How many people in this chamber realise that the Australian Army, despite its 33 ,000 men, can cope only with anti-terrorist activity? If a brigade or division were put ashore in Australia we simply could not cope with it. This country cannot raise and put in the field at 48 hours notice one fully trained and equipped army battalion. I do not know of one other country in the world that is so poverty stricken with respect to its army. We should forget about the business of satellite technology and star wars in the air and under the water. The Army is essential. Infantry is essential. It is the only way we can hold territory. We must have a force in being. Quite clearly, we cannot have a force that can cope with all conditions and contingencies, but we have to have something and be able to demonstrate the presence of that force so that any attacker realises that he has a threshold to overcome. When we realise that there is a multiplier effect of about three to one on any attacker, the bigger the force we can demonstrate we possess, the more difficult it becomes for anyone to make a lodgment in this country and the virtues of being an island nation are turned to our advantage.

We must dominate these difficulties in relation to defence because they are absolutely vital to our national security, but the problem is not solved by money alone. We do not have enough money to spend on defence at present, but clearly other factors are involved in the disbursement of moneys. We have to make sure that we are getting 100 cents value for every dollar we spend. I do not think that we do. There is waste and inefficiency in the Department of Defence. I think that was shown in the Auditor-General's report tabled here last Tuesday and I hope to come back to that at a future date. It is important not only that we get value for the dollar that we spend but also that the money is spent in the most effective direction for Australia's defence needs.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was on the question of money for defence and I was making the point that the money at present is not adequate. According to the estimates for this year we will spend over $5 billion on defence, about 10 per cent of Federal outlays, or about 3.1 per cent of the gross domestic product. We have to compare that with the smallest expenditure of one of the European countries, about 5 per cent of its gross domestic product; about 8 per cent of that of the United States and 13 per cent of that of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The hard fact of life is that defence costs money, real money. The Australian Labor Party will not recognise that fact. It will not recognise that we need an increase in real terms of around 4 per cent to 5 per cent per year over the next five years just to stay precisely in the position we are in at the moment-which means a decline into obsolescence. It is strange to me that a one per cent Medicare levy can be imposed on this country for a scheme that we do not need. We could disband that. The Labor Party should bring in a one per cent defence levy which is what we do need.
