SPEECH.PARA: At present, on this limited budget, most of the annual expenditure goes to paying for the essential equipment to partly modernise the services that was ordered by the previous Liberal-National Party Government. There is virtually nothing left to run the services on a daily basis. So the exercises are wiped, the budget has been cut by 30 per cent, there is no fuel and there is no ammunition. How can we maintain morale and proficiency on that basis?

We need more money for defence and we need fresh, innovative minds applied to reorganise the three forces. I have had quite a bit to do with the three forces and I will stand second to no one in my admiration for their professionalism. One has to maintain a perspective in this debate about the Australian defence services because with respect to human resources they are absolutely first class . Their problems are organisational and financial. Those forces are not assembled to form an effective whole. In the services we are very much prisoners of the past. For example, the Army still sees itself in the infantry role, its personnel being on foot with rifles and packs on their backs as they were in the Owen Stanleys in 1943. That, of course, is the whole conceptual basis of the Operational Deployment Force.

Australia presents unique problems with respect to its defence needs and therefore it demands its own solutions. I do not accept that the mere refinement of the present forces is all that is required, let alone the best way to go. I strongly support the need for three separate services but we have an overwhelming need for one Australian Defence Force with a common objective for the defence of this country.

In the remaining few minutes I would like to look briefly at some of the salient features that need attention in those three services. The Army is the largest of all three and perhaps most in need of reform. The Army does need to be turned upside down and reorganised, for with 33,000 men and women in uniform it cannot put one battalion into the field in 48 hours. I simply do not have time, in the period remaining, to go into the details but two features that stand out. First of all, the ratio of the fighting elements to the base support numbers is absolutely impossible. If we had had the same ratio in 1939-45 there would not have been enough people in the whole of Australia to keep the four Australian Imperial Force divisions formed and the militia units. Secondly, if the degree of readiness as practised by the Army was applied to the Air Force or the Navy we would have no aircraft in the air and no ships at sea.

I was once a supporter of the concept of the Operational Deployment Force, but having seen it in actuality and having watched it over a period I no longer believe in it. I think it is nonsense. At best it is a meaningless concept and at worst it creates a false sense of security insofar as it pretends to have readiness capability. It simply is not an effective fighting force. It consists of two under strength battalions of 680 men. They are under strength because they are each less one rifle company. It has no armour and no anti-armour capability. It has very limited artillery. It has no tactical mobility, either on land or in the air. Above all it has no reconnaissance capability.

The Navy has major problems also. The most worrying factor there is the no air capability at sea. The Labor Party never thought through the consequences of the abandonment of the Fleet Air Arm. Maybe the carrier had to go but the need remained and there was an obligation on the Labor Party not to denude and leave naked the Navy of this country. It has made no provision at all to fill that gap . We are grossly deficient at sea in anti-submarine capability. We have no air superiority and no air reconnaissance capability. The Government has compounded that error by throwing away some very valuable national defence assets in the form of the Skyhawks and the Trackers which could have been used effectively from shore bases for the rest of their lives. It was only recently that we spent $8m in buying spare parts for the Trackers, which have low time air frames and a long period of life ahead of them. We have a major problem with the surface ships which are now without a carrier. We have the FFGs, which were a disastrous decision of a previous Labor administration, and compounding that problem the Labor Party refuses to buy helicopters to give them an over-horizon targeting capability or an anti-submarine capability.
The Air Force is in many ways the best off, but it must have, as a matter of urgent priority, an air-fuelling capability and an enhanced weapons system.

Finally I mention the matter of command and control of the Australian forces. We have a very long way to go in the Department of Defence, starting with infrastructure, at the intelligence gathering end, right through to the exercise of command. Communications within the Services are better than communications at a joint service level. I do not wish to go too far into this in public but I am alarmed at the position as I have seen it. More importantly, I am alarmed at what we do not have in this dimension. Last of all is the matter of reserves for the Australian forces. We have had a lot of hot air in this place about the morality of tax evaders and others, but what about the morality of a government that promised not to tax payments to reserve forces and then, within months of getting into office, did it and destroyed the morale of the reserves in the process?

We need to consider the civilian component of the Department of Defence. The present system is a proven failure. The Government admits it would never use it in time of war so why then does it survive in time of peace? We are worse off in Australia today than we were in 1939. The Labor Party doctrine of no threat is a doctrine that must be abandoned immediately. The lesson of the Falklands war provided very clear proof that one cannot foresee when emergencies are going to arise and when one will need the defence forces. Britain would never have been able to fight the Falklands war if it had not had the planning done already for a North Atlantic Treaty Organisation operation in relation to Norway. It would never have lost the ships it did if it had taken notice of committees that looked at them and reported on their lack of anti-air capability. The plans were there; the time was not. The important thing is that one goes to war with the equipment one has at the time, not at the convenience of the enemy.

We have some very valuable assets in Australia. We have a nucleus of very dedicated, very able and very professional people in the Services, but they must be reorganised into an organic whole. They must have more money. They must never be placed in the position that a previous Labor government placed them in between 1939-45 when men were sent untrained and poorly equipped to lose their lives in defence of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the previous speaker, Senator MacGibbon, I wish to speak to the specific motion before the Senate. It is no wonder that Senator MacGibbon did not dwell on that for a great length of time in that if we go to the particular aspects and parts of the motion we see that his case really does not have all that much to stand on. Instead of support for this motion over the last 30 minutes of the debate we have had a virago of wild rhetoric, of cold war rhetoric; a virago of allegations showing the mover of the motion as someone without credibility in this area, without credence and without substance. In fact, if Senator MacGibbon is as much a dental expert as he professes to be an expert on foreign affairs and defence, it is little wonder that his constituents in Queensland sent him down to Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: I for one will not go into that sort of cold war rhetoric debate. I want to look at the specific aspects of Senator MacGibbon's motion and put them up for scrutiny by the Senate. The motion comes at the end of a few weeks of statements and rhetoric from the Opposition-from the Minister for Defence in the previous Fraser Government, Mr Sinclair, from Mr Newman and now from Senator MacGibbon- about a supposed run-down in Australia's defence capacity. We have seen an outstanding example of the chameleon culture of the Opposition and its reckless disregard for the truth, despite the fact that it is discussing matters as fundamental as the defence of Australia. Its memory has been shown to be extremely poor. In fact it is members of the Opposition who are threatening Australia's security with their scant regard for the truth, a precedent which they set in government and are now continuing in opposition.

At the outset I remind the Opposition, and especially Senator MacGibbon, of what members of the Opposition were saying about Australia's defence capacity just a year ago. Mr Sinclair, the Minister for Defence, in an article in the Pacific Defence Reporter just over a year ago, in February 1983, entitled 'Time on our Side'-in fact, in his case he almost got a bit of it-responded to a report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, that interpolation 'I think he nearly got a bit of it' is offensive and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—It is also true, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Senator Bolkus, I think that the remark should be withdrawn.
—I withdraw. What did Mr Sinclair say about Australia's defence capacity in the Pacific Defence Reporter of February 1983, 13 or 14 months ago? He made the following points:

SPEECH.PARA: Global nuclear war remains improbable, Australia would not be a principal threat in such a conflict.

The large armies in our region are largely irrelevant to Australia's defence problems, because they are currently unsupported by the substantial maritime and air resources needed to launch and sustain a major military action against Australia as an island nation.
These fundamental considerations provide us with considerable assurance for our own future security.
Australia is able, with its present and planned military capabilities, to make low or intermediate level attacks against it costly and hazardous.
Furthermore we are well equipped to expand these capabilities in the face of an emerging threat.

What has happened in 12 months to change that situation? What has changed? The only thing that has changed is that members of the Opposition were in government then and now they are in opposition. In the first Budget of the Hawke Government expenditure on defence increased by more than 4 per cent in real terms. Senator MacGibbon quibbled about 5 per cent in real terms. We have increased defence expenditure at a time of obvious economic difficulty. We can compare this increase in expenditure with the last Budget of the Fraser Government, in which real defence spending went down by 1.7 per cent. The current Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr Sinclair, is talking about a run-down in defence forces at a time when the Budget increase in that area is 4 per cent in real terms. When he was Minister for Defence he presided over the slashing of defence spending by 1.7 per cent in real terms. So now we are witnessing Opposition spokesmen, including Senator MacGibbon, Mr Newman and Mr Sinclair, proclaiming that the Government should be spending a lot more on defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you the best the Labor Party can do to put its case?

—I do not profess to be an expert on foreign affairs and defence but, given the honourable senator's performance immediately preceding mine and given the degree to which he proclaims himself to be an expert, I do not think the Government need go very far to top him.
—Keep on, if you are the best they have.

—I do not think I am doing too badly. What I am really saying is that it is a case of the Opposition saying: 'Don't do what we have done, don't do what we do; just do what we say regardless of the validity of the rhetoric'. Senator MacGibbon may continue to read his newspaper, but the fact is that the Government in which he was a senior member increased spending on defence by an average of 2.5 per cent per annum throughout its disastrous seven years of office. In our first year we have increased defence spending by 4.1 per cent and , by some strange logic, he claims that this is insufficient, that the previous Government did the job but somehow in 12 months we have let Australia's defence capacity fall down. The fact is that this Government is prepared to spend more on defence than the previous Government, and is now doing so. As I said, we witnessed a strange, rather unethical attack on a foreign politician, who was called a most charming liar. Senator MacGibbon may well have been a party to make an appropriate assessment on that but I think his final judgment was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the specific points of Senator MacGibbon's motion before the chamber. He claims that a totally inadequate share of the Federal Budget is being devoted to the Government's primary responsibility; that is, the defence of the nation. I have touched on that. All I can say is that it is total arrogance and impertinence for Senator MacGibbon, Mr Sinclair and others to raise this point in light of the record, but it is not an arrogance that we on this side are unaccustomed to given the performance of those people in recent years. We have raised defence expenditure in the context of an enormous deficit, one that the Opposition was not prepared to admit to when it was in government, even in its last dying days. It was only when we took over the Treasury benches on 6 March 1983-a date Senator MacGibbon obviously would like to forget-that we discovered the enormity of this country's economic problems. Despite that, despite the explosion in unemployment that took place under the Fraser Government and despite our commitment towards reducing that unemployment, whether by direct or indirect means, we have still found the opportunity and the money in budgetary allocations to raise defence expenditure. That is the record.

Let us look again at the previous Government's record. The previous Minister for Defence, then Mr Killen, one who was more noted for his oratory and his horse racing interests than his ability actually to work with his department and sustain a credible defence program, promised in a White Paper introduced in 1976 -a paper Senator MacGibbon forgot to mention-that resources devoted to defence by his Government would grow by more than 5 per cent per annum. That is the magical figure to which Senator MacGibbon returned today. What happened? In the next year the share of Budget outlays spent on defence fell to below 9 per cent. Although the previous Government promised a real increase of 5 per cent in defence expenditure, real expenditure actually went down. That is the defence record that we have to compare with the Hawke Government's record. So much for paragraph (a). In paragraph (b) Senator MacGibbon refers to the consequential placing of the Australian defence forces in a position from which recovery is now impossible. It is amazing what we are alleged to have done in the last 12 months. I turn to Mr Sinclair, someone for whom I am sure Senator MacGibbon has some respect even though the rest of Australia does not. Just over a year ago Mr Sinclair said:

The long lead-time in years necessary for personnel recruiting and training and manufacturing and acquisition of military hardware determining our defensive capacity is at least five and almost certainly ten years hence. It is the Government's view that this period is within the time frame necessary to identify possible threat ahead and so permit timely expansion, should it be believed necessary.

What has changed since then? As I said earlier, it all changed on 5 March 1983. This Government agrees with that judgment. It is one of the few judgments of Mr Sinclair's with which we do agree. Furthermore, as I have said, unlike the previous Government we are prepared to devote and sustain significant resources in this area. In paragraph (c) Senator MacGibbon refers to the abandonment of plans to provide a platform at sea for both rotary winged and fixed wing aircraft. I turn for a moment to fixed wing aircraft and to all the items in Senator MacGibbon's motion on which he chose not to dwell. It should be remembered that fixed wing naval aviation effectively ceased under the previous Government when the HMAS Melbourne was tied up in 1982. There was then no prospect of another platform being acquired that would be capable of operating the Skyhawks. The decision was announced by Sir James Killen on 29 April 1982. Let us not lay the blame on this Government.

I turn to rotary winged aircraft. Senator MacGibbon, in running away from the truth, neglected to mention that it is this Government's commitment-a commitment that is on record-that there will be, in the future, many sea-going platforms operating helicopters for anti-submarine warfare. The Government has already announced plans to acquire new anti-submarine helicopters for the guided missile frigates now entering service. It has also announced that our support ships will be able to operate them. This sort of flexibility is something that would not come from Senator MacGibbon's proposal.
Paragraph (d) of Senator MacGibbon's proposal states:
. . . the criminal negligence in disbanding the Fleet Air Arm whose continued existence was a national defence asset even if no sea-born platforms were available in the short term;

I read that out because we need to compare Sentor MacGibbon's rhetoric with the truth and with his motion. The truth is that the Government is not disbanding the Fleet Air Arm. No wonder, once again, Senator MacGibbon did not touch on this. Quite the opposite is happening. Planning is continuing for a significant expansion in the numbers of rotary winged aricraft. It has been announced that a new helicopter is to be introduced into the service. Where then is the credibility of Senator MacGibbon, the self-proclaimed expert on foreign affairs and defence? I will go on because the more I go on the more embarrassed Senator MacGibbon should feel in bringing up this matter, wasting the time of the Senate with a spurious motion and placing on the Notice Paper something that does not hold substance.

In paragraph (e) of his motion he claims that the Government has failed to provide helicopters for the FFGs for the Navy. The truth is that it has been announced that the Government gives high priority to the acquisition of new helicopters for the FFGs. The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) said that the types of helicopters available earlier for the FFGs were of older technology and limited capability and were judged unsuited for Australia's needs. The previous coalition Government-the Government of which Senator MacGibbon was a member, even though he may have slept through it-accepted this position. Under the Hawke Government tenders have been issued for two designs of helicopters which were not previously available. These tenders are currently being evaluated. One cannot do everything in the space of 12 months. Senator MacGibbon's Government had seven years to do it.

Senator MacGibbon's motion then criticises the decision to buy two more FFGs, claiming that that decision did not recognise the totally incorrect decision, as he called it, by a previous Labor government to buy this class of ship for the Royal Australian Navy. He claimed that the decision made between 1972 and 1975 was wrong, that the design was totally inadequate for Australia's needs and that our continuation along this line is something that should be corrected. What is the truth in respect of Senator MacGibbon's claim? The truth is that the previous Labor Government in fact put in action a program to acquire the first two FFGs from the United States of America. What Senator MacGibbon neglected to mention in his motion was that the subsequent coalition Government, his Government, reviewed the decision when it achieved office. What did it do then? It completed the contracts and the formalities and went ahead and bought the two FFGs early in 1976. It ordered a further two FFGs in 1977 and in 1980. The present Labor Government is continuing the program which was set out between 1972 and 1975. That program was adopted, after review, by Senator MacGibbon's side of this Parliament. It is apparent that this Government and the previous coalition Government was satisfied by their actions that this class of ship most adequately meets Australia's defence needs.

Paragraph (g) of the motion states that the Government failed to move purposefully to provide adequate airborne refuelling aircraft for the RAAF. The capacity exists at the moment. The Royal Australian Air Force already possesses four Boeing 747 aircraft that will be modified. Senator MacGibbon knows about that. The F111 strike reconnaissance aircraft can be refuelled in flight. There will be extended capacity in this area. As I said, the truth and the rhetoric do not come together at all. So it goes on. His claim that there was a failure to provide any airborne early warning aircraft can be discussed, but we know that Government priority is already being given to an over-the-horizon radar which is operating as project Jindalee and which we feel and the previous Government felt would adequately cover our needs in this area.

The man who talked wildly about nuclear war and about no notice being given in, as he called it, the Goebbels network-I think that slip is probably quite appropriate in this instance-went from nuclear warfare to the inadequate provision of boots and clothing. He did not substantiate his claims there at all . It just reads good on the Notice Paper. It might get him a bit of publicity in northern Queensland. But it is all rhetoric; is is all shallow and lacks substance. If he can come up with specific allegations, let him substantiate them. He did not do that today in the 30 minutes in which he spoke. He did not do it because he could not substantiate the allegations.

The one point to which he returned time and time again was the claim that there was a very depressed state of morale in the Australian defence forces arising, as he said, from the aforementioned factors and others. Senator MacGibbon may know one or two people in the defence forces but I shall quote from a recent statement by the Chief of the Defence Force Staff. Let us see how that stands with the network which Senator MacGibbon claims to have. The Chief of the Defence Force Staff said that he is satisfied that the overall morale and spirit of the defence forces remain high. He blames the lack of morale on the housing situation. Let us look at the facts. The housing situation is largely a legacy of the previous Government, the Fraser Government, the Government of which Senator MacGibbon was a member. What did he do about it then? What did he do when the iniquitous Garland report was adopted by the Government? That report stalled progress in the area. He did nothing. Despite the legacy left to this Government, it has started initiatives to upgrade existing homes and to add to the total inventory.

In the 20 minutes that I have been speaking I have managed to scrutinise and assess Senator MacGibbon's motion which is before this chamber. As I said, it is little wonder that what we got in lieu of substance from Senator MacGibbon was cold war rhetoric. It was rhetoric that we, as rational beings in this place, should reject out of hand. Cold war rhetoric can only be substantiated by baseless allegations. That is what we have seen this evening. It is quite ironic that, on a day when we have debated as a matter of public importance the question of disarmament, Senator MacGibbon and his colleagues are prepared to come in here and present a false claim of neglect in the defence forces. I have not attempted to argue the merits of increased defence spending or otherwise. What I have done is looked at the allegations made by Senator MacGibbon, Mr Sinclair and Mr Newman, who are all tin soldiers, and rejected them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to Senator Bolkus decrying Senator MacGibbon's excellent speech in the Senate in which he told us of the many inadequacies that exist in the Department of Defence and the Department of Defence Support. It is appropriate that I should speak in support of Senator MacGibbon's motion because I feel very strongly about the inadequate provision being made for the defence of our nation by this Government. Yesterday I moved a motion along similar lines to the motion that Senator MacGibbon put forward expressing concern over this Government's restraints in the area of defence training and maintenance schedules. I consider that the Government is not doing enough to encourage domestic industry to participate in Australian design, development and production for defence purposes, an initiative which, in my opinion, would help Australian industry to regain some international competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Labor Government the Australian Defence Force is suffering severely. Despite what Senator Bolkus says, there has been a rundown in equipment, spare parts, ammunition and fuel; exercising has been restricted; morale is low and, most significantly, no clear direction for the future is being given. Indeed, the situation has reached the alarming stage where the Department of Defence has admitted that Australia would have difficulty in maintaining security against a low level threat. For any government to have placed the security of our nation in such a precarious position is, in my opinion, unforgivable.

The very instability of world affairs at present and the pressures apparent in our region require Australia to have a defence capability with a large measure of self-sufficiency and mobility. Surely the defence of Australia, its territories, maritime zones and legitimate national interests is the first duty of an Australian government-whether it be a Labor or Liberal-National Party government. However, uncertainties about foreign policy and the provision of defence aid to countries in our regions, the fiasco over the dry-docking of HMS Invincible, about which Senator MacGibbon told us very clearly and distinctly, and the continued imprecision over the policy on visits of allied warships, have all left Australia isolated from our friends at a time of considerable global tension.

Labor's funding cuts have affected establishment levels in regular and Reserve forces, flying and steaming times for aircraft and ships, training levels in the three Services, the maintenance of stocks of fuel, munitions and spare parts and the scrapping of school cadets. I feel that the cadet corps should be re- established. School cadets are very important not only because they are trained for a future in the forces but also because they receive discipline. I believe many young men in the cadet corps, and girls also, are missing something because they are not able to have such training. Policy changes have affected servicemen 's Defence Force retirement and death benefits commutation tax liability and Reserve personnel pay taxation. I and other honourable senators have received many letters about this. Those changes have prejudiced morale. Service housing and base maintenance need significant additional investment. Yet the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) has said that he cannot guarantee that next year's Budget will even maintain the present defence allocation. The Australian defence forces have already been weakened by the decision against an aircraft carrier, by the scrapping of the Fleet Air Arm's fixed wing capability and by training cuts to the three Services and to the reserves. But with present defence cutbacks, Australia's position will deteriorate even further.

Nobody wants war. I believe the present horrific occurrences in the Middle East make us all well aware of the futility of nations going to war. However, to make provisions for the adequate defence of one's nation from attack is as much a form of necessary self-defence as making one's home safe from the mindless attacks of vandals and burglars. Nobody likes war, but it does go on. To turn one's back on it and pretend that if we do not equip ourselves properly against attack everyone will think that we are a peaceful nation and no one will attack us is absolute stupidity.

The Labor Government's neglect of the defence of our nation is tantamount to it declaring that the Australian people are not worth protecting, that the magnificent country of Australia is not worth protecting, that if potential invaders really want us that badly they can just come in and take us. I do not believe that the majority of Australians would take very kindly to that suggestion. I believe the majority of Australians would like to see-indeed, I would say they would expect to see-a more adequate defence of their homeland. I believe the significant shortfalls highlighted in the submission of the Department of Defence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence show the critical necessity for higher priority to be given to defence in this country.

The prime role of the Australian Defence Force should be the deterrence of any threat to Australian territory or our national interests and the maintenance of an ability to respond to any defence emergency affecting these, independently of our major allies. Yet the Department of Defence has admitted that Australia would have difficulty in maintaining security against even a low level threat. The Australian Defence Force should be able to meet such military obligations as may be required and without detriment to its prime role, our treaty arrangements under ANZUS and the five power defence pact, in accordance with Australia's membership of the United Nations and the Commonwealth and as a participant in such other multinational force arrangements as are in Australia's interests. I regret very much that this is not possible under the present Government's lack of commitment to this vital part of Australia's security and future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to say that the Australian Democrats cannot support the motion because of its wording and its scatter-gun approach. At the same time it does bring up some points that need to be discussed and I would like to look at a couple of those in practical terms in a moment or two. To say that the Senate condemns the Government for its abandonment of the maintenance of an adequate defence force for Australia, I think, is a rather strange irony from a Liberal senator in view of the fact that the Labor Government has been in office for only a year. As Senator Bolkus said, there are considerable lead times, as we all know, in providing defence equipment. I believe it is a very extreme statement. If the Senate says that it condemns the Government for its abandonment of the maintenance of an adequate defence force for Australia, ipso facto it is condemning the previous Government . I do not think that is quite what Senator MacGibbon intended, but of course that would have to be the effect of this motion if it were carried.

SPEECH.PARA: Anybody in his right senses knows that nobody can put together a defence policy and implement it in a year. I think that anybody who has read what has gone on and listened to the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) and others will see that the Government does seem to be showing encouraging signs of an approach to defence. Indeed, when the Minister for Defence made a comprehensive statement last November about the Government's thinking, we went so far as to say that we might get, for the first time, an army actually capable of defending Australia in the case of invasion, which we have certainly not had in the past. I agree with Senator MacGibbon that we do not have that now. One hopes that Mr Scholes and the Government will go ahead along the lines that they proposed and that this is not mere empty rhetoric. Both have said that they want to plan a flexible and highly mobile land force armed with modern weapons. Of course, that is what we need. The plans which the Minister outlined in his statement were a very promising beginning to implementing the concept. They showed that the Government had set its face against the blandishments of those who might seek to return to the old fashioned concept of a military force designed for foreign adventures but of little use for defence of the homeland.

In foreseeable circumstances, if there is a major war in this world, we will be very much on our own and our major allies will be very much preoccupied and perhaps even mauled to the extent that, with the best intentions in the world, there can be no question of their coming to our assistance. It is a fact that the United States of America has told us time and time again that we are foolish if we rely on the idea of holding out our hand to uncle, who will come and help us. That is not a criticism of the United States or its intentions towards us. It is merely looking at the realities. The Government plans to spend money on trucks and it is planning for a new light armoured fighting vehicle and a new parachute training school to be built at Nowra. I hope that goes ahead soon, and that it is large enough and effective enough. It has plans also for specialised guerrilla-type forces and reconnaissance units and is putting much greater stress on helicopters and modern missile systems for the Army. All of these are thoughts in the right direction. Honourable senators have a responsbility to keep an eye on what the Government does while it remains in office, to see that those sorts of things come to pass, and that the Government does not just make pious utterances. Short of nuclear war, the most likely threat to Australia would be a regional war of some kind. Australians in general expect the Government to develop progressively an Army that could meet and counter any threat to our soil from such a development.

I want to turn briefly to a question which was raised by Senator MacGibbon, but he did not say much about it. In relation to the Fleet Air Arm, he referred to the criminal negligence in disbanding the Fleet Air Arm, whose continued existence was a national defence asset even if no seaborne platforms were available in the short term. In this context I should draw attention to some comments that I have no doubt other honourable senators saw in the Pacific Defence Reporter of last August from Mr A. W. Grazebrook about the Arapaho containerised helicopter systems. I quote from his succinct and admirable article on the subject:

Arapaho is a system whereby standard-size containers, fitted out for maintenance, fuel, communications, operations control, ammunition, landing facilities, and air and maintenance personnel accommodation are embarked in a container ship.

This system has been developed by the United States and has been tried successfully by the United States Navy. Mr Grazebrook pointed out that the British Navy has leased the United States Navy's Arapaho equipment and chartered the container ship Astronomer in which it will test the Arapaho equipment at sea . The interesting thing about that is the new ship, that is, the Royal Navy ship Reliant, will be able to accommodate a total of six Sea Kings, with four in the hangars and two on landing spots. That is important to Australia, because the Royal Australian Navy has Sea Kings, complete with fully trained crews and operations and maintenance personnel ashore at Nowra.

It is interesting too, when one considers the very high cost of defence material, that Mr Grazebrook has estimated that, given that the RAN has the Sea Kings and the necessary maintenance and communications equipment ashore at Nowra , it would cost less than $A20m to fit out a normal roll-on roll-off container ship to get the Sea Kings to sea. That seems to be very economical, especially as he says that, of the $20m, more than 80 per cent would be spent in Australia. That is another good argument. The Australian Democrats, I believe, were the first to raise a protest against the asinine idea of buying a slow, short-deck carrier for this country. Thank God that concept has been laid to rest forever! That does not mean that we are opposed to the Fleet Air Arm; far from it. I commend the Government to listen to Mr Grazebrook and, if it has not done so, to consider the Arapaho system. For the $20m involved it would be well worth while following the lead of the Royal Navy and checking this out for ourselves. That would give us a situation where we would have a possibility in wartime of taking container ships round our coast and converting them rapidly to that kind of defence system.

While on the subject, it is interesting that if one reads the brochures on the Sea Harrier aircraft one finds that the same system is possible with the Sea Harriers. We can get a two-container system, one of which contains the aircraft and one of which contains its control systems, and it can be put on to virtually any ship. Certainly ships of the size of the coastal container ships around the Australian coast could accommodate that system. This approach towards naval and sea defence is a good one, because it does give us flexibility. It would allow us to use the facilities round our coast at a time of major war, when our merchant ships would not want to go very far out to sea without having some armament, for they would be sunk anyway. I commend that idea. Also, if we are going to go into the Sea Harrier business, that might be a way of getting into it without incurring too much expense. This presupposes that it is rational to have any kind of blue water fleet in time of war. That is what navies are for, after all. They are not to have parties on the quarterdeck regularly, which seems to me to be one of the principal functions in the life of a carrier in the modern world. As any naval flyer from any nation will say, any carrier is a sitting duck if it goes to sea in any war that is likely to occur in the foreseeable future. With Hunter killer submarines capable of attacking at 40 knots or more, it is obvious that that is the case.
I believe that Senator MacGibbon might have a point in paragraph (f) of his motion which states:

The decision to buy two more FFG's and not recognise the totally incorrect decision by a previous Labor Government to buy this class of ship for the Royal Australian Navy, a design which is completely inadequate for Australia's needs.

The point has been made by a government speaker since that the Liberal Government did not change this policy; it went ahead with the FFGs. It seemed rather strange to me when I was in Seattle a couple of years ago, where the FFGs were built, that they were regarded by the US Navy, where they originated, as being very much ships that were used in large numbers. They were not regarded as the sort of ships that can carry out isolated defence on their own behalf. Indeed, they need constant mother ship or repair facilities near to them, due to the fact that they have only one propeller. It seemed that any arrangement which provided that the principal modern naval missile ship for this Navy should have only one propeller was a disaster of the first order. We agree with Senator MacGibbon on that point.

While I was in Seattle I was fortunate to be at the final sea trials of USS Taurus, which was the final Pegasus class hydrofoil missile attack ship being delivered by Boeing Marine to the United States Navy. While I was there I talked to the Boeing Marine people who build these ships. I must say that I was impressed with these hydrofoils. They are quite remarkable ships. I have since mentioned to the Defence Ministers of both governments that we ought to consider those ships because of their low profile, high speed, flexibility, low cost and enormous hitting power. It is striking, in view of the comments that have been made about the FFGs, which cost something like $250m. Fully armed, the hydrofoils cost about $75m each. One of the PHMs, as they are called, can fire its eight harpoon missiles, which are on lightweight launchers, in 13 to 20 seconds-a vastly superior rate of fire to an FFG frigate, which can fire four harpoon missiles in 40 seconds.

The Indonesians-not that I am particularly pointing the bone at them-are buying Boeing PHMs. If those PHMs ever get within striking distance or there is any close range conflict between them and our FFGs, will the FFGs come off second best. A much smaller, much cheaper, much more lightly manned ship will clobber them. That is a good comment on the inadvisability of relying too much on that kind of ship. They are regarded as a blue water ship and are not capable of carrying armaments or any of the facilities that would protect them against nuclear attack submarines. Those ships would be at risk from the very moment they put to sea. The great advantage of the hydrofoils is that they are a coastal defence system and would match in very neatly with our FA18 fighters, providing an adequate naval and air defence capability, preferably along our northern coast. Manning is one of the great expenses. It was going to be one of the enormous expenses involved with the short-deck carrier. A PHM can be manned by 21 men, so we can buy about 14 of them for the cost of a short-deck carier and man them for about half the complement. The Australian Democrats commend the PHM to the Government and remind the Government that this is an area in which they might consider some expansion of our Navy in the future. I have had some discussions with naval officers who are very keen on those ships, especially the younger naval officers who are not on the captains list but who command our smaller ships and who will soon be on the captains list and who will run the Navy of the future.

While on the subject, I plead with the Government at least to consider some system whereby we might at least fit some of our Fremantle class ships with missiles and thereby make some of our younger and more enthusiastic naval officers happy that they will be at least in command of a warship that has some kind of capability other than a World War II bofors gun on the foredeck. That is what the Fremantle class ships have. I am reliably informed that they are not even capable, with those bofors guns, of putting a shot across the bows of a Taiwanese fishing boat in any kind of bad weather. Of course, the place for those guns in not the foredeck of a small ship. They were never designed for that and they are an utterly inappropriate type of armament. It is a pity because the Fremantle class ship is really a first class small warship in its own way. It has the space to accommodate missile systems. It has the channelling for them. It is high time the Government considered at least turning some of them into real warships so that, if ever there were an emergency or time of war, they would be of some use in the defence of this country. I defy anybody in the Senate to claim that in their present state they would be of any more use in a war situation than a rubber duck. Surely we do not want that situation to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -Senator MacGibbon, in bringing forward for discussion this matter of defence, has served an excellent purpose for the Senate and, more particularly, the Australian people. It is an area in which all Australians need to be involved. All Australians should take a realistic view of possible threats and the capacity we may need as time goes by to meet those threats. As this operation involves a consideration of our defence capacity and the sorts of commitments we may need to meet, it serves a very real purpose not only in this place but hopefully in the wider area of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated when I heard one or two of the matters brought forward tonight . I recall the words of Senator Bolkus which were a mixture of abuse and perverted humour. He more or less implied that the previous Government had left a dreadful legacy of Australian defence incapacity. Of course, when one looks at the missile firing frigates of the Royal Australian Navy, at the Orions, the Oberon submarines, HMAS Tobruk and the F111s, which are still the most sophisticated aircraft and the most effective strike aircraft in this part of the world; when one looks at and recalls the Australian helicopters which are serving today with distinction and effect with Australian pilots in the Sinai; when one recalls the capacities and development of the Special Air Service Regiment in Western Australia, probably one of the finest military units of its type in the world; when one thinks of the patrol boats that the coalition Government of yesteryear developed and which are continuing to be developed; and when one thinks of their bases in Darwin and Cairns and the significant capacity of the trainees in the forces, one has to recognise that Australia's capacity to defend itself is significant. It has a considerable capital asset, a considerable equipment capacity to meet the tasks that may confront it from time to time.

The significance of this debate is that 12 months after the change of government, rather than observing an increase in our defence capacity, we have seen a disastrous decline. Bearing that in mind it is important that this debate should continue and that we analyse the circumstances relating to the defence of this continent and, indeed, of the region.

I recall that Senator Mason has great knowledge of aircraft carriers and ships in general and I now note that he has recognised the failure to be accurate with a 20 millimetre gun on a patrol boat. Of course, that is a very accurate observation on his part. But he also said that he thought aircraft carriers were literally sitting ducks. One got the impression of their being sent to the bottom almost by the dozen. Of course, the fact is that only one aircraft carrier has ever been sunk by land-based aircraft. Indeed, their capacity to defend themselves is enormous. Their effectiveness as command ships and as central operating units in the defence of sea lanes is probably second to none. I really do not share the view of Senator Mason that aircraft carriers are little more than sitting ducks. It is hard to understand why several hundred of them are around the seas of the world today and are significant units in the navies of the United States of America, the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, France, Italy and so on. Either an enormous number of mistakes and miscalculations have been made by the naval people in particular, and the defence people in general, around the world, or Senator Mason's authority is not as great as he imagines.

I would have hoped that, with the circumstances of the last 12 months, with the Australian economy developing significantly in line with a lifting of the recession around the world and particularly in the United States-the Australian economy has been blessed at long last with the breaking of the most disastrous drought we have ever known-and while there is the prospect of increased revenue and perhaps more buoyant circumstances, one of the first things a responsible government would have done would be to increase the emphasis on defence. That does not appear to be the case. Indeed, I regret that it appears to be the contrary. We have virtually sold out our naval air capacity. There is total abandonment of the concept of an aircraft carrier which we so nearly had two or three years ago. Apparently, there is no concern to establish even platforms that will be of significant use in handling helicopters and vertical take-off aircraft.

The circumstances that confront us today are vastly different from the economic circumstances that confronted this country 18 months to 2 years ago. These things should now be feasible options for the Government, and are indeed distinctly relevant to a government's first responsibility. Above all things, a government must surely be concerned to establish the security of its nation. Indeed, it must be responsible enough to be involved with the region and ultimately, I suppose, with security around the world. However, its own security is certainly its first obligation. Its attitude to health, education, communications-to a whole range of necessary matters-is secondary to the circumstances that will dictate its capacity to defend itself and to enable these other enormously important areas to be researched and implemented.

Senator MacGibbons's motion suggests that the Government appears to be abandoning the maintenance of an adequate defence force in Australia. Indeed, there is very significant proof that that is the circumstance. It seems to me that we should be looking at a whole range of things that are relevant to the defence of this country. In the first place, although clearly there is no acutely identified threat to this country either in form or in time, unquestionably there are at least three areas of possible threat which we should be seeking to establish a capacity to meet. In the first place, we should be aware of the threat of terrorist activity, both from within-that is, on-shore- and off-shore. It is enormously important for us to be able to defend our oil installations and other important port facilities. We should be developing a capacity, in terms of both men and machines, to defend any possible terrorist activity in those areas.

Of course, it is important that we should look beyond our coastline to the region in which we are a very significant partner. Indeed, the security and development of the South Pacific region to which we belong is largely dependent on our capacity and determination to have a clear facility to defend it. Besides the terrorist situation, one has to be aware of the possibility of warfare of one kind and another, insurrection and difficulties experienced by our neighbours. It must be assumed that we would have the capacity and determination to help our neighbours meet those difficulties should they arise. So we have to have a capacity to move beyond our own shores and to give our troops not only carriage but also cover in meeting obligations within our region.

When we look even beyond our region it seems to me that in the wider view we should have a realisation of the demands of defence in a forward circumstance. We have screens beyond this country to which we should be willing and able to contribute a measure of defence capacity. It is in that area that the Butterworth base in Malaysia is so important. I am surprised and disappointed to observe that apparently the Government intends to scale down our involvement to the extent that a squadron will be based at Butterworth perhaps on a temporary basis for only one-third of the year and that ultimately our presence there might be eliminated altogether. It was and is the intention of the coalition to base a squadron of FA18 aircraft at Butterworth when those aircraft become available. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out earlier, such a squadron in such a position would make a very significant contribution to the defence not only of Australia but also of the whole region to our north.

Talking of the region to our north brings me to a consideration of the necessity for our foreign affairs relationships and our defence considerations to be closely related. I am quite concerned about some of the revelations of recent times in regard to the abrasive circumstance that has developed between Australia and our Association of South East Asian Nations neighbours. Indeed, the countries of ASEAN have proved to be a real bastion against the communist nations of the Asiatic mainland. Dennis Warner, a very experienced correspondent in South East Asian politics, certainly is of the view that although the disastrous, sad and tragic Vietnamese War resulted in a loss measured in terms of the foreseeable future as far as the history books are concerned, it may well have provided sufficient time-a sort of vacuum in time-during which the countries of ASEAN were able to consolidate regimes and their defensive capacity and to become a bulwark, if you like, in the South East Asian area against the spread of communism.

The spread of the communist power and influence in that part of the world is not really a dream; it is quite factual. The Vietnamese are still 100,000 or 200 ,000 strong in Cambodia, where they are playing the role virtually of Soviet puppets. They have extended to the Soviets the use of the facilities of Kham Ran Bay in Vietnam. This has meant the establishment of a very significant Soviet naval force in that part of the world, which lies astride the oil routes and general trade routes from the Gulf area to Japan and East Asia and, indeed, to the Pacific itself. All of those factors have increased the tensions of the area . They have also increased the need for Australian defence awareness and for Australia's capacity and determination to defend itself and play a very real part in the defence of its region.

A little earlier in this debate mention was made of the lead time that is required to provide the sorts of facilities and equipment that are necessary in a rapidly changing defensive and armament capacity. Because of that lead time Australia should now be looking-I have seen no evidence that the present Federal Government is looking-towards the establishment of the sort of equipment that will be needed in the next five, 10 or 15 years. We should be looking at converting Boeing 707s for air refuelling; at introducing airborne early warning aircraft; at purchasing anti-submarine warfare helicopters and vertical take off aircraft with appropriate platforms. This country should look ultimately to the need to replace the Oberon class submarine. In that context it is surely not unreal to look, in terms of five or ten years hence, at nuclear powered submarines as the most effective weapon for a country that is so far from the major population centres of the world, surrounded as it is by massive ocean areas.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, there is no apparent immediate threat in this part of the world and we should be thankful that that is the case but, regrettably, the world is unstable. For example, there is warfare in North Africa and in the Middle East-and indeed in many parts of the Middle East area where there is no actual warfare there is a dicey type of peace. There are problems in South West Asia, continuing warfare in areas of South East Asia, and problems in Central America. The circumstances that surround Australia immediately may in relative terms be peaceful, but the circumstances in the world in general are far from peaceful. One adds to all the problems I have mentioned continuing terrorist attacks which cause unstable conditions in the world. Australia should be seeking to upgrade its present equipment and to establish the training facilities in the air, on the sea and on the land that this country needs, but should also seek to ensure that the sort of equipment this nation is likely to need in five, 10 or 15 years is on its way. I seek leave to contunie my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 May 1983, on motion by Senator Lewis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has proposed as a private member's Bill a Bill for an Act to establish Anzac Day as a national day of remembrance, which is uncontroversial, but also to provide for observances in the Australian Capital Territory to mark Anzac Day. The provisions of the Bill designed to achieve that objective are very much more controversial. The Government, as a result, opposes Senator Lewis's Bill. Though we endorse the sentiments contained in clause 4 of the Bill about Anzac Day being appropriately marked as a national day of remembrance, though we acknowledge the enormous significance of Anzac Day not only in our history but also in terms of our whole national culture, though we are anxious that the day be commemorated in Canberra and elsewhere with all the solemnity and dignity appropriate to the occasion, though we fully appreciate the values of respect for personal sacrifice which lie behind observance of the day, we consider that the solutions proposed in the Bill to the problems which have arisen in the Anzac Day march and ceremony in Canberra in recent years are unacceptable. There are better ways, which I shall outline, to ensure appropriate commemoration of the occasion, but in a way that does not undermine the democratic values for which so many Australians in so many wars fought and died.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of reasons why Senator Lewis's Bill in its present form is quite unacceptable. I shall spell them out to the House. In the first place the Bill would place the arrangement of appropriate Anzac day observances in the Australian Capital Territory in the hands of the President of the Returned Services League of Australia. He would be empowered to designate areas for such observances and to grant permission to persons or classes of persons to participate in such observances. Under the provisions of the Bill the Federal Court of Australia would have the power to review such decisions. Senator Lewis' s Bill is novel in placing significant public powers with the president of a private organisation, overriding other Commonwealth legislation in the process- for example, the Australian War Memorial Act 1980-placing areas of the Territory under the control of government bodies.

The second problem of the Bill is that the review power vested in the Federal Court is severely limited to altering the designation of an area or a decision of the President refusing a person or group permission to participate where the alteration would be consistent with the establishment of Anzac Day as a national day of remembrance. The third problem-perhaps the most significant problem of all-is that the Bill would abrogate the right of peaceful assembly for all persons in areas designated by the President of the RSL in the Australian Capital Territory, unless the President chose to allow those persons to participate in such observances as he may have arranged, and there is a limited power of review of his decision. The Bill would clearly impinge upon the civil liberties of citizens in the Australian Capital Territory. While the right of assembly guaranteed by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights recognises that some restrictions may be placed legitimately on this right, the provisions in the Bill, in the view of the Government, go quite beyond what may be regarded as restrictions which are necessary in the interests of public order .

The fourth problem in the Bill-this is not a product of any knowledge on my part but speculation which may well be relevant-is that Senator Lewis's Bill may not accomplish his intention, presumably, to preserve Anzac Day in the Australian Capital Territory for RSL marches without disturbance by others. It may be the case that the RSL would not welcome the legislation as that organisation would be put to considerable expense in publishing in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notices of arrangements for observances, designed at areas and permissions to participate-not least the expenses that may be associated in defending those decisions in subsequent court proceedings.

The fifth problem that appears in the Bill is that clearly there would be considerable difficulty in listing, not less than 90 days before Anzac Day in any year, all persons allowed to attend without requiring them to seek permission. Thus, many people wishing merely to view the parade could be excluded from traditional viewing areas. Otherwise protesting groups could join spectators along the route of the Anzac day parade even though the RSL said they were unable to join the parade. In 1982 the RSL objected to the presence, on a knoll behind the main Anzac Day ceremony in front of the Australian War Memorial , of Women Against Rape in War, but this sort of protest would not be prevented by Senator Lewis's Bill. The Government believes that the inevitable result of the enactment of the Bill would be to create many more problems than it solves.

It may be that many of the problems in the Bill would be avoided if the amendments circulated by the Australian Democrats were accepted. That series of amendments adopts a fairly robust approach towards the legislation and strips away from it almost all of its substantive provisions so far as they govern the role of the President of the RSL and the whole question of designated areas and limitations on rights of access to those designated areas. Practically all the Democrats' amendments leave intact is clause 4 of the Bill which I will read into the record as follows:

It is hereby declared that it is the intention of the Parliament that Anzac Day should be marked as a national day of remembrance for the purpose of commemorating members of Australian armed forces and their auxiliary services who served Australia in the cause of freedom and who suffered death, injury or loss as a result of their service as members of those forces in the course of armed conflicts in which those forces were engaged.

Apart from that, the only thing that the Bill, as amended by the Democrats, would leave intact is the provision authorising the House of Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory in effect to proscribe of its own authority and in the exercise of an open-ended discretion the way in which Anzac Day would be commemorated in the Australian Capital Territory. By arrangement, and to assist public debate on the issues that are involved in this legislation and in the counter proposals, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full text of the Democrats proposed amendments.
Leave granted.
The amendments read as follows:
(1) Page 1, clause 3, definition of ''observance'', leave out ''the President'' , insert ''House of Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory''.
(2) Page 1, clause 3, definition of ''Returned Services League of Australia'', leave out the definition.
(3) Page 2, clause 3, definition of ''the Court'', leave out the definition.
(4) Page 2, clause 3, definition of ''the President'', leave out the definition .
(5) Clause 5 to be opposed.
(6) Page 2, clause 6, sub-clause (1), leave out ''the President'', insert ''the House of Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory''.
(7) Page 2, clause 6, sub-clause (1), leave out ''he'' insert ''it''.
(8) Page 2, clause 6, sub-clauses (2), (3), (4) and (5), leave out the sub- clauses.
(9) Clauses 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14 and 15 to be opposed.

While the Government sees some merit in a Bill which would contain, as I have said several times, the kind of declaratory provision that is contained in clause 4 of the Bill, we do not however believe that it is appropriate that the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, at least in these pre-self- government days, should be left with the open-ended authority to proscribe, presumably in a legislative fashion, the appropriate measures for the observance of Anzac Day or any other public march, ceremony or protest in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Government believes that the preferable course is to promulgate a new public assemblies ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory. My colleague, the Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren, has already announced that that is the Government's intention. This legislation, unlike Senator Lewis's Bill, will guarantee to the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory the right of peaceful assembly which is recognised in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The new Government legislation, like the public assemblies legislation in force in New South Wales and South Australia, will provide for the prior notification to the police of public assemblies. Assemblies so notified will enjoy immunity from prosecution for obstruction of persons or traffic. The onus will be on the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to apply to the Supreme Court for an order prohibiting the holding of a public assembly if he is of the opinion that it would not be in the public interest for it to be held. In forming this opinion, the Commissioner will be required to have regard to the right of peaceful assembly, recognised in the Civil and Political Rights Covenant, and any likelihood that if the assembly were to be held serious public disorder would be occasioned, the safety of any person would be placed in jeopardy, damage to property would be occasioned or the assembly would cause an obstruction that in the circumstances would be of unreasonable size or duration. The Supreme Court, in determining whether to prohibit the holding of an assembly, will be required under the proposed legislation to have regard to the same considerations. The right of peaceful assembly will thus be recognised and assemblies will be prohibited under the Civil and Political Rights Covenant.

The biggest problem in designing a public assemblies ordinance of general application is the problem of so-called competing assemblies. This after all was the central problem which arose in Canberra in 1981 when we had the Anzac Day marchers on the one hand and the group calling itself Women Against Rape in War on the other. It was that conflict or clash between the so-called competing assemblies, although in this instance they shared many values, that led to the extraordinary proposal in the 1982 ordinance which was much debated in this place for the concept of a limited participation assembly, a concept which seems to flow through into at least some of the conceptual thinking behind Senator Lewis's Bill.

The Government is now considering a legislative model for dealing with this problem of competing assemblies which I outlined very briefly in the course of the 1982 debate. If adopted, I believe it would be both defensible in principle, securing a balance between the interests of the original participants in the assembly and those whose presence might offend them, and at the same time be capable of practical operation. Such a model would contain three elements. The first element would be that the conduct is objectively likely to occasion a breach of the peace. This sort of consideration is appropriately expressed in the language of the first part of clause 24 (2) as it appears in the Public Assemblies Ordinance of 1982, namely:

. . . a police officer of or above the rank of sergeant has reasonable grounds for believing that the conduct of a person in or near a public assembly is likely to cause or provoke a breach of the peace by any person.

But this is a necessary, not a sufficient requirement. If it stands alone as it does in the 1982 ordinance, it would in effect enable participants in an authorised assembly, for example RSL members, to demand the removal of other protesters, for example, Women Against Rape in War, on the basis that their mere presence was likely to generate a hostile reaction. But there are many occasions when the primary obligation of the police must surely be to protect the rights of other protesters and not just, in effect, accede to the whims of those who are first in the field.

The second element in this cumulative three-tier model is this: That someone found the conduct subjectively offensive or insulting. There must be a requirement of this kind because if no one was actually offended or insulted, protests could be stifled simply on unfounded assumptions by law enforcement officers about likely effects. The question arises, however, as to how this requirement can be made to work in practice. In this regard, I accept that it would be appropriate for a police officer to be able to act, that is, give directions, on the basis that this element was satisfied if he had reasonable grounds for believing that someone was actually offended or insulted. For the offence itself, that is, of contravening a lawful direction, to be made out later in court it would be necessary to produce evidence that someone was actually offended. In the circumstances of the Canberra marches of the past, that is unlikely to be a difficult condition to satisfy.

The third crucial element in the three-tier model is this: That the conduct was objectively offensive or insulting. The requirement here is that a reasonable man or woman in all the circumstances would have been offended or insulted. It is necessary to add that third criterion to ensure that the first two do not operate illiberally. Conduct which is objectively inoffensive can nonetheless both offend particular, albeit unreasonable, individuals and be likely for that reason to cause a breach of the peace. Such conduct should not be restrained or punished on that basis. If that means that extra police resources may have to be devoted on occasion to protecting inoffensive provokers from unreasonable persons who are provoked, that is a price that simply has to be paid if we are to remain serious about fundamental civil liberties principles.

I make clear that no final decision has been made by the Government about all of this, but we have been wrestling with these difficult concepts for some time in an endeavour to get the principles right. I thought it was perhaps worth flagging this sort of proposal for comment and consideration at this stage rather than have to deal with it on the run as it were in the context of the actual legislation when it comes forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit late for Anzac Day.

—Regrettably, it seems that it may be. The new legislation, when it is promulgated by Mr Uren, will mark a significant departure from the approach of the previous Government to the problems which have arisen in the past in the Anzac Day march and ceremony in Canberra. By attempting to establish a separate category of so-called limited participation assemblies, which included the Anzac Day march, the previous Government merely exacerbated the problems. Because it considered the old legislation an affront to civil liberties, this Government repealed it soon after coming to power in March 1983. The new legislation will accord appropriate recognition to the civil liberties of the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory. We believe it will set the scene for the resolution of Anzac Day problems in the future in an atmosphere of consultation and co-operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not in any way criticise Senator Lewis for bringing forward this Bill. We believe it is a well-intentioned measure which does capture part of the reason at least why Anzac Day is such an important ceremony and so dear to the hearts of all Australians. The Government believes that it is important not to be carried away by that very obvious consideration as to ignore in the process, or perhaps to insufficiently emphasise in the process, the other values which are so crucial to the maintenance of democratic societies such as our own. We believe that Senator Lewis's Bill should not be passed in its present form. We look forward to the promulgation in the future of legislation for the Australian Capital Territory which will guarantee that RSL marches and ceremonies can be conducted with the propriety and solemnity that they deserve, but at the same time ensure that the rights of peaceful assembly of other Canberra citizens and visitors will not be infringed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I address myself to the debate on the second reading of the Anzac Day Bill 1983 which was brought down by Senator Lewis. I am somewhat surprised and disappointed that we should be finding it so difficult to instigate this sort of legislation. I should have thought that it would have had the considerable support not only of all the people in this chamber but, significantly, of all Australians. However, if that is not to be the case, at least in the short term, I will seek permission to incorporate in Hansard Senator Lewis's proposed amendments and the explanatory memorandum. He has seven amendments which I believe totally meet the requirements of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which examined this Bill some time ago and brought down some relevant and quite logical observations. Those observations will be incorporated into the Bill via these proposed amendments. As an aid to understanding what this is about, I will read the explanatory memorandum to the amendments. There are seven points altogether which state:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Defines a Committee to include the National President of the R.S.L., the Chief of Defence Force Staff, and the Director of the Australian War Memorial ( or their respective nominees);
2. & 3. Substitutes the current title of the R.S.L.;
4. Requires the President to act on the advice of the Committee in arranging appropriate observances to mark Anzac Day in the A.C.T.;
5. Enables the Committee to seek the advice of others;
6. Deletes the right of the President to ignore the advice of the Committee;
7. Requires the President to advise unsuccessful applicants of their rights of review.

That really seems not only to cover the matters that were highlighted by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee but also very realistically to come to grips with virtually any opposition that could be raised to this Bill. I was surprised and disappointed to read the proposition of the Australian Democrats, who seeks to have control vested in the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. If we wanted to insult totally ex-service men and women in Australia that would be one simple way to do it.

The Anzac Day Bill seeks to establish Anzac Day as a national day of remembrance and provides for commemoration services in the national capital. As I said earlier, I am surprised and somewhat disappointed that there could be a long debate and various expressions of disapproval and disagreement on a matter such as this. Anzac Day has a particular place in the Australian traditional scene. It has been commemorated in this country since 1916, and I think great credit is due to Senator Lewis for having seen fit to bring this sort of legislation to the fore. It is, I believe, appropriate and absolutely logical that we should attempt, by legislation such as this, to ensure the proper recognition and control of a day that has been celebrated since 1916, a day that has been celebrated in this country from coast to coast, from north to south, from east to west, in towns and villages, in the provincial cities and in the great cities. It has indeed become a tradition within the Australian scene, very much a part of Australian history.

It is a unique day in that it commemorates the sacrifices of Australians in many, and in those days continuously, tragic circumstances. It commemorates sacrifices, but it certainly does not celebrate or glorify war or conflict in any way. It does not have even the slightest thing to do with hating one's enemy . It is a day concerned purely and simply with the recognition of the sacrifices that were made all those years ago and on occasions since. As I said, it does not seek to hate an enemy and it does not seek to glorify war. On the contrary, I believe the circumstances of the original Anzac Day, which this is all about, made no small contribution to the establishment of what I suppose we call an Australian national character. I refer to various elements of that character which, of course, have been found and developed in lots of other spheres. They have been found and developed in the history of this country's exploration and development-the challenges of distance, communication, loneliness, education and health in harsh terrain and a harsh climate. They have contributed to the characteristics which I believe also came significantly out of the Anzac experience. I think particularly of courage and tolerance, because if there is one thing that came out of Anzac, and indeed of other similar problem areas, it surely must have been the capacity of people to show a very real and significant measure of tolerance. Of course, alongside tolerance must have been a measure of humour and-the great Australian word-mateship. It is obvious to me that without those faculties Anzac Day would not have survived. They were the qualities that enabled it to become something which we in Australia, and indeed Australians and others around the world, have commemorated year after year.

Finally, in this context, there is no shadow of doubt that the Anzac experience enabled at least some people to survive and live another day, and probably enabled many of their descendants to continue on and to develop. Discipline and a measure of loyalty were faculties developed to a very high degree in the Anzac experience. There can be little or no doubt that without a measure of discipline , which I hope and believe is part of the Australian national character, there is no way on earth that the freedom we spend so much time talking about will ever survive. It did indeed make a very significant contribution to the Australian character along those lines-lines which have been emphasised in Australian history.

The word 'Anzac' was protected commercially many years ago. In fact it was protected back in 1921. It is a very sad thing that today it should be seen to be necessary to protect it against minorities seeking to use it for their own promotions. I emphasise that I am not suggesting that minorities of all colour and creed with various objectives should not have a right to promote what they honestly believe. Indeed they have, but they certainly do not have, in my view, a right to impede commemoration of a day such as Anzac Day with a view to destroying a significant part of Australia's history. Whilst I believe there is every reason for the right of freedom of assembly, there is no reason why that sort of thing should be permitted to destroy observations of such value and national signficance as the celebration of Anzac Day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated under sessional order for consideration of General Business having expired, the Senate will proceed with further consideration of Government Business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.
[COGNATE BILLS:
FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA AMENDMENT BILL 1984
AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT SOLICITOR (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984]
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In winding up the cognate debate on the second reading stage of the Judiciary Amendment Bill ( No. 2), the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill and the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill, I remind the Senate that the legislation does two things, the first of which is to replace the personal office of Crown Solicitor with a corporate entity to be known as the Australian Government Solicitor, an entity which in fact will be the legal firm name under which the Commonwealth Government acts.
—Are not a 'firm' and a 'corporate entity' a contradiction in terms?

—It is not a contradiction in terms, if I might confront that point directly.
