Senator Durack made the point in the course of his remarks that it is odd or unusual to establish a firm of solicitors, using that expression in a loose way, as a corporate entity. He needs to appreciate that although no doubt it is not a familiar animal in Western Australia, where he commenced practice, the incorporation of solicitors' practices and the informal description of those practices as firms is not unknown. It is allowed for in South Australia and the Northern Territory. In South Australia the practising certificate is issued, I am told, to the company in question. Moreover, it is worth mentioning that the Treasury Solicitor in England is a corporation sole.

SPEECH.PARA: Since we have started on that part of the legislation, I will now deal with the other aspect of Senator Durack's challenge to the particular amendment here proposed. He says that the Australian Government Solicitor concept is a totally bureaucratic exercise which does not make much sense and ought not to be such as should be accepted without demur by this Parliament. He proposes that this matter be referred to a committee of the Parliament for further examination. Although I appreciate that the subject is one of some sensitivity to Senator Durack, he ought to be reminded that the proposal results from a substantial change in the structure of the Attorney-General's Department, a change which flows in turn from the manifest failures of administrative performance by that Department in recent years in that part of the Department's activities which represents its activities as the legal firm, in effect, for the nation. The Crown Solicitor's Division of the Department has tended to be separate from the rest of the Department in many respects and the report of the review of the structure and organisation of the Department referred to the problems and indeed the necessity of integrating the Crown Solicitor's Division into the Department.

The abolition of the personal office of the Crown Solicitor will allow a rearrangement and a rationalisation of the legal services performed by the Department for its clients. Moreover, whereas under the old arrangement professional responsibility for all actions carried on throughout Australia in the name of the Crown Solicitor was carried out by the Crown Solicitor in Canberra, creating a situation in which there was an overload of work at the top , the present proposal will create a framework within which professional responsibility to the courts for the conduct of actions can be exercised at the regional office level by the officers in charge of those offices. We are talking about a legal firm which operates in an environment in which currently some 11, 000 matters are in litigation around Australia. Obviously it is impossible for any one person to accept responsibility on such a large scale. That is the underlying rationale for this change. Many other points could be made but they were essentially made in the second reading speech. I am a little puzzled, a little surprised and a little disappointed that Senator Durack should continue to quibble about what is manifestly a sensible and overdue change.

The real nub of this debate concerns not the argument about the Australian Government Solicitor concept but rather the other step that this legislation takes which is to abolish appeals as of right, to the extent that they exist, to the High Court of Australia and create in their place a situation whereby it is proposed that in future all appeals to the High Court be by way of special leave . This proposal has produced an enthusiastic campaign against abolition from the Law Council of Australia and the Australian Bar Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing at all to do with vested interests?

—Not a thing. That campaign is being built around the general theme that the abolition of the appeal right here proposed amounts to a denial of access, a denial of right of appeal, traditionally enjoyed, to the High Court and as such something that, it is said, is unconscionable and highly unattractive. The campaign, and the discussion associated with that campaign, has been going on for some time-in fact, since around the middle of last year when I first floated publicly the proposal that special leave be the only route to the High Court in its appellate jurisdiction. I believe that since that time, and since the Government's position was floated, the arguments have really been pretty well exhausted. There simply is not any point in a full scale committee examination of this proposal of the kind that is proposed in Senator Durack's amendment to the motion for the second reading. That amendment would require the reference of all this legislation to the Senate committee. I make it clear, though, that I am certainly happy to delay the Committee stage consideration of this legislation until Parliament meets next week in order to allow such further deliberation as anyone wants to give to the detailed legislative proposals which are now before the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: There are problems with the present system of appeals by way of special leave and I believe that those problems should be frankly acknowledged as part of understanding the background to the Government's proposal. In the first place, it is not the case that all appeals that should be going to the High Court at the moment are going to the High Court. I think all of us-practitioners, the High Court itself and, I hope, other members of this Parliament-would agree that the two basic categories of measures which ought to be allowed to be appealed to the High Court and which ought to be guaranteed passage to the High Court are: Firstly, those matters where what is in issue is a law of general application or certainly of public importance where the High Court has some belief that the law is in need of examination and has not been properly stated by the courts below; and, secondly, the category of cases, both civil and criminal, where there is some reason to suppose that a miscarriage of justice might have occurred in the particular case. It may be that a point of law of major importance is not involved at all but where there is some reason to believe that justice may not have been done, that the administration of justice might be put at risk in some way if the matter were not appealed, that is obviously a case which ought to be able to go to the High Court. I repeat: I do not believe that, at the moment, it is the case that all of the matters which satisfy one or other of those two general descriptions are, for one reason or another, getting to the High Court, and they should.

The second problem that is evident with the systems as presently operating is that special leave applications are expensive. They involve two bites of the cherry, not always in criminal matters where, for the most part, the Court tends to treat the application for special leave as the appeal itself and hears and determines the whole matter on the spot, but certainly in civil matters the application for special leave is made by one group of practitioners flying to Canberra, staying overnight and appearing, albeit often only for a few minutes, in the High Court the following day and going back to their respective cities, and then the same group or perhaps an even more expensive group of practitioners flying up to Canberra for the hearing and determination of the appeal itself at some later stage. That can be very expensive indeed for litigants. That point has to be readily acknowledged. To that extent, any system which implies a greater number of matters having to be dealt with in that two-stage way does need to be accompanied by some kind of provisions to ensure that extra expense is not unnecessarily incurred. The Government very much takes that point on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having taken it on board, what are you going to do about it?

—I will get to that in a moment. Senator Haines should curb her racing hormones. We have some considerable time yet to deal with this matter . I think it is important, since the matter has attracted genuine public concern --
—Carry on; we are enjoying every minute of it.
—I would not expect Senator Archer to appreciate the subtleties of this matter.
—Who would you expect to appreciate them?

—That is a very good question in this chamber. Senator Durack, for a start, is not bad on these matters, Senator Haines has been doing very well in recent days. I am not sure about anyone else in the chamber at the moment. Senator McIntosh, Senator Primmer, Senator Reynolds and Senator Jones are very good on these matters. I think there is really quite a considerable number of people who are interested and keen to get this one right, particularly in the context that we will be debating the details of it next week, and I think we ought to understand the basic principles.
—Do you want some more senators in here for support?
—I think that would be something of a waste of time.
—Curb your boyish impetuousness; you never know where it will lead you.

—I appreciate Senator Martin's thoughtfulness. There is a third problem governing the system of appeals generally to the High Court which is particularly strongly felt in the smaller States of the Federation. It is felt in those States with smaller courts where there is a limited pool of judges to appeal to and to appeal from. The argument in relation to those States with those small courts tends to be-it is very understandable-that there should be a second tier of appeals more or less automatically accessible to litigants and practitioners in those jurisdictions. What is the solution to those problems? The only answer that has been given by the organised legal profession has really been to stick with the present monetary criterion. At the moment when we are talking about appeals as of right we are only talking about a very limited category of appeals; those where the sum in issue is more than $20,000, except in personal injury cases where the argument is only about quantum. The argument of the Law Council of Australia is at least let us keep intact the principle that where there is a lot of money involved those sorts of cases ought to be able to go. It acknowledges that $20,000 is not, any longer, very much money and is quite happy to contemplate a quite substantial addition to that criterion, but nonetheless that is as far as it puts it. It floated in its letter, which was incorporated by Senator Haines, it may have been, or by somebody else in the earlier stages of this debate--
—Senator Hill supported my view.

—Senator Hill. Senator Haines's argument was sufficient to stand on its own feet without any documentary help whatsoever. There have been other possible criteria for automatic appeals that have been floated by the legal profession. For example where there is division in the court below. It has been suggested that that is sufficient ground for the matter to go automatically up to the High Court. It has also been suggested that, where the court below certifies the matter as appropriate to be dealt with on appeal by the High Court , that too represents a category of matters that should come as of right to the High Court. Even the most cursory examination should make people appreciate that there is nothing about any of those criteria which will guarantee that the right cases do go to the High Court: Those cases where there is some genuine reason to believe that a miscarriage of justice of some kind may have occurred or those cases where some point of law or of genuine public importance is involved. Particularly indefensible in principle and particularly incapable of producing solutions to that problem in practice is the criterion based purely in terms of dollars and cents. Whatever other criterion or criteria it may be possible to tailor, I do not believe that we should for a moment contemplate giving aid and comfort to those who would argue in terms of a maintenance of the status quo with a monetary criterion, albeit one substantially increased.
—Unless we were able to go to the pre-1976 situation. According to them there has been some difference in the way the cost was determined.

—I understand the point. One way of narrowing it is by saying that the amount of money that is at risk for the person is of that magnitude. If it is an argument about a house that is worth $20,000, that is one thing; if it is where the actual sum that is at risk for the individual was of that order of magnitude, that is another way. But the same point can be made by simply increasing the sum of money involved to a higher amount. Really, I suggest, as I think Senator Haines would appreciate, her having mastered the intricacies of this subject matter over the past few days, that really does not alter the situation one iota in terms of the basic issues of principle that are involved.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to what I described as the third problem, that which particularly afflicts the smaller States and those jurisdications with smaller courts, I think the only point that can be said is that any of the automatic criteria do not help the problem there either. The only thing that would help that problem is for all matters to be appealable automatically to the High Court. That is clearly not defensible either. It may be that there is a longer term solution likely to be available with the creation of an integrated Australian court of appeal which many of us, including, I know, Senator Durack, are keen to establish which would create a larger pool of appellate judges to appeal to. But clearly that is not something that will be with us in the near future.

The reality is that the Government's solution, for all the attention and concern that is attracted in some quarters, is a better one. It will free up the Court to deal with those important cases which are being refused access to the Court at the margin at the moment. I think the best way of demonstrating that is to refer to some of the statistics about the operation of the Court. I appreciate that the statistics that are prepared by and for the Court at the moment are not terribly useful or revealing in terms of enabling us to readily come to grips with this problem of how the Court is organising its business at the moment.

Let us look at it in these terms: The average number of reported cases heard by the High Court each year is about 100. Sometimes it is more, sometimes it is less. The average number of appeals heard by the Court each year is anywhere between 30 and 70. In recent years there have been some quite marked fluctuations. Of the total number of appeals that are heard by the Court-it will be appreciated that the Court does many other things apart from hearing appeals; it hears matters in the first instance and so on in its original jurisdiction- the number of appeals that come up as of right represents a very substantial proportion. In 1981, 40 per cent of all appeals came up as of right. In 1982, 60 per cent of all appeals heard by the Court were as of right. In 1983, 64 per cent of all appeals were heard as of right. Appeals as of right represent-to the best that one can ascertain from the statistics-generally somewhere between 30 per cent and 50 per cent of the Court's total work load measured by the number of cases it is hearing.

Moreover, appeals as of right represent an even more substantial actual burden on the Court because they come up to the Court in their entirety. The Court does not just pick and choose the particular points that it wants to deal with. When an appeal comes up as of right the Court must deal with the whole matter. If there is a contest about the weight of evidence, often the Court has to wade through dozens of volumes of evidence in order to deal with that point. It may involve no point of law of general application. There may be no reason to believe that a particular miscarriage of justice has occurred; it might just be an argument about the construction of a commercial document. This is the sort of thing that is occupying an enormous amount of the Court's time.

The essential argument of the Government in accepting the Court's own view of its problems at the moment is that were the Court able to get rid of the appeals as of right which have no other merit associated with them it would have that much more time available to deal with, on a special leave basis, those cases which are, on the face of it, infinitely more meritorious. One can argue about just how much more time would be available, but on the figures I have indicated it is clearly substantial. Of course, it is the case that some of those matters going up as of right would also come up on a special leave basis because in some instances they would involve matters of general importance or the case itself would raise questions about the possible miscarriage of justice.

The best estimate-it is really only intuitive-that I can get from people associated with the Court is that perhaps a quarter of the cases presently coming up on appeal as of right involve special leave points. The special leave points would not necessarily represent the totality of the matters in issue in each case. It may be that many of those cases involving a special leave point would occupy the Court's time far less coming up that way than they do coming up , as now, as of right. Although it is difficult to be precise-I appreciate that a number of honourable senators wanted more precise statistics in this respect-I believe the general scale of the problem and the way in which the Government's solution will contribute to resolve the difficulties can be steadily appreciated .

The other side of what the Government is trying to do here, which is not apparent on the face of the legislation but which was mentioned in the second reading speech, is to try to make some administrative arrangements which will relieve the cost burdens on litigants that are associated with the special leave procedure. The Court has agreed now in principle, and the Government has agreed to accommodate it in this respect, to have regular sittings in both Sydney and Melbourne in order to hear special leave applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Western Australia and other States?

—I am coming to that. At the moment the Court visits Western Australia and other States, albeit very rarely-perhaps once a year. At the moment it does not visit Sydney and Melbourne at all. So all litigation coming from Sydney and Melbourne, every application for special leave, necessarily involves an interstate plane trip for the persons concerned. So far as the west, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania are concerned, clearly it will not be possible, because of the relative quantity of numbers coming forward , for any more regular sittings to be built into the system, but I think it is a matter of looking at the ways in which new technology can contribute to a solution. One of the things which the Government is looking at, although it sounds pretty exotic for our courts, which are not quick to be susceptible to innovation, and which I believe deserves serious consideration is the idea of the video conference. It would involve setting up a big video screen with the relevant counsel arguing the case directly, face to face, to the Court in Canberra.
—Would they have to robe, do you think?

—They might have to robe, depending on whether it was a chamber application. The honourable senator will recall the exotic distinctions that apply. The point I am making is simply that there are administrative solutions which in a lateral way can solve some of these problems which will not be resolved by the really quite inequitable and, with respect, silly system that is operating at the moment and which is just not guaranteeing, as I keep saying, that the cases that should get up do get up.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Critchton-Browne-You would not have written submissions?

TALK.START.PARA: — I am canvassing with the Court the question of written submissions. The difficulty is that most members of the legal profession find the concept of written submissions quite anathema. Whether it is because they have difficulty in writing coherently as distinct from talking, which seems to come much more easily to members of my profession, remains to be seen. I am particularly anxious that the question of written submissions be looked at for applications in criminal matters. At the moment, the Court will not entertain applications for special leave without legal representation. I believe that can create injustices of its own kind. These are the kinds of things that are being very actively pursued by the Government at the moment in order to try to resolve what it readily acknowledges to be a real problem in the operation of a special leave system. It seems that nobody really wants to move to the American system where everything is done on the papers in the first instance and the court makes a decision yea or nay on all the thousands of matters that are put to it, but I think there are ways in which we can improve the way in which the special leave system operates.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points made in this respect-I will be quicker dealing with the last few points I want to make-is the desirability of reasons being expressed by the Court in the course of dealing with special leave applications. Senator Haines was particularly keen to make this point, as indeed are many members of the legal profession. There is a real difficulty in trying to legislatively instruct or force the High Court to give reasons in special leave applications without making life impossibly difficult for the High Court and in effect turning each matter it deals with on special leave into a mini-appeal in its own right. About the only way we can get past this problem in a legislative way, is, I suspect, by outlining in great detail all the possible criteria that might be thought appropriate by the Court in accepting or refusing a special leave aplication and then enabling the Court to rely on one or other of those formulae to identify to the litigants why it has decided as it has.

There is a difficulty about that because it is difficult to state in precise legislative form all the criteria which have been applied in the past, quite apart from those which might be thought relevant in the future. Again, in that respect I am having continuing discussions with the Court. I am concerned to ensure that, so far as possible, reasons are given to litigants so that it can be understood why it is that a particular matter has been dealt with. The Court tends to tell me that in 99 per cent of the cases the litigants will be very well aware from the course of the oral argument what it is that has actually moved the Court to decide as it does. I believe this can be resolved by further consultation and discussion. It is certainly very difficult to see a way of resolving it by actually changing the terms of the legislation.

However, one of the things we can do in the legislation, and one of the things I believe we should do, is actually incorporate into the legislation at least some of the criteria which the Court has traditionally taken into account in determining special leave applications and which really are the central criteria in this respect. We will be considering this matter at the Committee stage and I will not stop to deal with it now. For the record, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of the amendment which the Government proposes in this respect, which is the incorporation of a new section 35A in the Judiciary Act articulating essentially the two basic considerations that I set out earlier-the idea of the public importance or general significance of the point of law and, on the other hand, the idea of the necessity to deal with the possibility of a miscarriage of justice in a particular case.
Leave granted.
The amendment read as follows-
Criteria for granting special leave to appeal

'35A. In considering whether to grant an application for special leave to appeal to the High Court under this Act or under any other Act, the High Court may have regard to any matters that it considers relevant but shall have regard to-
(a) whether the proceedings in which the judgment to which the application relates was pronounced involve a question of law-
(i) that is of public importance, whether because of its general application or otherwise; or

(ii) in respect of which a decision of the High Court, as the final appellate court, is required to resolve differences of opinion between different courts, or within the one court, as to the state of the law; and
(b) whether the interests of the administration of justice, either generally or in the particular case, require consideration by the High Court of the judgment to which the application relates.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law Council has indicated a certain willingness to accept that, albeit as a second best solution to its concerns. Senator Haines in her speech indicated some of the further amendments that the Law Council was pressing upon the Government if it was going to proceed down the section 35A path. Those changes are unacceptable, for reasons that I can perhaps better explain at the Committee stage of the debate but which have to do with technical problems associated with them rather than any lack of appreciation on my part or on the Government's part of what the Law Council is trying to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that there is a real problem with the High Court's work load generally . The figures that have been made available to interested members demonstrate that. But the more particular problem in the High Court at the moment is the clogging up of the system by the appeals as of right that are being heard. I believe our job as a government and as a legislature is to help unclog the system and to ensure the application of proper principles. I believe that the system, as it is proposed to be amended by the Government, will work effectively and fairly. It will nationalise the High Court's work load and satisfy the legal profession, although its members are grumbling still. I believe it will be fair to litigants.

Let me conclude by saying that I do not assert that as an article of faith. I am happy and the Government is happy to test it. I told the Law Council in discussions the other night and I say it now publicly, that the Government is very happy to consult with the Law Council and the High Court to establish a basis for the effective monitoring and review of the new system. As I have indicated already, the statistics that are presently gleaned by the High Court and its registry are not especially helpful in trying to come to grips with the particular problem of working out how the present as of right, special leave system operates. One has to really burrow, in the way that I have endeavoured to do to provide the foundation for this speech tonight, to give the sorts of figures that can be given with appropriate research. We need to be able to pull out those figures and identify what is working and what is not working under the new system.

I make it clear that the Government will fully review the operation of the new system no later than two years after its introduction, and certainly will do so earlier than that if it is apparent that any particular problems have arisen that need correction. I believe that the Government has acted in complete good faith throughout the course of this obviously sensitive and important debate that has been going on with the profession since the middle of last year. We have consulted extensively and we believe that the data on which the case can be made is clearly available. We believe that the Parliament should make the only decision which, so far as it creates new legislative guidelines in this area, will ensure that justice is genuinely done in the cases with which the High Court deals.

I have indicated that the Government, for all those reasons, believes that the matters are ones that can be relatively quickly and easily grasped, although there are some difficulties in coming to grips with the data easily and, as such , there is no necessity to refer the matter to a Senate committee. The principles involved are relatively clearcut and such remaining discussion as needs to occur can happen in the context of the Committee debate on this measure which will now occur next week.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Durack's amendment) be left out .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bill in the Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Veterans: Repatriation System-Mrs Irene Greenwood-Importation of Soft Goods

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators receive a great deal of correspondence every day, and on some occasions one is confronted with what to do about a constituent's complaint or problem. Often one feels at a complete loss to be able to do anything. I would like to read a letter that I received today because I believe it contains an example of some of the problems that exist within our community on an individual basis. It comes from a veteran, who states:

SPEECH.PARA: I speak as an Australian front line solider who served his country without reservation for 5 years 10/12 months. I enlisted at 16 . . . served in every threatre of war as an infantry man or special operations behind enemy lines.
He had forged his birth certificate and changed his name, as often happened during the Second World War. The letter continues:
I was wounded, injured, suffered malaria . . . dysentry, dengue . . . tropical ulcers, malnutrition and was still fighting the Japanese 2 weeks after VJ ( Victory Japan day).

When I cam out after 4 months in hospital I was a mental and physical wreck. For 4 years I could not face the public-I was unemployed. It has taken years to literally pull myself out of the mire. I never (and neither have my frontline mates) expected that Australia owed me a living but certainly I . . . did expect justice.
Here are some examples.
(a) Although I had . . . dysentry the Repat refused to accept it as a war caused disability for seven years. I had to pay for my medical all that time-yet they had the medical evidence.
(b) only several months ago they finally accepted an injury to eye as war caused-because they said that there was no evidence-I was injured in Greece but it was never recorded.
(c) Although I was exposed to repeated and gross stress-see attached history-I was never debriefed, never had access to psychological treatment.
(b) the Repat has committed some dreadful errors of judgement, divulged medical history which penalised the future of the exsoldier.
Rather than itemise in this letter please refer to attached list of questions . . .

The Parliament have NO idea of what is being done to us. We have lost jobs or had them jeopardised because of our service, the insurance companies have penalised us. Many of us including myself had to pay our own medical expenses until finally we were accepted. We have lost our sick leave entitlements in some cases had to use our holidays to get treatment. In my case I did not have a holiday in 11 years . . .

It was not until 1983 when under the 'Freedom of Information Act 1982' I found out that the Repat had evidence of some of my illnesses-yet all this time they had kept asking me for evidence which in fact was in their possession-I also found out the Army had failed to include some wounds, injuries, diseases . . .

Please Sir-I know you are very busy-but please take time to digest what I have sent you. I repeat I and many of my mates have never thought that Australia owed us a living but No one ever told us we would have to subsidise our war caused medical costs for wounds and diseases experience whilst serving our country.

. . . please let me address the sitting. I am not a stirer, I am not political. ALL I ask is to please let me . . . adress Parliament and . . . explain what is being done to US who really served our country.
I am prepared to go to Canberra at my own cost.
I can produce a lot of documentary evidence. I am. now 61. I have little time left. You politicians really do not know, are not aware of the grave injustices. Please let me speak.

Fairly obviously, it would not be possible for that ex-soldier to address the Senate but he has provided me with a list of questions that he would like put and I would like to put them now. I do not expected the Minister at the Table, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to answer them, but I believe they are the types of questions that one meets time and again from veterans around the country. While both the previous Government and the present Government try very hard at the legislative level and often at the administrative level to meet many of the complaints, the fact that these complaints still come, and seem to come in increasing numbers, leads me to be more and more concerned about the administration of the Repatriation Act of this country and its operation at various levels. Why is that so? Why do so many people still suffer from obvious injustices?

I would seek the indulgence of the Senate to read the list of questions on behalf of this person who obviously cannot speak before the Senate. Why has Repat refused claims allegedly on grounds of lack of medical evidence when in fact that evidence is in the medical files of the armed services? Why have the politicians reduced the drug entitlements of returned soldiers? How come the insurance companies are allowed to load the premiums on diggers who contracted tropical diseases during the war? How come the Army failed to include all medical history in the records of the ex-digger, making it impossible to prove what diseases, illnesses or wounds he has suffered? Why does it take up to eight months for a digger to get an appointment with a specialist? Why has the Government never carried out a survey of life expectancy based on abnormal stresses, wounds and diseases of ex-diggers? The insurance companies have and so penalise returned servicemen accordingly by loading premiums. How come Repat can refuse to accept a disability for up to seven years, and in one case 30 years, and then, when it does accept them, not backdate although the ex-soldier has been carrying the burden of related medical and doctors' expenses all that time? Politicians, workers and even reporters-or their estates-get lump sum settlements both in and out of court under common law or workers compensation. Why not the soldier? How come Repat can divulge a personal medical history to an ex-digger's firm and so endanger his employment? Why does an ex-soldier have to exhaust his sick leave entitlement with his firm, because of war caused disabilities, and then have to use up his annual leave? What right has Repat to ask employment and wage details of a recipient of a disability pension? Does this mean, for example, that if there are two ex-servicemen, each of whom has lost one hand, the one with double the salary of the other gets less disability pension?

Very obviously, some of those questions are relatively easy to answer but some are much more difficult. Some, in fact, are examples of injustices which have occurred time and again. I want to put that one person's request to me on the record not only because of what I have read out but also because he has included a copy of a diary that he kept during the war, from 1942 to two weeks after peace. The reason that the diary was kept for two weeks after peace was that at the end of the war this then young man had been behind enemy lines, often entirely alone and often working with people from various places. He was situated in Borneo for most of the war. When one reads the diary one is struck by the horror that that person went through. One entry in 1942 reads in such a way that one wonders how he could have maintained his sanity for another two or three years.

That person, who fulfilled his duty to the Australian nation, now has to write that letter in 1984. I believe that the fact he has had to do so is a blot on this nation. It is also a blot on this Parliament in terms of the type of overview that it has had of the administration of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, of the repatriation system. One wonders how we are eventually ever going to solve these problems. I and many other members of parliament receive similar letters time and again. Something must be done. These people who cry out for justice cannot be left. This person cannot be left alone at the age of 61, after all these years, to battle the repatriation system, to fight yet another war for what are just entitlements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to tie in the matter of public importance we discussed today with an article which appeared in this morning's edition of the West Australian newspaper. Frequently newspaper stories which concern Western Australia are unlikely to make many of the newspapers in the eastern States. I tie in the matter of public importance because page 3 of the West Australian contains an article which is headed 'The day her ship came in'. It relates to a touching story of a woman who devoted her entire lifetime to the promotion not only of her own gender but also of peace. I refer to Mrs Irene Greenwood who will be well known to a lot of people in this chamber, particularly to those who come from Western Australia. Irene is now 84 years of age. It was the Western Australian State Government's wish that the new ship that was being put into service by the State shipping line should be named after her.

SPEECH.PARA: Irene has done a tremendous amount of work for the peace movement in Western Australia and, indeed, throughout the world. She has represented many organisations on many occasions. I had the honour of appearing on a number of platforms with her. I want to demonstrate that totally unselfish attitude of Irene by quoting an expression that she used in this article when she was interviewed. The article stated:
'I am not pleased just for myself,' she said. 'I think it is a tribute to the generation of pioneer women in this great State.'

Irene Greenwood was born in Albany in 1899. As she would say, she is a very young woman-she was born in the last month of the last year of the last century. She has won international acclaim as a writer, broadcaster, social reformer and feminist. I think she was probably born as the latter. I cannot ever remember an occasion when she has not been putting forward very strong feminist views. Her work as a pioneer of the Australian women's movement was recognised when she was made a member of the Order of Australia in 1975. On that occasion I had the honour of taking her to lunch in Parliament House. I remember the absolute joy and pleasure she felt at that time, not because she had been recognised but because as a woman and a peace worker there was at long last recognition of some of the work that people were doing. In 1981 she became one of the first women to receive an honorary doctorate from Murdoch University. The same year she was awarded the United Nations Peace Medal. I think that is the most important point . Following the matter of public importance that we discussed today, I think it is important that a tribute is paid to people such as Irene Greenwood who has demonstrated that she is not only a wonderful person in her own right but also one who cares for the rest of humanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notified the office of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) that I intended to raise a matter on the adjournment debate tonight. I know that the Minister's absence is unavoidable and therefore I do not make any point of the fact that he is not able to give me an immediate answer. However, I would ask that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who is in charge of the Senate at the moment, draw my remarks to the attention of the Minister tomorrow. I refer to the concern that is arising in Victoria about what is regarded as excessive delay with the import of certain soft goods. A very lengthy time is taken to test the quality and content of the imported merchandise. This testing is done at the government laboratories which, it is suggested, are either understaffed or inefficient, or both.

SPEECH.PARA: The Melbourne Chamber of Commerce informs me that two government agencies, the Customs Service and the Department of Science and Technology, are involved and suggests that is the problem. Products from overseas were being held up on the wharf for six to eight weeks due to testing delays. Members of the Chamber of Commerce have to finance soft goods for the eight weeks they do not have access and, additionally, are missing out on the seasonal sale to wholesalers and retailers. It is suggested private testing authorities should be authorised to carry out the testing procedure if it cannot be done expeditiously by the Government laboratory.

The request made by the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce, both to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), in their respective capacities in relation to Customs and the laboratories, was that steps be taken urgently to reduce financial suffering, alleviate concern, and avoid wasting the time of a significant number of people. It is claimed that importers of made up fabrics and importers of fabrics for manufacture in Australia are being held up and that this is having an effect on the availability of domestically manufactured goods as well as on employment in manufacturing. The consequential losses are total losses as the firms concerned miss out on the market. As the winter market is about to be embarked upon, it is obvious that urgent action should be taken by the Government to overcome an unconscionable delay as a result of what is regarded as an administrative breakdown in the operation of government. I ask that the matter be brought to the attention of the relevant Ministers tomorrow, with a request that they indicate to the Senate tomorrow whether some action can be taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall comment briefly on the matters raised by honourable senators in this debate and ensure that action is taken where needed. Senator Macklin read a letter from a veteran constituent which is of concern to us all, particularly as it raises serious accusations about the Department of Veterans' Affairs. He talked of inaccuracy in Veterans' Affairs records, improper behaviour by the Department in not recognising the presence of diseases on medical records, and an even more serious accusation that the Department exposed medical records in an unauthorised way in that without authorisation it informed employers of illnesses suffered by employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I have two comments to make. First, I shall draw the letter quoted by Senator Macklin to the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt ). However, as the Minister will not be able to identify the person concerned, he will not be able to do very much. Secondly, I would have thought that any such serious accusations should have been brought by the honourable senator to the attention of the Minister and the Department to ensure that some justice was done.

I am glad that Senator Coleman let the House know that a ship in Western Australia had been named after Irene Greenwood. I can describe her in the Senate as the grand old lady of the peace movement in Western Australia, and in some ways of Australia, but I must say I would never say that to her face for fear of what she might do to me. She is a fine lady and I am glad that she has been recognised in this way.

Senator Rae said that he notified Senator Button's office tonight. Unfortunately, Senator Button is in Sydney, but his office has been alerted to this matter. Clearly, on the face of the matter excessive delays such as have been instanced cannot be tolerated and something should be done about it in an important area of this type. I shall ensure that Senator Button knows about the matter in the morning and that Senator Rae will be given an answer as soon as possble.
Senate adjourned at 10.45 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Authorities, Committees and Bureaus: Department of Science and Technology

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 29 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What new authorities, committees, bureaus, or other such groups: (a) have been established; or (b) are proposed, by or within this Department, since 5 March 1983.
(2) How many additional staff: (a) have been, or are being, appointed; or (b) are proposed to be recruited, as a result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Two committees and one board have been established within this Department since 5 March 1983. They are the national biotechnology program- Research Grants Advisory Committee which has a chairman and four members who were appointed on 1 September 1983; the National Research Fellowships Advisory Committee which has a chairman and eight members who were appointed on 1 December 1983; and the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board which has a chairman and six members who were appointed on 1 February 1984.
(1) (b) No other authorities, committees, bureaus, or other such groups are proposed to be established within this Department at this time.

(2) (a) and (b) No additional departmental staff have been, or are in the process of being, appointed directly to these bodies. However, fifteen staff will be used initially to administer the operational procedures resulting from the creation of the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board and six staff will be used to provide support to the other two committees. It is expected that staff from within the Australian Public Service will be recruited. As the selection process is taking place it is not possible to identify the number of positions which may be filled from outside the Department at this time .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do many patients seeking in vitro fertilisation (IVF) have to travel extensive distances from all over Australia to receive this specialist service; if so, are such patients eligible for benefits under the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme as IVF is not currently a schedule item.
(2) What progress has the Department of Health made in reviewing this situation .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is being performed in all mainland State capital cities and people from country areas would therefore need to travel to the State capital to obtain this specialist service. One of the eligibility criteria for payment of benefits under the Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme (IPTAAS) is that the service received must be an item within the medical benefits schedule. The IPTAAS benefits are therefore not available to patients seeking IVF as it is not an item within the Schedule.

(2) A number of ethical and legal issues surrounding IVF have still to be resolved. The most appropriate method of funding these services has also to be determined and this matter will be considered in the forthcoming overall review of the Medical Benefits Schedule.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 15 December 1983.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Science and Technology seen the Royal Australian Chemical Institute report 'Why Doesn't Australia have a Research-Based Drug Industry'.
(2) What is the Government's reaction to the report and its recommendations.
(3) Will the Government set up a National Medicinal and Agro-Chemical Research and Development Council along similar lines to the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I refer the honourable senator to the Minister for Health's reply to the same question which appeared in Hansard on 6 March 1984. I would add that I broadly agree with the report's conclusion that Australia has virtually all the necessary research, development, marketing and finance resources to set up a viable research-based drug industry. However, it is not an area where we consider a broad spectrum approach to be appropriate, rather industry needs to identify particular areas where they might compete successfully. Great opportunity would appear to lie in the area of diagnostics, veterinary medicines and agro-chemicals, where Australia can afford the costs of developing a product to the marketable stage. For veterinary medicines and agro-chemicals Australia has the added advantage of being a substantial market in its own right.

The report identifies four factors which hinder a research-based drug and/or agro-chemical industry. These are a lack of defined national priorities, inadequate communication between researchers and industry, insufficient capital and inadequate toxicological facilities. The National Technology Conference in September 1983 addressed the problems of incentives for innovation, assistance measures and industry/research interaction. A National Technology Strategy which provides a coherent response to these issues through an active and anticipatory approach to technology development is currently under preparation.

The Government has introduced a range of measures which will address the factors raised in the RACI report. These include the national biotechnology program; the national research fellowships scheme; provision for the establishment of management and investment companies, including a 100 per cent tax deduction; and further support to industrial research and development through increased funding of the Australian industrial research development and incentives scheme.
The specific matter of the lack of toxicological facilities is one which may indeed warrant further consideration.

I would also note that there are at present significant efforts being made by Australian firms and groups such as the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, Biotechnology Australia, Bioclone Australia, Australian Monoclonal Development, Biotechnology Research Enterprises South Australia, Silenus Laboratories and others in the area of medicinal and agrochemical research. Several of these companies have received support through the national biotechnology program, which has to date funded several projects worth a total of $4.51m and through the Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme.

(3) The Minister for Health's reply to the same question on 6 March 1984 addresses this matter. I would add that the Government already has in place a range of funding mechanisms (listed above) which support medicinal and agro- chemical research and development. This particular field of research and development is just one of several areas which have been identified as having potential for producing growth industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 15 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any staff been employed to work on the proposed assets test program; if so, in which State and Territory were they (a) appointed; and (b) presently working.
(2) Was Public Service Board approval sought for their recruitment; if so, when was approval (a) sought; and (b) granted.
(3) What is the total number of new officers that the Public Service Board has approved for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to appoint for the proposed assets test program.
(4) How many other officers of the Department are working on the proposed assets test program.
(5) From which source are funds being used to pay the new recruits for the proposed assets test program.
(6) How many of the new officers are (a) permanent; and (b) temporary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) On the assumption that you are seeking information about new staff recruited to work on the assets test program, in the Department's central office in Canberra two persons have been employed to undertake work on the proposed income/assets test program. One has since been appointed permanently and one is a temporary employee.

In addition, 112 staff were employed, to undertake formal and on-the-job training to enable existing experienced staff to be released later in the year for the proposed income/assets test program. The 112 were made up as follows:
New South Wales-31
Victoria-31
Queensland-22
Western Australia-10
South Australia-13
Tasmania-5
(2) (a) and (b) The Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service matters agreed to staff intake plans until the end of March 1984 to allow for the recruitment of staff.

(3) The Department sought establishment approval from the Public Service Board for 543 positions for the income/assets test program. Of these positions, 498 were proposed to form a reserve pool to be allocated on a needs basis for work directly on the income/assets program. The Public Service Board had agreed to the establishment of 386 positions.
(4) One hundred and twenty-two other officers of the Department were working directly on the income/assets test program. The location of these staff was as follows:
Central Office-30
New South Wales-23
Victoria-19
Queensland-11
Western Australia-16
South Australia-14
Tasmania-7
Officers of the Department's systems division in central office were also providing assistance.

(5) Payments to staff working on the proposed income/assets test program and those undertaking formal and on-the-job training (see (1) above) have been made from the Department's normal appropriation pending augmentation from appropriation Division 312 (see my answer to Question No. 617).
(6) (a) and (b) With the exception of the one person referred to in (1) above, all recruitments are permanent officers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Euratom agreement effectively mean Australian control over uranium mined in Australia is lost when the uranium is delivered to one of the member nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Science and Technology Council inquiry into issues relating to Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle is currently examining Australia's nuclear safeguards arrangements, giving particular attention to the effectiveness of the bilateral and multilateral agreements, and to the scope for strengthening these agreements.

In the agreement between the Government of Australia and the European atomic energy community (Euratom), the community has undertaken that Australian origin nuclear material (AONM) shall, upon transfer to Euratom pursuant to the agreement and whilst under the jurisdiction of Euratom member states, be subject to the controls and safeguards specified in the agreement.

The agreement provides that AONM will be used in Euratom member countries only for peaceful and non-explosive purposes. Within Euratom's jurisdiction AONM is subject to the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards as well as Euratom safeguards and to agreed levels of physical protection.

The agreement also provides that AONM shall not be retransferred beyond the community to any other country, enriched beyond 20 per cent in the isotope U-235 , or reprocessed unless Australia gives prior consent. In the case of reprocessing, Australia has exercised its prior consent rights in advance on a long term basis under conditions agreed under the Australia/Euratom agreement. These conditions permit reprocessing under IAEA safeguards, for the purposes of energy use or spent fuel management, and in accordance with the delineated and recorded Euratom nuclear cycle program agreed with Australia. Reprocessing for other peaceful purposes, for example, research, requires prior consultation and agreement on the conditions to apply. Australia has also exercised its prior consent rights on a long term basis in the case of transfers between the community and third countries in accordance with the agreed fuel cycle program or to third countries with which Australia has a bilateral safeguards agreement, subject to Euratom's obligation to give Australia prompt notification in the case of each transfer of this type.
The agreement requires Euratom to provide Australia with regular reports accounting for AONM subject to the agreement.
